Oxford transcription team, 1992-1998: Peter Robinson, Elizabeth Solopova, Lorna Stevenson, with contributions from James McCabe, Hubert Stadler, Cathy Swires, Paul and Maureen Watry, Laura Wright, Diana Wyatt and Simon Horobin
Sheffield transcription team, 1992-1998, led by Norman Blake: Michael Pidd and Estelle Stubbs, with Linda Cross, Claire Thomson and Simon Horobin
De Montfort transcription team, 1998-2005: Peter Robinson, Barbara Bordalejo, Orietta Da Rold, Gavin Cole, Pip Willcox, Jennifer Marshall, Takako Kato, Jacob Thaisen, Nicole Green

Brigham Young University transcription team, 1995-2006, led by Paul Thomas: Sara Black, Jessica Cox, Barbara Christiansen, Kerry Clift Spencer*, Heidi Elldredge, Leona Fisher Sankhla, Kela Flint*, Melissa Gallup, Shannon Harris, Rebecca Johnson, Mary Jorgensen, Darin Merrill*, Wesley Pack*, Jared Perkins, Jon Penny, Randall Rogers, Ryan Rowberry*, Sara Slack, Carie Soderquist Jackson*, Kat Southerland, Matt Tenney, Briton Wright, John Young. University of Sheffield, 1994-1999, led by Norman Blake: Michael Pidd and Estelle Stubbs, with Linda Cross, Claire Thomson, Orietta Da Rold and Simon Horobin. In partnership with the Canterbury Tales Project, at that time led by Norman Blake in partnership with Peter Robinson and Elizabeth Solopova (up to 1998), and using images and other resources supplied by the Project, the Sheffield team transcribed eight manuscripts in full (Ad3, Corpus, Dd, Gg, Ellesmere, Ha4, Hengwrt, Lansdowne), sections of some seven other manuscripts, and all manuscripts of the Franklin's Tale. No part of these transcripts is contained in this iteration of the Project.

div.l: Ful fetouse was hir cloke as I was ware
Of smale corall a bouȝt hir arme she bare
A peyr of bedis gaudit al with greyn
And theron hyng a broche ful sheen
On wich was first I writen a crownyd . A .
And aftir that Amor vincit ommia
Anothir Nonne with hir had she
That was hir chapeleyn and prestis thre
A Monk there was for the mastry
An owt rider he lovid venory
A manly man to be an abbot abill
Ful many a deynte hors he had in his Stabill
And when he rode men myȝt his bridill here
Gynglyng ⁊and wistleyng in the wynd clere
And eke as lowde as doith a chapell bell
Ther as the lord was keper of the sell
The reule of Seynt Maury ⁊and of Seynt Benet
Be cause he held it som dele streyte
This ilk Monke lete old thingis pase
And held aftir the new world the spase
He gaff nat of the tixt a pullid henne
That seith þat hunters been nat holy men
Ne that a Monke when he is rechelese
Is likened to a Fissh when it is watirlese
That is to sey a Monke oute of his cloystour
But that tixt he held nat worth an oystyr
And seyd that his opynyioune was good
What shuld he stody and make hym wood
Oppon a book in cloystour alwey to pour
Or swynk with hondis or do eny labour
As Austyn did but let the world be servid
Let Austyn have his swynk to hym reservid
Therfor he was a prikasour A riȝte
Greyhoundis he had as white as eny mylk
Of prikyng ⁊and of huntyng for the hare
Was al his lust for no thing wold he spare
I saw his sclevis purfelid atte hond
With gryce and that the fynest of the londe
And for to fasten his hood vndir his chyn
He had of gold wrouȝt a corious pynne
Above the knot the grettir end was
His heed was ballid and shoon as glas
And eke his fase as he had been a noynt
He was a lord fat and in good poynt
His stepen eyen rollyng on his hede
That stemyd as a furneys doith of lede
His botis soupill his hors in grete estate
Now certenly he was a feir prelate
He was nat pale as a forpynyd goost
A fat Swanne lovid he best of eny rost
His Palfrey was as browne as bery
A Frere ther was a wanton ⁊and a mery
A lymytour a ful solempne man
In al the iiij ordirs is noon so wele can
So much of dalyaunce ⁊and off feir langage
He had I made many a feir mariage
Of yong vommen at his own cost
Vn to his ordir he was a nobill post
Ful wele belovid and famuler was he
With Frankleyns ovir al the contre
And with worthy yemen of the town
For he had power of confessioune
And plesaunce was his Absolucioun
And seyd hym selff more then a curate
And of his ordur he was lycenciate
Of al felicite he was riȝte perfite
That held oppynyoune that pleyn delite
An housholder and that agrete was hee
An esy man to gyve penaunce
There as he wist to gyve have good petaunce
On to a pore ordur for to gyve
What that a man is wele I shryve
Yff he gaff he durst make a vaunte
Yff that a man were repentaunte
a man so hard was of hert
wepe þouȝe he sore smert
There fore in steed in wepeing and preyers
Men must gyve sylvir to the pore freris
His typpet stuffid was ful off knyvis
And with pynnys to gyve feir wyvis
And certeyn he had a mery note
Merely coude he syng and pley atte Root
Of tydingis he bare vttirly the pryse
Mylk white he was as the flour delyse
Ther to he was strong as a Champioune
He knewe the taverns wele in every town
And every hostelere and tapstere
Bettir then a lazer or a begstere
For as to such man as was hee
Accordith nat as by his faculte
To have of such lazers aqueyntaunce
It is nat honest it may nat avaunce .
For to dele with such poraill
But wᵗith riche and sellers of vitaill
And evir wher that riches shuld arise
Curteys he was and lewly of servise
Ther was no man ow wher so vertuous
He was the beggest Begger Frere in his house
For they a wydow had but a shoo
So plesaunt was he with Inprincipio
Ȝit wold he have a ferthing or he went
His purchas was bettir þen his rent
And berk he cowde as it weer a welp
In love dayis ther coude he much help
For there he nat like a Cloysterere
With a threde bare cope as a pore Frere
But he was like a mastir or a Pope
Of dobill worstede was his semy cope
That rounde was as abell out of price
Som what he lipsid for his wantonyce
To make his Englissh swete on his tunge
And his harping when he had sunge
His eyen twynkelid in his hede a riȝte
As doon the Sterris in the Frosty nyȝte
This worthy lymytoure was callid hubbert
A Marchant there was with a forkid berde
In motley on hiȝe on hors he sat
Oppon his hede a Flaundris bevir hatt
His botis clapsid feir and fetously
His resons he spak al solempnly
Shewing alwey the encrese of his wynnyng
He wold the see were kept for eny thyng
Betwixe Midilburh and orewell
Wele coude he in his eschaungis by ⁊and sell
This worthy man his wit was wel be sett
Ther wist no white what he was in dett
So estately was he of governaunce
With his bergeyns and with his chefesaunce
For soth he was a worthy man with all
But soth to sey I note how men hym call
A Clerk ther was of Oxinforth also
That on to logik had long I go
As leen was his hors as a rake
And he was nat riȝte fat I vndirtake
But lokid holowe and ther to sobirly
Ful thredebare was his ovir court by
For he had goten hym no benefice
Ne noon othir maner of office
For hym were levir to have at his beddis hede
Twenty bokis clad in white and rede
Of Aristotill and of Philosophy othir /
And ȝit had he but litill gold in /cofir
On bookis and on lernyng he it spent
For that was all his besy entent
And al wey for the sowlis to prey
That gaff hym wher with to his scole ay
Of study toke he most cure and hede
Nat o word spak he more then nede
Both short ⁊and quyk and of good centence
Sownyng to moral vertu was his prudence
And gladly wold he lern and gladly teche
And therto ful sofft was hi in his speche
A Seriaunte of lawe þer was both ware ⁊and wise
That offten had been atte parvise
And he was riche of excellence
Discrete he was and of grete reverence
Hit semed so hys wordis were so wise
Iustice he was ful offt at eny syse
By patent and by pleyn commyssioune
For his science and his hiȝe renown
Of Feeis and robis had he many oon
So grete a purchasour was ther nowher noon
All was fee sympyll to hym in effect
His purchace myȝt nat be to hym in suspect
No where so leff a man as he ther was
And ȝit he made hym besier then he was
In termys he had the case and domys all
That from the term of king William were fall
Ther to he cowde endite and make a thinge
Ther cowd no white pynch at his writynge
And every statute cowde he pleyn be rote
He rood but hoomly in a medley cote
I gird with a synke and barrys smale
Of his aray tell I no lengir tale
A Frankelen there was in his compane
White was his berde as the deyse
And of his complexioune he was sangweyn
Wele lovid he by the morow a cupp of wyne
To lyve in delite was evir his wonne
For he was epiours own sonne
That held oppynyoun that pleyn delite
Was verry Felicite parfite
An housholder and that agrete was he
Seynt Iulian he was clepid in his contre
His brede his ale was evir aftir oon
A bettir wynyd man was ther no wher noon
Wᵗith out bakemete was he nevir in his house
His Fissh his Flessh and that so plentevouse
It shewid in his house of mete and drynke
Of al deyntees that men coude thynke
Aftir the sondry seson of the yeer
So chaungit he his mete and his sopere
Ful many a fat Partrik had he in mewe
And may a breem and luce in his stewe
Woo was the Cook but his sause were
Poynant and sharp and redy al his geer
His tabill dormaunte in his hall alwey
Stood redy coverid al the long day
At Sessiouns ther was he lorde and syre
Ful offt tyme he was knyȝt of the Shier
A lase and a gipsere had he of silk
Hanging at his girdill white as morow mylk
A Shryve had he been and Acoronoure
In al that contre was such a vavesoure
An habirdassher and a Carpentere
A webb a dyer and a Tapysere
And they were clothid al in oon lyvereye
Of a grete solempne Fraternite
Ful fressh and new hir geer pikid was
Hir knyvis I chapid nat with bras
But with sylvir wrouȝt ful cleen ⁊and weel
Hir girdilis and hir powchis everydele
Wele semed eche of hem a feir Burgeys
To sytten in the ȝeld hall on the deys
Everich for the wisdom that he can
Was haply to be an Aldirman
For catell had they I nawȝe and rent
And hir wyvis wold it wele assent
And els certen they weer to blame
It is ful feir to be clepid madame
And go to vigill al to fore
And have a mantell rially I bore
A kook they had wᵗith hem for the nonys
To boyll the Chekons with þe b marybonys
And powdir marchaunt tart and galyngale
Wele cowde he know a drauȝt of good ale
He cowd rost and seeth boyll and fry
Make mortrews and wele bake a pye
And blanke manger made he with the best
A Shipman ther was þat woned fer be weste
For Auȝte I woot he was of dertemowith
He rood oppon arounsy as wel as he cowith
And in a gown of folding to the kne
A dagger and a lase hanging had he
A bowt his nek vndir his arme a down
The hoot somyr had made his hew al brown
And certenly he was agood felawe
Ful many a drawȝt of wyne had he I sclawe
From Burdeux ward whils the Chapman eke
Of no presciens toke ther of noon heed
At ful many a batell in that londe
He fauȝt and had the hiȝer honde
But of his crafft to reken wel the tyde
His stremys his daungers hym besyde
Ther nas soch noon from hul to cartage
And wise he was þouȝe he were ful of corage
Hardy he was and ware to vndirtake
With many atempest his berd hath ke
He knew al the havyns as they were
From Englonde on to Caphefenestere
And every creke in breten and in Speyn
His barge was callid the Magdeleyn
Uith vs ther was a doctour of Phisik
In al the world was noon hym lyke
To speke of Phesik and of Surgery
For he was groundit in Astronomy
He kept his paciens a ful grete dele
In houre by magik naturell
Wele cowd he of Fortune the accident
Of his ymage for his pacient
He knewe the case of every malady
Weer it of cold moyst or dry
And weer engendrit of what humour
He was a verry parfite practesoure
The cause he knewe And of his harm the rote
Anoon he gaff the Seekman his boot
For redy were al his Appoticaries
To send hym his dreggis and his letewaries
For eche of othir made hem for to wynne
Hir frendshippis were nat new to be gynne
Ful wele knew he the old estapulis
And discord and eke Ruphus
Olde Ipocras haly and eke galiene
Serupion Crase and eke avisene
Amorois Damastione and Constantyne
Bernard Gatisden and Gylbertyne
Of his Diete mesurabill was hee
For it was of noon superfluyte
But of grete norisshing degestibill
His study was but litill on the bibill
In sangwen and in a perce clad with all
I lynyd with taffate and wᵗith syndall
And he ne was but esy of dispence
He kept that he wanne in pestelence
For gold in Phisik is acordiall
Wherfor he lovid gold in speciall
A good wyff ther was of þe town of Bāthe
And she was som dele deff ⁊and þat was scathe
Of cloth makyng had she such an haunte
She passid hem of Ipris and of Gaunte
In al the parissh wyff was ther noon
That to the offryng to fore hir shuld goon
And yff they did then wroth was she
Then was she oute of al charite
Hir kerchers ful fyne weer of ground
I durst swere þey weyid down a pound
That on a Sonday were on hir hede
Hir hosyn were of Fyne scarlet rede
Ful streyte I teyd and shois ful newe
Bold was hir fase and feir and rede of hewe
She was a worthy vomman al hir lyff
Husbondis atte chirch dorr had she fiff
With out othir company in yowith
But ther of nedith nat to speke at nowȝe
At Is had she been and at Ierusaleme
She had passid many a straunge streme
At Room had she been and at Babyloon
In Galys at Seynt Iamys and at Coleyn
She coude much of wandryng in the wey
Gap tothid was she sothly for to sey
Oppon an ambeler ful esely she satt
I wymplid wele and on hir hede an hatt
As brode as it were a bokelere or a targe
A foot mantell a bouȝt hir hippis large
And on hir helis a peir of sporis sharp
In feleshipp cowde she lawȝe and carpe
Of remedies of love she cowd ꝑparchaunce
For of that arte she cowd al the Daunce
A good man ther was of religioune
And was a person of a town
But riche he was and holy of werk
He was also a lernyd man a clerk
That cristis gospellis trewly wold he prech
His parisshons devoutly wold he teche
Benyng he was and wondir dilygent
Aryȝt wis man and a pacient
And such he was provid offt sithis
Ful loth he was to curs for his tithis
But rathir wold he gyve hem a bowt
To his pore parisshons there as he ouȝt
Of his offryng and of his sustenaunce
He cowde in litill thing have suffisaunce
Wyde was his parissh ⁊and howsis ferr a sondir
But he let nat for reyn ne for thundir
In clennes more and in foule to visite
The ferthest in his parissh more and lite
Oppon his feet and in his hond a staff
This nobill ensaumpill to his shepe he gaff
That first he wrouȝt and aftir þat he tauȝt
Out of the gospell these wordis he cauȝte
And this figure he ekid ther to
That yf gold rust what shuld Iren do
For yf a preste be foule in whom wee trust
No wondir yff a lewd man rust
And shame it is yf a preest take kepe
A shyten shepard and a cleen shepe
Wele ouȝte a prest ensaumpill forto gyve
By hys clennes how his shepe shuld lyve
Be set nat his benyfice to hier
And let his Shepe acombryn in the myir
And ren to london to Seynt Poulis
To gete hym a Chauntre to syng for sowlis
Othir with a brethirhed to be hold
But dwelling at home to kepe his folde
So that the wolff ne do nat mys cary
He was a Sheppard and nat a mercenary
And they be holy weer and vertuouse
He was nat to synful men to dispetouse
But in his Shepe discrete and benynge
Ne of his spech daungerous ne digne
To draw folk to heven with feirnes
By good ensaumpill that was his besynes
But yf it were eny persone obstinate
What so he were of hyȝe or low estate
Hym wold he snybben for the nonys
A bettir preest I trow no where is
He waytid aftir noon pompe ne reverence
Ne he made no spisid conscience
But Cristis lore and his postelys twelve
He tauȝte hem first And folowed hem hym selve
With hym ther was a plouȝman his brothir
That had I ledd of dung many a fothir
A trewe swynker and a good was he
Lyving in pees and ꝑparfite charite
God lovid he best with al his hert
At al tymes wheþir he gamyd or smert
And then his neybour riȝt as hym selve
He wold throssh and therto digg ⁊and delve
For Cristis sake for every pore white
With oute hier yf it ly in his myȝte
His tythis payde both feir and wele
Both of his propir swynk and catell
In a Tabert he rood oppon a meer
There was also a reve and a myllere
A Sompnoure and a pardonere also
A mancipill and my selff and no mo
The Miller was a stout carll for the nonys
Fu bigg he was of brawn ⁊and of bonys
That previd wele wher that evir he cam
Atte wrestlyng he wold al wey have þe ram
He was short shuldryt a thyk gnarr
There nas no dorr that he wold heve of barr
Or breke it at rennyng with his hede
His berd as ony sowe or wexe was rede
And therto brode as it were a spade
Oppon the Copp of his nose he hade
A werte and ther on stood a tufft of herys
Reed as the brustelis of a Sowis eris
His nosetrillis blak were and wyde
A swerd and a bokelere bare he by his syde
His mowith as grete as a furneyse
He was a Iangelere a Ioly hardoyse
And that was most of synne and harlotries
Wele cowde he stele corn and toll thries
And that he had a thombe of gold parde
A white cote and a blew werid he
A bag pipe cowde he blow wele and sown
And there with al he brouȝt vs out of town
A gentill mancipill ther was of a Tempill
Of wich eủery catour myȝt take ensaumpill
For to be wyse in bying of vitaile
For whethir he payde or toke be tayle
Algate he weytid so on his cate
That he was ay beforn and in good estate
Now is nat that / of God a feir grace
That such a lewd mannys wit shal pase
The wisdom of the hepe of wise men
Of mastris wich he had mo then thries ten
That were of lawe expert and coriouse
Of wich there were a dosyn in his house
Worthy to be steward of rent and londe
Of eny lorde that is in Englonde
To make hym lyve by his own good
In honour detles but yf that he were wood
Othir lyve as sharply as he wold desire
And forto helpen al a shijre
In eny cause that myȝt fall or happ
And ȝit this mancipill set al hir capp
The Reve was a colerik man
His berde was shave as nere as he can
His heer was by his eer rownd I shoor
His topp was dokkit lyke a prest to fore
Ful long weer his leggis ⁊and ful leen
And like a staff ther nas no calff I seen
Wele cowd he kepe a garner and a byn
Ther was noon auditour cowd of hym wyn
Wele wist he by the drouȝt and by the reyn
The ȝelding of his seed and of his greyn
His lordis sheep his nete and his deyre
His swyne his hors and his pultre
Was holy in this Revis governynge
And by covenaunte gaff the rekenyng
Sithen his lorde was xx yeer of age
Ther was no man coude bryng hym in rerage
Ther nas bayly ne herd / ne noon othir hyne
That he ne coude his scleyȝt ⁊and his covyne
They were of hym adred as the deth
His wonnyng was feir oppon an heth
With green treis shadit was his plase
He cowd bettir then his lorde purchase
Ful riche he was astoryd pryvely
His lorde he coude plese discretely
To gyve hym ageyn of his own good
And have thanke and ȝit a Cote ⁊and an hode
In yowith he had lerned a good mystere
He was a well good wriȝt ⁊and a Carpentere
This Reve sat oppon a wel good stott
That was al popill grey and hiȝt Scott
A long Surcote of peers oppon he had
And by his syde he bare a rusty blade
Of Norfolk was this Reve of wich I tell
Be side a town men callit Baldiswell
Tukkid he was like a Frere a bowte
And evir he rood the hyndrest of the rowte
A Sompnour was ther wᵗith vs in the plase
That had a feir rede cherebyn fase
And sausflem he was wᵗith eyen narowe
Hote he was and likorous as a Sparowe
With blak browis scallid ⁊and pillyd berde
Of his visage children were sore aferd
Ther nas quyk sylvir letarge ne brymstoon
Borace ceruce ne oyle of tartir noon
Ne oynement that both cheke and bite
That myȝt help of his welkis white
Ne of his knobbis sittyng on his chekis
Wele lovid he garlik oynons ⁊and lekis
And for to drynk rede wyne as the blood
Then wold he speke and cry as he were wood
And when he had wele dronk of the wyne
That wold he speke no word but latyne
A few termys he had too or thre
That he had lernyd out of som degre
No wondir is who herd hym al the day
And eke yee know wele that a Iay
Can clepe wat as wele as the pope
But who coude hym in othir thingis grope
Then hed he spent all his philosophy
A questio quid queris wold he cry
He was a gentill harlot and a kynde
A bettir felaw shuld no man fynde
He wold suffir for a quart of wyne
A good felaw to have his concubyne
A twelmonth and excuse hym at the full
Ful pryvely a fynche coude he pull
And yf he fond owher a good felawe
He wold make hym a noon to have awe
In such cause of the Archedekyns curs
But yf mannys soule were in his purs
For in his purs he shuld I pynchid be
Purs is the Erchedekyns hell seyd he
But wele I woot he lyed in dede
For of cursyng ouȝt eche man to drede
For cursyng woll sclee ryȝt as soylyng savith
And also ware hym of a significauit
In daunger had he at his own guyse
The yong gerlis of the diocyse
And knew of hir counsell and was of hir rede
A Garlond he had set on his hede
As grete as it were an ale stake
A bokeler had he made hym of a cake
Uith hym ther was a gentill pardoner
Of Rouncyvale his Frend ⁊and his comper
That streyte was com from the pope of Room
Ful lowde he song com hidir leve grome
This Sompnour bare to hym a styff Burdon
Was nevir Trompe of half so grete a sown
This pardoner had here as ȝelow as glas
But smoth it hong as doith a streke of Flexe
By owncys hyng his lokkis that he had
And ther with his shuldris ovir spred
But then it lay by couplis oon ⁊and oon
An hood for Iolyte werid he noon
For it was trussid oppon his valet
Hym þouȝt he rode al on the new get
All newe shave wᵗith out capp rode al bare
Such glaryng eyen had he as hath an hare
His valet to fore hym in his lapp
A vernakill had he sowid on his capp
Bret ful of pardon com from Room al hote
A voyse he had as smal as hath agoot
No berd had he ne nevir shuld have
Evir as much as it were newe shave
I trow he had a gelding or a mare
But of his crafft to Berewik on to ware
Was ther nevir such a pardonere
For in his male he had a pylow bere
Wich that he seyd was our ladies veyle
He seyd he had a gobet of the Seyll
That Seinyt Petir had when that he went
Oppon the See till Ihıı̄uns Criste hym hent
He had a loton Crosse ful of stonys
And in a glas he had piggis bonys
But with these Relikis when that he fonde
A pore person dwellyng oppon londe
Oppon a day he gate hym more mony
Than the person gate in monthis twey
And thus he feyned with flateryng ⁊and Iapis
He made the person ⁊and the pepill his Apis
But trewly to tell at the last
He was in chirch a nobill ecclesiast
Wele cowd he rede a lesson or a story
Ful wele he wist when that song was sung
He must preche and file a while his tung
To wyn sylvir as wele as he cowith
Therfor he song the merier and lowith
Now hav I told ȝew shortly in a clause
The state the Aray the nombir ⁊and þe cause
Why that assemblit was this company
In Southwirk atte gentil hostery
That hiȝt the Tabert fast by the bell
But now is tyme to ȝew for to tell
How that wee bere vs in that ilk nyȝt
When that wee were in the hostry alyȝt
And aftir woll I tell of our viage
And al the remnaunte of our pilgremage
But first I prey ȝew of yeur curtesy
That yee ne reken nat me vylany
They that I speke pleynly in this matere
To tell ȝewe hir wordis and hir chere
And they I speke hir wordis propirly
For this yee know as wele as I
Who shall tell a tale aftir a man
He must reherce as nere as he can
Every word yf it be in his charge
Al speke he nevir so rude ⁊and so large
Or els he must tell his tale vntrew
Or sey thingis or fynde wordis fe new
He may nat spare al they he were his brothir
He must as wele sey o word as a nothir
Criste spak hym selff ful brode in holy writt
And wele yee woot no vilany is it
Eke Plato seith who can it rede
The wordis be chosen to the dede
Also I prey ȝew for gyve it me
Al they I set nat folk in hir degre
Her in these talis as they shuld stond
My witt is short yee may wele vndirstond
Grete cheer made our hoost to vs everychoon
And to the soper set he vs anoon
He servid vs with vitaill of the best
Strong was the wyne ⁊and wele drynk vs lyst
A semely man was our hoost with all
For to be a Marchall in an hall
A large man he was with eyen stepe
A Feir burgeys ther was no such in chepe
Bold was his spech and he was wele I tauȝt
And of manhode lakkid he riȝt nauȝt
And eke ther to he was a mery man
And aftir soper to pley he be gan
And spak of myrth a mong othir thingis
When that wee had made our rekenyngis
And seyd this now lordis trewly
Yee be to me ryȝt wel com hertly
For be my trowith yf that I shall nat ly
I saw nat this yeer so mery a company
At onys in this herburh as is newe
Feyn wold I do ȝew myrth yf I wost how
And of my myrth I am riȝt now be thouȝt
To do yewe ese and it shall cost ȝew nauȝte
Yee goon to Cauntirbury god ȝew spede
The blesful martir quyt ȝew yeur mede
And wele yee woot as yee go by the wey
Yee shapyn ȝewe to lawȝe and to pley
For treuly comfort ne myrth is ther noon
To ryde by the wey Domb as a Stone
And therfor woll I make ȝewe disporte
As I seyd erst and do ȝewe comfort
And yff it like ȝew al by oon assent
For to stonde at my Iugement
And to werken as I shall ȝew sey
To morow when yee ride by the wey
Now by my Fadir soule that is deed
But yee be mery I shal gyve ȝew myn hede
Hold vp yeur hondis with out more spech
Our counsell shall nat long be to seche
Vs thouȝt it was worth to make vs nyce
And bad hym sey his verdite ⁊and his devise
Now lordyngis quod he herkenyth for the best
And bad hym sey on what hym list
But I prey ȝew take it nat in disdeyn
This is the poynt to speke it short ⁊and pleyn
That eche of ȝewe to short with yeur wey
Shall in this viage tell talys twey
To Cauntirbury ward I meen it so
And homward he shall tell othir talis too
Of aventuris that whilom have be fall
And wich of ȝew bereth hym best of all
That is to sey that tellith in this case
Talis of best sentence ⁊and most solase
Shall have a soper of our alther cost
Here in this plase sittyng by thy post
When that wee com a geyn fro Cauntirbury
And for to make ȝewe the more mery
I woll my selff go with ȝew and ryde
At myne own cost and be yeur guyde
And who that woll this Iugement wᵗith sey
Shall pay for all the costis by the wey
And yf yee vouch saff that it be soo
Tell me a noon with out wordis mo
And I wol hertly shape me therfore
This thing was grauntid and othis swore
With ful glad hert and preyen hem also
That he wold vouch saff so for to do
And that he wold be our governour
And of our talys Iugg and reportour
And set a soper atta certen prise
And woll be rewlid at his devise
Hyȝe and lowe and al by oon assent
Wee be accordit to the Iugement
And ther oppon the wyne was fet a noon
Wee dronken and to rest went echoon
With out eny lengir taryinge
A morow when the day gan sprynge
Op rose our hoost and was al our kok
And gadrid vs all in a flokk
And forth wee rydyn a litill more pase
Vn to the wateryng of Seynt Thomase
And there our hoost gan his hors a rest
And seyd herkenyth lordis yf ȝew lest
Yee woot our forward and I woll accord
Yff the even song ⁊and the morow song accord
Let see now who shall tel the first tale
As evir mot he drynk wyne or ale
Who so woll be rebell to my Iugement
Shal pay for al the A le that by þe wey is spent
Now draw cut or that we ferther twyn
Wich of vs shall first the tale be gynne
Sir knyȝte quod he my mastir ⁊and my lorde
Drawith cut for that is myne accord
Comyth hidir quod he my lady Priores
And yee sir clerk let be yeur shamefastnes
Ne stodijth nat ley hond every man
Anoon to with draw every white be ganne
And shortly to tell as it was
Weer it by Aventure sort or case
The soth is this the cut fill on the knyȝt
Of wich ful bliith and glad was every white
And tell he must his tale as it was reson
By forward and by composicioune
As yee have herd what nedith wordis mo
And when this good man saw that it was so
As he that was wyse and obedient
To kepe his forward and by his fre assent
He seyd sithins I shal be gynne the game
What wel com be cut on goddis name
Now let vs ryde and herkenyth what I sey
And with that word we rydyn forth our wey
And so be gan with a riȝt mery chere
And seyd a noon his tale as yee shul heer
Here begynnyth the knyȝhte his tale
Whilom there was as old story tellith vs
A Duke somtyme callid Theseus
Of thebes he was lorde ⁊and governoure
And in his tyme a worthy conquerour
That gretter there noon vndir the sonne
Ful many a rich contre had he wonne
That with his wisdom and his chyvalry
He conquerd al the regn of Femyny
That whilom was clepid Sithea
And weddit the Quene callid Ipolita
And brouȝht hir home in his contre
With much Ioy and solempnite
And eke hir yong Sustir Emely
And thus with victory and melody
Lete I this worthy Duke to Athenes ride
And al his hoost in Armys hym beside
And certis yf it nere to long to here
I have shuld told ȝew al the matere
How I wonne was the regn͗e of Femeny
By Theseus and by his Chyvalry
And of the grete batel for the nonys
Betwix Athenes and Amazsones
And how besegit was Ipolyta
The feir hardy Quene of Cithea
And off the Feest that was at hir Weddyng
And off the tempest at hire home comyng
But al this thing I must as now forbere
I hav god woot a long feld to ere
And weyk be the oxen of the plowȝe
The remnaunt of my tale is long I nowȝe
I woll nat let eke noon of this rowte
Let every felaw tel his tale a bowte
And let see now who shall the souper wyn
And ther I lefft I woll ageyn be gynne
This Duke of whom I make mencioun
When he was com almost into the town̄
He was avare as he kyst his eye a syde
In all his wole and al his most pryde
Where that knelid in the hiȝe wey
A company of ladies twey ⁊and twey
Ech aftir othir clothid in blakk
But such a cry and woo they make
That in this world ni creature lyving
That herd such a nothir weymentyng
And on this cry wold they nevir stent
Tyll they the reynys of his brydill hent
What folk be yee at my home comyng
Perturb me my Feest thus with crying
Quod Theseus have yee so grete envy
Of myne honour / that thus compleyn ⁊and cry
Or who hath ȝewe mys bodyn or offendit
And tellith me yff it may be amendit
And why yee be thus clothid In blak
The eldest of hem all then spakk
When she had swowned with a dedly cher͗e
That it was rewith to seen and to here
She seyd / lord to whom fortune hath gyve
Victory and as a conquerour for to lyve
Nauȝt grevith vs your glory ⁊and your͗e honour͗e
But wee besech ȝewe of mercy ⁊and socoure
Have mercy on our / woo and distres
Som drop of pete þurh yeur gentilnes
Oppon vs wrecchid vommen let it fall
For certis lord ther is noon of vs all
That she ne hath bene a Duches or a Quene
Now be we caytyfs as it is wele seen
I thankid be fortune and hir fals whele
That noon estatt assurith to be wele
Now certis lorde to abide in yeur / presence
Her͗e in this tempilt of Goddis clemies
Wee have been weyting al this Fourtenyȝt
Now help vs lord sith it is in thy myȝt
I wrecchid whiȝt þat wepe thus
Was whilom of Campanous
That starff at Thebes accursid be the day
And all wee that been in this aray
And make al this lamentacioune
We losten al our husbondis in that town̄
Whils the sege ther abowt lay
And ȝit nowe the old Creon welawey
That lord is of Thebes the Cete
Fulfillid of al Ire and iniquite
He fer dispite of Tyranny
To do the dede bodies vylany
Of al our͗e lordis / with that been sclawe
Hath al the bodies on an hepe I throw
And woll nat suffer hem by noon assent
Nethir to be buried ne to be brent
But makith houndis ete hem in dispite
And with that woord without more respite
The fill grobelyng crying spetously
Have on vs wrecchid vommen som mercy
And let our sorow synk in thyne hert
This gentill Duke down of his coursour stert
With hert petouse when he herd hem speke
Hym þouȝt his hert wold to breke
When he sawe hem so petouse ⁊and so make
That whilom where of so grete estate
And in his armys he hem al vp hent
And hem comfortid in ful good entent
He wold do so ferforth his myȝte
Oppon Creon the teraunt hem to wreke
That al the pepill of Greke therof shuld speke
Howe Creon was of Theseus servid
As he hath his deth wele disservid
And riȝte a noon with out more a bood
His baner he displayd ⁊and forth he rood
To Thebes ward and al his hoost be syde
Ne nere Attenes wold he go ne ride
Ne take his ese fully halff a day
But on his wey that nyȝt he lay
And sent a noon Ipolita the Quene
And Emely hir yong Sustir Sheen
Oon to the town of Attenes to dwell
div.note: lipa Regina uely hir sustꝰus
div.l: And forth he ridith ther͗e is no more to tell
He rode Statu of marce wᵗith spere ⁊and targe
So shyneth in his white baner large
That al the feldis gliteren vp ⁊and down
And by his baner born is his penoun
Of gold ful rich ther͗e in was bete
The methau with he wan in Crete
This worthy Duke this conquerour
And in his hoost of Chyvalry the flour
Tyl that he com to Thebes and a liȝte
Feir in a feld ther͗e as he þouȝt to fiȝte
But shortly to speke of this thing
With Creon wich was of thebes þe kyng
He fauȝt ⁊and sclouȝe hym manly as a knȝt
In pleyn batell ⁊and put his folk to fliȝt
And with a sawt he wan the Cete aftir
And rent a down both wal speer ⁊and raftir
And to the ladies he restoryd a geyn
The bonys of hir frendis þat were scleyn̄
To do observauncis as tho was the guyse
But it were al to long to devise
The grete clamour and the weymentyng
That the ladies made atte berying
Of the bodies and the grete honoure
That Theseus the nobill conquerour
Doith to the ladies when they from hym went
But shortly for to tell myne entent
When that this worthy duke Theseus
Hath Creon scleyn and wan Thebes thus
Still in the feld he toke al nyȝt his rest
And did with al the contre as hym list
He ransakid the taas of the bodies dede
Hem for to stripe of hir harnes ⁊and weed
The pillours did hir besynes ⁊and cure
Aftir the batell and the discomfetur͗e
And so it fill that in that taas þey fond
Thurh girt with many a grevouse blody wounde
To yong knyȝtis lying by and by
Both in armys wrouȝt ful richely
div.note: ¶ Decite Palamon
div.l: Of wich too Arcite hit the toon
And the todir hiȝt Palamon
Nat allyng fully dede they were
But by hir͗e Cote armurs and hir geer
The herodis knew hem best in speciall
As they that weer of the blood riall
Of Theseus and of Sustirs too I born
Out of the taas the Pillours hath hem torn
And hath hem caried sofft on to the tent
Of Theseus and he ful soon hem sent
To Attenes to dwell ther͗e in prisoıı̄un
Perpetuel he wold no raunsom
And when this worthy duke had thus I doon
He took his hoost and home he goith anoon
With laurer crowned as a conquerour
And ther͗e he lyvith in Ioy and in honour
Turn of his lyff what nedith wordis mo
And in a tour with angwissh ⁊and wᵗith woo
Dwellid Palamon and eke Arcite
For evir more ther͗e may no gold hem quyte
Thus passith yeer by yeer and day be day
Tyl it fill onys in a morow grey
That Emely that feir was to seen
Then is the lyly oppon the stalk green
And fressher then may wᵗith flowris newe
For with the rose colour strofe hir hewe
I noot wich was the feyrer of hem too
Or it was day sche was wont to do
She was arysen and al redy diȝte
For may wol have no scloggart a nyȝte
The seson prikith every gentill hert
And makith hem out of hir sclepe stert
I clothid Fressh was she to devise
To do honour to may and for to ryse
Hir ȝelow here was broydit on a tres
By hynde hir bak a long ȝerd I ges
And in the garden when the sone vp rist
She walkith vp ⁊and down as hir list
And gadrith flouris white ⁊and rede
To make a subtil chapelet to hir hede
And as an Aungel hevenly she songe
The grete Toure that was so thik ⁊and stronge
Wich of the castel was the cheff Dungion
Ther as these knyȝtis weren in Prisone
Of wich I told ȝewe and tell shall
Was even Ioynyng to the castell wall
Ther͗e as this Emely had hir pleying
Briȝte was the sonne and clere in the mornyng
And Palamon this woful prisonere
As was his wonne by leve of his gaylere
Was rysen and romed on a chambir on hiȝe
In wich he all the nobill Cete sy
And eke the garden ful of braunchis grene
There as this fressh Emely the shene
Was in hir walk and romyd vp ⁊and down
This sorowful prysoner this Palamon
Goith on the chambir to and fro
And to hym selff compleyned of his woo
That he was born ful offt he seyd allas
And so it fill by aventure and caas
That þurh a wyndow thik of many a barr͗e
Of iren grete and square as eny spare
He kyst his eye oppon Emelya
And ther͗e with he blent and cried . A
As they he avere stongen to the hert
And with that cry Arcite vp stert
And seyd cosyn myne what eylith the
That art so pale ⁊and deedly on to see
Why cryist þow who hath doon the offence
For Goddis love take al in pacience
Our prison for it may noon othir be
Fortune hath gyven vs this aduersite
Or els som wiccid aspect or disposicioune
Of Saturn by som constillacioune
Hath gyven vs al they wee had sworn
So stood heven when that wee were born
Wee must endure it is short ͗e pleyn
This Palamon answerd ͗e seyd ageyn̄
Cosyn for soth of this oppynyoun
Thow hast a veyn Imagenacioune
This pryson causith me nat to cry
But I was hurt riȝt now þurh myne eye
Vn to my hert that woll my bane be
The feirnes of a lady that I se
Ȝondir in the garden romeyng to ⁊and fro
Is the cause of my crying and woo
I note whethir she be a vomman or Goddes
But Venus it is sothly as I ges
And ther͗e with al on kneis down̄ he fill
And seyd Venus yf it be thy will
Ȝew in this garden thus to transfigur
To fore me sorowful wrecchid creatur
Out of this prisoin help that wee scape
And yf so be my destene be shape
By etern world to dy in prison
Of our͗e lynage have som compassioun
That is so low brouȝt to Tyranny
And with that worde Arcite gan̄ to spy
Where as the lady went to and fro
And with that siȝte hir bewte hurt hym so
That yf Palamon were woundit sore
Arcite is hurt as much as he or more
And with a siȝe he siȝid petously
The Fressh bewte shall sclee me sodenly
Of hir that romyth in the ȝondir place
And but I have hir͗e mercy and hir͗e grace
That I may hir͗e see atte lest wey
I am but dede ther is no more to sey
This Palamon when he these wordis herd
Dispetously he lokid and answerd
Whethir seist þow this in ernest or in pley
Nay quod Arcite be my fey
God help me so me list ful evil to pley
This Palamon gan knyt his browis twey
It were to the quod he no grete honour
For to be fals and to be atreytour
To me that am thy cosyn and thy brothir
I sworn ful depe and ech of vs to othir
That nevir for to dy in the peyn
Tyll that the deth depart shuld vs tweyn
Nethir in love to hyndir othir
Ne in noon evill case my leve brothir
But that þow shuldist trewly for ther me
In every caas as I shuld forther the
This was thyn othe ⁊and myne certeyn
I woot wele þow darst it nat with seyn
Thus art thow of my counsell wᵗith out dowt
And now thow woldist falsly be a bowt
To love my lady whom I love and serve
And evir shall tyl my hert sterve
Now certis fals Arcite / þow shalt nat so
I lovid hir͗e first and told the my woo
As to my consell and my brothir sworn
I pose that thow lovidist hir to fore
Wost þow nat wele the old clerkis saw
That who shal gyve a lober eny law
Love is gretter law be my panne
Than may be gyven to eny erthly man
And therfor positiff law and such degre
Is broken al wey for love meth degre
A man must nedis love magre his hede
He may nat flee it thouȝ he shuld be dede
Al be she mayden wydowe or wyffe
And eke it is nat likly by my lyffe
To stond in hir͗e grace no more shal I
For wele þow vetist þy self verely
That thow ⁊and I be dampnyd to prison
Perpetuelly vs gaynyth no raunsom
Ne stryff as did the houndis for the boon
They fauȝt al day and ȝit hir͗e part was noon
Ther͗e can a cur while they were so wroth
And bare a wey the boon be twix hem both
And therfore atte kyingis court my brothir
Ech man for hym selff ther͗e is noon othir
Love yf thow list for I woll love ⁊and shall
And sothly leve brothir this is all
Here in this pryson must wee endure
And every of vs take his aventure
Grete was the stryff ⁊and long be twene hem twey
Yf that I had leyser for to sey
But to the effect it happid on a day
To tel it shortly as I may
A worthy Duke that his Parotheus
That felawe was to duke Theseus
That of þat story me list nat to endite
Duke Parotheus lovid wele Arcite
And had hym know at Thebes yeer by yeer
And fynally atte request and preyer
Of Parotheus wᵗithout eny raunsom
Duke Theseus lete hym out of prison
Frely to go wher͗e hym list ovir all
In such a guyse as I ȝew tel shall
This was the forward to endite
Betwen Duke Theseus ⁊and Arcite
That yf so were that arcite were I founde
Evir in his lyff by nyȝte day or stounde
In eny contre of this Duke theseus
And he were cauȝt it was accord it thus
That wᵗith a swerd he shuld lese his hede
Ther͗e nas noon othir remedy ne rede
He takith his leve ⁊and homward hym sped
Let hym be ware his lyff lyth to wedd
It were a grete thing to tell and to trete
How grete sorow suffrith now Arcet
Now is me shapyn eternally to dwell
Nouȝt in purgatory but in hell
Allas that evir I knew Parotheus
For els had I dwellid with theseus
I fethrid in his prison wᵗith othir mo
Then had I be at ese and nat in woo
Oonly the siȝt of hir͗e whom that I serve
They that I may hir grace nevir deserv
Wold have suffisid riȝt I nowȝ for me
O dere cosyn Palamon quod he
Thyne is the victory of this aventure
Ful blesfull in prison maist þow endure
In prison certis nay but in paradise
Wele hath fortune turned the the dyse
That hast the siȝte of hir͗e in myne absence
For possibil is sith þow hast hir͗e p̉resence
And art a knyȝt worthy and abill
That by som caas sith fortune is chaungabill
Thow maist som tyme to thy desir͗e atteyn
But I that am exilid and bareyne
Of al grace and in so grete dispeir
That ther͗e nys feer watir erth ne heir
Ne creature þat of hem made is
That may me help or confort do I wis
Well ouȝt I sterve in wanhope ⁊and distres
Fare wele my lyff my lust my gladnes
Allas why pleyn men so in comune
Of purveaunce of good or of infortune
That ȝevith hem offt in many wyse
Wel bettir then hem selff can devise
Som men desiren to have riches
That cause is of mordur or of seknes
And som man wold out of his pryson feyn
That in his house of his meyne is sleyn
Infinite harmys been in this matere
Wee woot nat what thing wee prey here
Wee fare as he þat dronken is as a mouse
A dronken man woot wele he hath an house
But he woot nat wich is the ryȝt wey þidir
And to a dronken man the wey is sclydir
And certis in this world so fare wee
Wee sekyn first aftir felicite
But wee go wrong ful offt sikirly
Thus may wee sey al and namele I
That wont to have had a grete oppynyoun
That and I myȝt have scapid out of prison
Then had I be in Ioy and ꝑparfite hele
Ther͗e now I am exilid from myne hele
Sithens I may nat see ȝew Emely
I ne ambut dede ther͗e is no remedy
Oppon that othir syd Palamone
When that he wist that Arcite was goon
Such sorowe he makith that in the grete tour
Resownyd of his yoling and of his clamour
The pure Feteris on his shynys grete
Were of his bittir salt weet
Allas quod he Arcita cosyn myne
Of al our͗e stryff God woot the fruyt is thyn
Thow walkist now in Thebes at thy large
And of my woo thow gyvist litill charge
Thow maist sey thow hast wisdom ⁊and manhede
Assembill al the folk of our kynrede
And make a werr so sharp on this contre
That by som aventure or trete
Thow maist have hir͗e to thy lady ⁊and to thy wyff
For with I must nedis lese my lyff
For as be wey of possibilite
Sithyns thow art at large ⁊and prison fre
And art a lorde grete is thyn avauntage
More then is myne shit here in a cage
For I may wepe ⁊and weyle whils I lyve
Wᵗith al the woo that prison may me gyve
And eke wᵗith peyne that love gyvith also
That dublith al my turnment ⁊and my woo
Ther͗e with the Feer of Ielousy vp stert
Wᵗith in his brest ⁊and toke hym by the hert
So woodly that it was to be hold
The boxe tree or the Asshtre for dede cold
That seyd oe o cruell goddis that art govern
The world with bydding of yeur word etern
And writen on the tabill of the Athemand
Yeur ꝑparlement and yeur etern gandent
What is man kynde more on to ȝew hold
Then is the Shepe that roukith in the fold
For scleyn is man riȝt as anothir best
And dwellith eke in prison ⁊and in arest
And hath sekenes and grete aduersite
And oft tymes giltles parde
What governaill is in this prescience
That giltles turmentith Innocence
And ȝit encresith this al my penaunce
That man is bound to his observaunce
For Goddis sake to lettyn of his will
Ther͗e as a beest may his will fulfill
And when a beest is deed he hath no peyn
They he in this world have care and woo
With out dowt it may stond so
The answere of this I lete to divinis
But wele I woot in this world grett peyn is
Allas I see a serpent or a theffe /
That many a trew man hath do myscheif
Go at his large and wher͗e hym list may torn
But I must be in prison þurh Satourn
And þurh hym I Aloon and eke wood
That hath distroid nyȝe al the blood
Of Thebes with his waast wallis wyde
And Venus scleeth me on the todir syde
For Ielouse and feer of hym Arcite
No we woll I stynt of Palamon Alite
And let hym in his prison still dwellyn
And of Arcite forth woll I tellyn
The somer passith the nyȝtis Wexen long
Encresith he dobill wyse his peynys strong
Both of the lover and the prysoner
I woot he hath the wofuller myster
For shortly to sey of this Palamon
Perpetuelly is dampnyd to prison
In cheynys and in Fetheris to be dede
And Arcite is exilid by his hede
For evir more out of that contre
Yee lovers axe I now this questioune
Who hath the wers of Arcite or Palamone
The toon may se his lady day be day
But in prison must he dwell al way
The todir wher͗e hym list may ride ⁊and go
But se his lady shal he nevir mo
Now demeth as yee list yee that can
For I woll tel forth as I be gan
When that Arcite to Thebes com was
Ful offt a day he swelt and seyd allas
For sith his lady shal he nevir see mo
And shortly to conclude al his woo
So much sorow ne hath creature
That is or shall whils the world may endure
His mete his drynk his sclepe is hym be rafft
That leen he wex and dry as a staff
Hys eyen holow ⁊and grysly to be hold
His hew falow and pale as asshen cold
And solotory he was and evir aloon
And wayling as he myȝt evir makeing his moon
And yf he herd song or instrument
Then wold he wepe þat men myȝt hym nat stynt
So febill were his spiritis ⁊and he lowe
And chaungit so that no man coude hym knowe
His speche ne his voise þeyȝ men it herd
And in his gir͗e for al the world he ferd
Nauȝt like to the lovers malady
Of hirs but rathir like to many
Engendrid of humours malyncoly
Be forn his fatell fantesy
And shortly turnyd was al vp so down
Bothe in habite ⁊and in his disposicioune
Of hym þis wofull lover dan Arcite
What shall I of his woo al day endite
When he enduryd hath a yer͗e or too
This cruel turment peyn and woo
As Thebes in his contre as I seyd
Oppon a nyȝt a sclepe as he hym leyd
Hym þouȝt how that he vengit mercury
To fore hym stode and bad hym be mery
His sclepn ȝerd he bare in hond vp riȝt
An hat he bare oppon his heris briȝt
Arayed was his god as he toke kepe
As he was when Argus toke his sclepe
And seyd thus wend þow shall to Attenes
There is the shape of thy woo an ende
And with that woord Arcite wook ⁊and stert
Now trewly howe sore þat I smert
Quod he to Attenes well I fare
Ne for drede of deth shal I nat spare
To se my lady that I serve
In hir͗e presence I rech nat to sterve
And with that word he cauȝt a grete myrroʳe
And saw that chaung it was his colour
And saw his vysage al in anothir kynde
And riȝt a noon it run hym in mynde
That sith yus his fase was disfugerid
Of the malady wich he had endurid
He myȝt wele yff he bare hym lowe
Lyve in Athenes evir more vnknowe
And see his lady nyȝ day be day
And riȝt a noon he chaung it his aray
And clad hym as a pore laborer
And al aloon save a poor Squyer
That knew his pryve ⁊and his case
Wich was disgisid porely as he was
To Attenes is he goon þe next wey
And to the court he went oppon a day
And atte gate he proferid his servise
To drug ⁊and drawe such as men wold devise
And shortly of this mater for to seyn̄
He fill in office toward a Chambirleyn̄
The wich that was dwelling was with Emely
For he was wise and wele cowd espye
Of every servant wich that servid there
Wel cowde he hew wood ⁊and watir beer
For he was yong ⁊and myȝty for / þe nonys
And ther͗e to was strong and bigg of bonys
To doon that eny white coude hym devise
A yeer / or to he was in this servise
Page in the Chambir of Emely the briȝt
And Philistrat he seyd that he hiȝt
But halfi so wele a lovid man as he
Ne was ther͗e noon in court of his degre
He was so gentil of condicioune

div.l: (base) That thurgh out al the Court was his renoun
(base) They seiden / that it were a charitee
(base) That Theseus / wolde enhauncen his degree
(base) And putten hym / in worshipful seruyse
(base) Ther as he myghte / his vertu excercise
(base) And thus with Inne a while / his name is spronge
(base) Bothe of his dedes / and his goode tonge
(base) That Theseus / hath taken hym so ner
(base) That of his chambre / he made hym a Squier
(base) And gaf hym gold / to mayntene his degree
(base) And eek men broghte hym / out of his contree
(base) Fro yeer to yeer / ful pryuely his rente
(base) But honestly / and sleighly / he it spente
(base) That no man wondred / how that he it hadde
(base) And thre yeer in this wise / his lyf he ladde
(base) And bar hym so / in pees / and ek in werre
(base) Ther was no man / that Theseus hath derre
(base) And in this blisse / lete I now Arcite
(base) And speke I wole / of Palamon alite
(base) ¶ In derknesse / and horrible / and strong prisoun
(base) This seuen yeer / hath seten Palamoun
(base) Forpyned / what for wo / and for distresse
(base) Who feeleth / double soor / and heuynesse
(base) But Palamon / that loue destreyneth so
(base) That wood out of his wit he gooth for wo
(base) And eek ther to / he is a prisoner
(base) Perpetuelly / nat oonly for a yer
(base) Who koude ryme / in englissh proprely
(base) His martirdom / for sothe it am noght I
(base) Therfore I passe / as lightly / as I may
(base) ¶ It fil / that / in that seuenthe yeer of May
(base) I wylle not taire yow alle the day
(base) The thridde nyght . as olde bokes seyn
(base) That al this storie / tellen moore pleyn
(base) Were it by auenture / or destynee
(base) As whan a thyng is shapen / it shal be
(base) That soone after the mydnyght Palamoun
(base) By helpyng of a freend / brak his prisoun
(base) And fleeth the Citee / faste as he may go
(base) For he hadde yeue / his Gailler drynke so
(base) Of a Clarree / maad of certeyn wyn
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) With Nercotikes / and opye / of Thebes fyn / /
(base) That al that nyght . thogh that men wolde hym shake
(base) The Gailler sleep / he myghte noght awake
(base) ¶ And thus he fleeth / as faste as euere he may
(base) The nyght was short and faste by the day
(base) That nedes cost he moste hymseluen hyde
(base) And til a groue / faste ther bisyde
(base) With dreedful foot thanne stalketh Palamoun
(base) For shortly / this was his opynyoun
(base) That in that groue / he wolde hym hyde al day
(base) And in the nyght thanne wolde he take his way
(base) To Thebesward / his freendes for to preye
(base) On Theseus / to helpe hym to werreye
(base) And shortly / outher he wolde lese his lyf /
(base) Or wynnen Emelie / vnto his wyf
(base) This is the effect and his entente pleyn
(base) ¶ Now wol I turne / to Arcite ageyn
(base) That litel wiste / how neigh that was his care
(base) Til that Fortune / hadde broght hym / in the snare
(base) ¶ The bisy larke / messager of day
(base) Salueth in hir song the morwe gray
(base) And firy Phebus / riseth vp so brighte
(base) That al the Orient . laugheth of the lighte
(base) And with his stremes / dryeth in the greues
(base) The siluer dropes / hangynge on the leues
(base) And Arcita / that in the Court roial
(base) With Theseus / is Squyer principal
(base) Is risen / and looketh on the murye day
(base) And for to doon / his obseruance to May
(base) Remembrynge / on the point of his desir
(base) He on a Courser / startlynge as the fir
(base) Is riden in to the feldes / hym to pleye
(base) Out of the Court . were it a myle / or tweye
(base) And to the groue / of which that I yow tolde
(base) By auenture / his wey he gan to holde
(base) To maken hym / a gerland of the greues
(base) Were it of wodebynde / or hawethorn leues
(base) And loude he soong . ayein the sonne shene
(base) May / with alle thy floures / and thy grene
(base) Wel come be thow / faire fresshe May
(base) In hope / that I som grene gete may
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) And from his courser / with a lusty herte
(base) In to the groue / ful hastily he sterte
(base) And in a path / he rometh vp and doun
(base) Ther as by auenture / this Palamoun
(base) Was in a bussh / that no man myghte hym se
(base) For soore afered / of his deeth was he
(base) No thyng knew he / that it was Arcite
(base) God woot he wolde haue trowed it ful lite
(base) But sooth is seyd / go sithen many yeris
(base) That feeld hath eyen / and the wode hath erys
(base) It is ful fair / a man to bere hym euene
(base) For alday meeten men / at vnset steuene
(base) Ful litel woot Arcite / of his felawe
(base) That was so neigh / to herknen al his sawe
(base) For in the bussh / he sitteth now ful stille
(base) ¶ Whan that Arcite / hadde romed al his fille
(base) And songen al the roundel lustily
(base) In to a studie / he fil sodeynly
(base) As doon thise louerys / in hir queynte gerys
(base) Now in the crop / now down in the brerys
(base) Now vp / now down / as boket in a welle
(base) Right as the friday / soothly for to telle
(base) Now it shyneth / now it reyneth faste
(base) Right so / kan gery Venus ouercaste
(base) The hertes of hir folk . right as hir day
(base) Is gerful / right so chaungeth she array
(base) Selde is the friday / al the wike ylike
(base) ¶ Whan that Arcite hadde songe / he gan to syke
(base) And sette hym down / withouten any moore
(base) Allas quod he / that day / that I was bore
(base) How longe Iuno / thurgh thy crueltee
(base) Woltow werreyen / Thebes the Citee
(base) Allas / ybroght is to confusioun
(base) The blood roial / of Cadme and Amphioun
(base) ¶ Of Cadmus / which that was the firste man
(base) That Thebes bulte / and first bigan
(base) And of the Citee / first was crowned kyng
(base) Of his lynage am I / and his of spryng
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) By verray ligne / as of the stok roial
(base) And now I am / so caytyf and so thral
(base) That he that is / my mortal enemy
(base) I serue hym / as his Squyer pourely
(base) And yet dooth Iuno / me wel moore shame
(base) For I dar noght biknowe myn owen name
(base) But ther as I was wont to highte Arcite
(base) Now highte I Philostrate / noght worth a myte
(base) ¶ Allas thow felle Mars / allas Iuno
(base) Thus hath youre Ire / oure lynage al fordo
(base) Saue oonly me / and wrecched Palamoun
(base) That Theseus / martireth in prisoun
(base) ¶ And oueral this / to sleen me outrely
(base) Loue hath his firy dart so brennyngly
(base) Ystiked / thurgh my trewe careful herte
(base) That shapen was my deeth / erst than my sherte
(base) Ye sleen me with youre eyen / Emelye
(base) Ye been the cause / wherfore that I dye
(base) Of al the remenant of myn oother care
(base) Ne sette I noght . the mountaunce of a tare
(base) So that I koude doon aught . to youre plesaunce
(base) And with that word / he fil down in a traunce
(base) A longe tyme / and afterward he vp sterte
(base) ¶ This Palamoun / that thoughte / that thurgh his herte
(base) He felte a coold swerd / sodeynly glyde
(base) For Ire he quook . no lenger wolde he byde
(base) And whan that he had herd / Arcites tale
(base) As he were wood / wᵗith face deed and pale
(base) He stirte hym vp / out of the buskes thikke
(base) And seyde Arcite / false traytour wikke
(base) Now art thow hent that louest my lady so
(base) For whom that I haue / al this peyne and wo
(base) And art my blood / and to my conseil sworn
(base) As I ful ofte / haue toold thee her biforn
(base) And hast byiaped here / duc Theseus
(base) And falsly / chaunged hast thy name thus
(base) I wol be deed / or ellis thow shalt dye
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Thow shalt noght / loue my lady Emelye
(base) But I wol loue hire oonly / and namo
(base) For I am Palamon / thy mortal foo
(base) And thogh that I / no wepne haue in this place
(base) But out of prisoun / am astert by grace
(base) I drede noght that outher thow shalt dye
(base) Or thow ne shalt noght louen Emelye
(base) Chees which thow wolt or thow shalt noght asterte
(base) ¶ This Arcite / with ful despitous herte
(base) Whan he hym knew / and hadde his tale herd
(base) As fiers as leoun / pulled out his swerd
(base) As fers as a liou saide thus be god that sittith aboue
(base) And seyde thus / by god that sitteth aboue
(base) Nere it that thow art syk and wood for loue
(base) And eek that thow / no wepne hast in this place
(base) Thow sholdest neuere / out of this groue pace
(base) But out of prisoun art y stert by grace
(base) That thow ne sholdest dyen of myn hond
(base) For I diffye / the seuretee and the bond
(base) Which that thow seist that I haue maad to thee
(base) What verray fool / thynk wel that loue is free
(base) And I wol loue hire / maugree al thy myght
(base) ¶ But for as muche / as thow art a worthy knyght
(base) And wilnest to darreyne hire by bataille
(base) Haue here my trouthe / tomorwe I nyl nat faille
(base) Withouten wityng of any oother wight
(base) That here I wol be founden / as a knyght
(base) And bryngen harneys / right ynogh for thee
(base) And chees the beste / and leef the worste to me
(base) And mete and drynke / this nyght wol I brynge
(base) Ynogh for thee / and clothes for thy beddynge
(base) And if so be / that thow my lady wynne
(base) And sle me in this wode / ther I am Inne
(base) Thow mayst wel haue thy lady / as for me
(base) ¶ This Palamon answerde / I graunte it thee
(base) And thus they been departed / til amorwe
(base) Whan ech of hem / hadde leyd his feith to borwe
(base) ¶ O Cupide / out of alle charitee
(base) O regne / that wolde no felawe haue to thee
(base) Ful sooth is seyd / that loue ne lordshipe
(base) Wol noght his thankes / haue no felaweshipe
(base) Wel fynden that Arcite and Palamoun
(base) ¶ Arcite / is riden anoon / vnto the town
(base) And on the morwe / er it were dayes lyght
(base) Ful priuely / two harneys hath he dyght
(base) Bothe suffisaunt and mete to darreyne
(base) The bataille in the feeld / bitwix hem tweyne
(base) And on his hors / allone / as he was born
(base) He carieth al this harneys / hym biforn
(base) And in the groue / at tyme and place yset
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) This Arcite / and this Palamon been met
(base) ¶ To chaungen / gan the colour in hir face
(base) Right as the hunterys / in the regne of Trace
(base) That stonden at the gappe / with a spere
(base) Whanne hunted is / the leoun or the Bere
(base) And hereth hym / come russhynge in the greues
(base) And breketh / bothe bowes / and the leues
(base) And thynketh / here cometh my mortal enemy
(base) Withoute faille / he moot be deed / or .I.
(base) For outher / I moot sleen hym / at the gappe
(base) Or he moot sle me / if that me myshappe
(base) So ferden they / in chaungyng of hir hewe
(base) As fer / as euerich / oother of hem knewe
(base) ¶ Ther nas no good day / ne no saluynge
(base) But streight withouten word / or rehersynge
(base) Euerich of hem / heelp for to armen oother
(base) As frendly / as he weere / his owene brother
(base) And after that with sharpe speres stronge
(base) They foynen / ech at oother / wonder longe
(base) Thou myghtest wene / that this Palamoun
(base) In his fightyng were a wood leoun
(base) And as a crewel Tygre / was Arcite
(base) As wilde boores / gonnen they to smyte
(base) That frothen / whit as foom / for Ire wood
(base) Vp to the Anclees / foghte they in hir blood
(base) And in this wise / I lete hem fightyng dwelle
(base) And forth I wole / of Theseus yow telle
(base) ¶ The destynee / Ministre general
(base) That executeth / in the world oueral
(base) The purueiance / that god hath seyn biforn
(base) So stroong it is / that thogh the world hadde sworn
(base) The contrarie of a thyng by ye / or nay
(base) Yet som tyme / it shal fallen on a day
(base) That falleth nat eft / with Inne a thousand yeer
(base) For certeinly / oure appetites heer
(base) Be it of werre / or pees / or hate / or loue
(base) Al is this ruled / by the sighte aboue
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) ¶ This mene I now / by myghty Theseus
(base) That for to hunten / is so desirus
(base) And namely / at the grete hert in May
(base) That in his bed / ther daweth hym no day
(base) That he nys clad / and redy for to ryde
(base) With hunte and horn / and houndes hym bisyde
(base) For in his huntyng hath he swich delit
(base) That it is / al his ioye and appetit
(base) To been hymself the grete hertes bane
(base) For after Mars / he serueth now Diane
(base) ¶ Cleer was the day / as I haue told er this
(base) And Theseus / with alle ioye and blys
(base) With his ypolita / the faire queene
(base) And Emelie / clothed al in greene
(base) On huntyng be they riden roially
(base) And to the groue / that stood ful faste by
(base) In which ther was an hert as men hym tolde
(base) Duc Theseus / the streighte wey hath holde
(base) And to the launde / he rideth hym ful right
(base) For thider was the hert wont haue his flight
(base) And ouer a brook / and so forth on his weye
(base) This duc / wol han a cours at hym / or tweye
(base) With houndes swiche / as that hym list comaunde
(base) And whan this Duc. was come vnto the launde
(base) Vnder the sonne he looketh / and anon
(base) He was war / of Arcite and Palamoun
(base) That foghten breme / as it were boles two
(base) The brighte swerdes / wenten to and fro
(base) So hidously / that with the leeste strook
(base) It semed / as it wolde felle an ook
(base) But what they weere / no thyng he ne woot
(base) This Duc his courser / with the spores smoot
(base) And at a stert he was bitwix hem two
(base) And pulled out a swerd / and cryed hoo
(base) Namoore / vpon peyne / of lesyng of youre heed
(base) By myghty Mars / he shal anon be deed
(base) That smyteth any strook / that I may seen
(base) But telleth me / what myster men ye been
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) That been so hardy / for to fighten heer
(base) Withouten Iuge / or oother officer
(base) As it weere in a lystes roially
(base) ¶ This Palamon / answerde hastily
(base) And seyde / sire / what nedeth wordes mo
(base) And seide sire what nedith wordes moo
(base) We haue the deeth disserued / bothe two
(base) Two woful wrecches been we / two caytyues
(base) That been encombred / of oure owene lyues
(base) And as thow art a rightful lord and Iuge
(base) Ne yif vs / neither mercy ne refuge
(base) But slee me first. for seinte charitee
(base) But slee my felawe eek as wel as me
(base) Or slee hym first. for thogh thow knowe it lite
(base) This is thy mortal foo / this is Arcite
(base) That fro thy lond / is banysshed on his heed
(base) For which / he hath deserued to be deed
(base) For this is he / that cam vnto thy yate
(base) And seyde / that he highte Philostrate
(base) Thus hath he iaped thee / ful many a yeer
(base) And thow hast maked hym / thy chief Squyer
(base) And this is he / that loueth Emelye
(base) For sith the day is come / that I shal dye
(base) I make pleynly / my confessioun
(base) That I am / thilke woful Palamoun
(base) That hath thy prisoun / broken wikkedly
(base) I am thy mortal foo / and it am I
(base) That loueth so hoote / Emelye the brighte
(base) That I wol dyen / present in hir sighte
(base) Wherfore I axe deeth / and my Iuwise
(base) But slee my felawe / in the same wise
(base) For bothe haue we / deserued to be slayn
(base) ¶ This worthy Duc answerde anoon agayn
(base) And seyde / this is a short conclusioun
(base) Youre owene mouth / by youre confessioun
(base) Hath dampned yow / and I wol it recorde
(base) It nedeth noght to pyne yow with the corde
(base) Ye shul be deed / by myghty Mars the rede
(base) ¶ The queene anoon / for verray wommanhede
