(base) ¶ Considreth eek / how that the harde stoon
(base) Vnder oure foot on which we ryde and goon
(base) It wasteth / as it lyth by the weye
(base) The brode Ryuer / som tyme wexeth dreye
(base) The grete townes / se we wane and wende
(base) Thanne se ye / that al this thyng hath ende
(base) Of man and womman / se we wel also
(base) That nedeth / in oon of thise termes two
(base) This is to seyn / in youthe / or ellis age
(base) He moot be deed / the kyng as shal a page
(base) Som in his bed / som in the depe see
(base) Som in the large feeld / as ye may se
(base) Ther helpeth noght al gooth that ilke weye
(base) Thanne may I seyn / that al this thyng moot deye
(base) What maketh this but Iuppiter the kyng
(base) That is Prince / and cause of alle thyng
(base) Conuertyng al vnto his propre welle
(base) From which it is diryued sooth to telle
(base) And heer agayns / no creature on lyue
(base) Of no degree / auailleth for to stryue
(base) ¶ Thanne is it wisdom / as it thynketh me
(base) To maken vertu / of necessitee
(base) And take it wel / that we may nat eschue
(base) And nameliche / that to vs alle is due
(base) And who so gruccheth oght he dooth folye
(base) And rebel is / to hym that al may gye
(base) And certeinly / a man hath moost honour
(base) To dyen / in his excellence and flour
(base) Whan he is siker / of his goode name
(base) Thanne hath he doon / his freend ne hym no shame
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) And gladder oghte / his freend been of his deeth
(base) Whan with honour / yolden is vp his breeth
(base) Than whan his name / apalled is for age
(base) For al forgeten is his vasselage
(base) Thanne is it best as for a worthy fame
(base) To dyen / whan he is best of name
(base) ¶ The contrarie of al this / is wilfulnesse
(base) Why grucchen we / why haue we heuynesse
(base) That goode Arcite / of chiualrie flour
(base) Departed is / with duetee / and with honour
(base) Out of this foule prison / of this lyf
(base) Why gruccheth heere / his cosyn and his wyf /
(base) Of his welfare / that loueth hem so weel
(base) Kan he hem thank nay god woot neuer a deel
(base) That bothe his soule / and eek hem self offende
(base) And yet they mowe / hir lustes nat amende
(base) ¶ What may I conclude / of this longe serye
(base) But after wo / I rede vs to be merye
(base) And thanken Iuppiter / of al his grace
(base) And er we / departen from this place
(base) I rede we make / of sorwes two
(base) O parfit Ioye / lastynge euere mo
(base) And loketh now / wher moost sorwe is her Inne
(base) Ther wol I first amenden and bigynne
(base) ¶ Suster quod he / this is my ful assent
(base) With al thauys / heer of my parlement
(base) That gentil Palamon / youre owene knyght
(base) That serueth yow / with wyl and herte myght
(base) And euere hath doon / syn ye first hym knewe
(base) That ye shal of youre grace vpon hym rewe
(base) And taken hym / for housbond and for lord
(base) Leen me youre hond / for this is oure acord
(base) Lat se now / of youre wommanly pitee
(base) He is / a kynges brother sone pardee
(base) And thogh he were / a poure Bachiler
(base) Syn he hath serued yow / so many a yeer
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) And had for yow / so greet aduersitee
(base) It moste been considred / leueth me
(base) For gentil mercy / oghte to passen right
(base) ¶ Thanne seyde he thus / to Palamon the knyght
(base) I trowe / ther nedeth litel sermonyng
(base) To make yow / assente to this thyng
(base) Com neer / and taketh youre lady by the hond
(base) Bitwixe hem / was maad anon the bond
(base) That highte matrymoigne / or mariage
(base) By al the conseil / and the Baronage
(base) And thus / with alle blisse / and melodye
(base) Hath Palamon / ywedded Emelye
(base) And god / that al this world hath wroght
(base) Sende hym his loue / that hath it deere aboght
(base) For now is Palamon / in alle wele
(base) Lyuynge in blisse / in richesse / and in heele
(base) And Emelye / hym loueth so tendrely
(base) And he / hir serueth so gentilly
(base) That was ther no word hem bitwene
(base) Of Ialousie / or any oother teene
(base) Thus endeth Palamon / and Emelye
(base) And god saue / al this faire compaignye Amen
Here endith the knyȝt his tale
And here be gynnyth the miller his prolog
When that the knyȝt had his tale I told
In all the world was þ̉ere yong ne oold
But seyd it was a nobill story
And worthy to be had in memory
And namely the gentils euerychoon
Our hoost swore and seyd by Seynt John
This goith a riȝt vnbokelid is the male
Let see who shall tell a nothir tale
For trewly the game is wel be gonn
Now tellith sir monke yf that yee conne
Som what to quyte with the knyȝte his tale
The miller that ful dronken was of ale
So that vnneth oppon his hors he satt
He wold a vale nethir hood ne hatt
Ne a byde no man for curtesy
But in pilatus voise he gan to cry
And swore by Armys blood and bonys
I can a nobill tale for the nonys
With wich I woll quyte the knyȝt his tale
They saw þat he was dronkyn of Ale
A byde Robyn a byde leve brothir
Sum bettir man shall tell vs a nothir
Abyde and lete vs work thryfftely
Be Goddis soule quod he that wol nat I
For I woll speke or go forth my wey
Thy bad tale tell on on devilwey
Thow art a fool thy wit is obir com
Now herkenyth quod the miller al rsoun
But first I make a protestacioune
That I am dronk I know it be my sown
And therfor sir yff I speek or sey
Weet it the ale of Southwork I ȝew prey
For I woll tell a legend and a lyffe
Both of a Carpentere and of his wyff
How that a Clerk hath set the writis capp
The Reve answerd and seyd stynt thy clapp
Let be thyn dronkyn harlotry
It is a synne and eke agrete foly
To appeir eny man or hym defame
And eke to bryng wyvis in such a name
Thow maist I nowȝ of othir thingis seyn
This dronken myller spak ful soon ageyn
And seyde a leve brothir Oswold
Hethat hath no wyff is no cukkold
But I sey nat therfor thow art oon
Ther been ful good wyvis many oon
And evir a thowsand good aȝenst oon badd
Thow knowist thy selff but yff thow be mad
Why art thow angry with my tale now
I have a wyff as wele as hast thow
Ȝit nold I for the Oxen in my plowȝe
Take oppon me more then I nowȝe
As deme of my selff that I were oon
I woll beleve that I am noon
An husbond shuld nat be enquysityff
Of Goddis pryvite ne of his wyffe
So he may fynde goddis foyson ther
Of the remnaunt it nedith nat to enquer
What shuld I sey but this myllere
He nold his woordis for no man for bere
But told his harlotry in his manere
Me forthinkith I shal reherce it here
And therfor every gentill man wᵗith hert I prey
For Goddis love demeth nat þat I sey
Of evill entent but that I must reherce
Hir talis wheþir they be bettir or wers
Or ellis falsen som of my matere
And therfor who so list nat to here
Turn ovir the leff and chese a nothir tale
For yee shull fynde I nowȝ grete ⁊and smale
Of historiall thing that towchith gentilnes
And eke moralite and holynes
Blamyth me nat they yee chese amys
The miller is a chorll yee know wele this
So was the Reve and many othir mo
And of harlotry they told both too
Avisith ȝew and put me out of blame
And eke men shuld nat make ernest of game
Here endith the Millere his prologg
And here begynnyth he his tale-
Whilom ther was dwellyng in Oxinforth
A riche chorll þat gestis had to bord
And of his crafft he was a carpentere
With hym was dwellyng a pore scolere
That had lernyd art but al his fantesy
Was turnyd for to lern astronomy
And also he coude certen of concluciouns
To Demyn by interrogaciouns
Yff that men axe of certen howris
Yff shuld com eny drouȝt or elles showris
Yff men axid hym what shuld be fall
Of al thing I may nat reherce all
This clerk was clepid ende Nicholas
Of dern loue he cowd and of solas
And therto he was sclyȝe and eke pryvye
And like a mayde meke forto see
A chambir had he in hostry
A loon with out eny company
Ful fetyse dyte with herbis swete
And he hym selff made it feet
With licorise and with Cetewale
His almery with bookis grete ⁊and smale
His astroloby longyng to his arte
His algrym stonys lyng feir a parte
On shewis cowchid at his beddis hede
His pres cobeid with a folding rede
And al a boke lay a gay Sawtre
On wich he made a nyȝtis melode
And Angelus ad virgynem he song
And seyd I woll nat kis the be my fey
Why let be seyd she let be Nicholas
Or I wol cry out and Allas
But he spak so feir and ꝓproferit hir so fast
That she hir love grauntid hym atte last
And swore hir othe by Seynt Thomas of kent
That she wold be at his comaundement
When that she may hir leyser wele espy
Myn husbond is so ful of Ielowsy
But that yee be ware and pryve
I am but dede I woot wele quod she
Yee must be ful dern as in this case
Nay ther of care nat I quod Nicholas
A Clerk had ful evill be set his while
But yff he cowd a cely carpenter begile
And thus they were accordit and I sworn
That at what tyme as I have seyd to forn
When Nicholas had doon thus everydele
And thakkid hir about the lendis wele
He kissith hir swetely and toke his sawtre
And pleyith fast and makith melode
Then fill it thus thatto the parissh chirch
Cristis own workis for to worche
This good wyff went oppon an holy day
Hir forhede shoon and was full gay
So was it wassh when she list to wirk
Now was there of the parissh chirch a clerk
The wich was clepid Absolon
Crull was his hede and as the gold it shoon
And strecchid as a faan larg ⁊and brode
Ful streyt ⁊and hevyn lay his hede a brood
His rud was rede his eyen grey as goos
With powlis wyndowis corven on his shois
In hosyn rede he went ful fetously
He clothid was ful smal and propirly
Ful feir in a kirtill in a litill waget
And passing wele the poyntis been set
And ther oppon he had agay surplise
As white as the flour of rise
Amery child he was so God me save
Well cowd he lete blood and eke shave
And make a Chartir of lond or a quetuᵃnce
In twenty maner cowd he tripp ⁊and daunce
Aftir the Scole of Oxinforth tho
And with his leggis casting to ⁊and fro
And pley songis on a smal ribibill
Som tyme he song a lowde quynybill
As wele coud he pley on a getern
In al the house nas ther brewhouse ne tavern
But he was ther with his solas
Ther eny galant tapster was
The soth to sey he was som dele skeymous
Of farting and such thingis Daungerouse
This Absolon that was Ioly and gay
Goith with the sensour on the holy day
Sensingthe wyvis of the parissh fast
And many a lovely look on hem he cast
And namly oppon the Carpenteris wyff
To look on hir he þouȝt a mery lyff
She was propir swete and likorouse
I dare wele sey and she had been a mowse
And he a Cat he wold hir hent a noon
This parissh Clerk this Ioly Absolon
Hath in his hert such a love longing
That of no wyff wold he take noon offring
For curtesy he seyd he wold noon
The moon when it was nyȝte briȝt shoon
And Absolon his githeryn hath I take
For paramowris he þouȝt to wake
And forth he goith gelous ⁊and amerouse
Tyll he com to the Carpenteris house
A litill aftir the Cok had I crowe
And dressid hym vndir a shott wyndow
That was oppon the Carpenters wall
And singith in his voise gentil ⁊and small
Now dere lady yff thy will be
I prey ȝew for to rew on me
Ful wele according to his gytirnyng
This Carpenter a wook ⁊and herd hym syng
And spak to his wyff and seyd anoon
What Alison herist þow nat Absolou
That chauntith thus vndir our bowris wall
And she answerd hir husbond ther with all
Ȝis God woot Iohn I her it every dele
This passith forth what woll yee bet þen wele
From day to day this Ioly Absolon
So besy a bowthir is that woo is hym be goon
He walkith al the nyȝt ⁊and al the day
He kembith his lokkis ⁊and makith hym gay
He wowith hir by menys of brocage
And swore he wold be hir own page
He singith broking as a nyȝtyngale
He sent hir meth pyment ⁊and spicid Ale
Wafris pipeing out of the gleed
And for she was of town he ꝓproferid mede
For som folk woll love vommen for riches
Som for strokis som for gentilnes
Som tyme to shew his hiȝe mastre
He pleyith herode oppon a scaffold tre
But al avaylith hym nat in this case
So lovith she this end Nicholas
That Absolon shal blow the bukkis horn
He nat for his labour but a scorn
And thus she makith Absolon hir Ape
Al his ernest she turnyth in to a Iape
For soth this proverb is no ly
Men sey that the nyȝte is scly
Makith the ferr love to be loth
For þouȝ that Abselon be wood or wroth
Be cause he was ferr from hir eye siȝte
This Nycholas stondith in his liȝte
Now bere the wele hend Nicholas
For Absolon may syng and sey Allas
And so it fill oppon a Satirday
This Carpenter was goon to Oseney
And eke Nycholas and Alyson
Accordit were to this conclusyoun
That Nycholas shal shapyn hym a wyle
This sely Ielouse husbond to begyle
If so be the game went a riȝte
She shuld sclepe in his Armys that nyȝt
For this is his desir and hers also
And riȝte a noon with out wordis mo
This Nycholas no leng wold tary
But doith ful sofftly onto his chambir cary
Both mete and drynk for a day or tweyn
And to hir husbond bad she shuld seyn
Yff that he axid aftir end Nicholas
She shuld sey she nyst wher he was
Of al that day she saw hym nat wᵗith eye
trowid he had som malady
For no cry þe mayde did call
He wold answere for auȝte þᵗat myȝt fall
This passith forth al the Satirday
That Nicholas still in his bed lay
And ete and sclepe and did what hym list
Tyll Sonday þat þe sonne goith to rest
This sely Carpenter had grete mervaill
Of Nicholas or what thing myȝt hym eyle
And seyd I am dede by Seynt Thomas
It stondith nat ariȝte with Nicholas
God sheld that he died sodenly
This world is now ful feculy
I saw this day a corse born to chirch
That a monday last was I saw hym wirch
Go vp quod he to his knave a noon
Clepe at his dorr or knok with a stoon
Loke how it is and tel it boldly
This knave went vp ful sturdely
And atte Chambir dorr whils that he stood
He cried and knokkid as he were wood
What how what do yee mastir Nicholay
How may yee sclepe al this long day
But al for nouȝt he wold here nevir a woord
An hool he saw low vndir a borde
Ther as the Cat was wont in to crepe
And atte hole he lokith in ful depe
And atte last he had of hym a siȝte
This Nicholas sat evir gaping vp riȝt
As he had lokid on the new moon
And down he goith and told his mastir sone
In what aray he saw this ilk man
This Carpenter to blis hym be gan
And seyd help vs seynt Frethiswyde
For wee woot litill what we shul be tyde
This man is fal with his Astronomy
In to som woodnes or to sum Agoy
And thouȝt wele how it shuld be
Men shuld nat know of Goddis pⁱrivite
I blessid be al wey a lewd man
That but al oonly his beleve can
So farid a nothir clerk with Astronomy
He walkid in to the feldis for to pry
Oppon the Sterris to weet what shuld be fall
Tyll he was in a marl pit I fall
He saw it nouȝt but ȝitbe Seynt Thomas
Me grevith sore for end Nicholas
He shall be ratid of his studijng
Ȝyff that I may be Ihıı̄un heven kyng
Gete me a staff that I myȝte vndir / sporr /
Whils thow Robyn hevist vp the dorr
He shall out of his stodijng I ges
And to the Chambir dorr he gan hym dres
His man was a strong knave for the nonys
And by the hasp he hevid vp the dorr attonys
In to the floor fill the dorr a noon
This Nycholas sat as still as eny stoon
And evir gapid in to the heire
This Carpenter went he had been in dispeir /
What thynk on God as wee do men that swynk
This Nicholas answerd fet me drynke
And aftir woll I speek in pryvete
Of certen thingis that towchyn the ⁊and me
I woll noon othir man tell it certeyn
This Carpentere goith down ⁊and comyth ageyn
And brouȝt of myȝty ale a quart
And when that ech man had dronk his parte
This Nicholas his dorr fast shitt
And down the Carpentere by hym he sett
And seyd Iohn my hoost leve and dere
Thow shalt oppon thy trowith swere here
Thatto no white þow shalt my counsell wrey
For it is Cristis counsell that I sey
Yff thow tellit any man þow art lore
For vengaunce þow have shalt therfore
And yff thow wry me thow shal be wood
Nay Criste for bede it for his blood
Quod this sely man I am no blab
And thouȝe I sey I am nat leve to gabb
Sey what thow wolt I shall it nevir tell
To child ne wyff by hym that horowid hell
Now Iohıı̄un quod Nicholas I woll nat ly
I have founden in my Astronomy
As I have lokid oppon the moon the bryȝt
That now a monday next at nyȝte
Shall fall a reyne and that so wild ⁊and wood
That halff so grete was nevir noyous flood
This world he seyd in les then and an our
Then shall man kynde Drench wᵗith the shoure
This Carpenter answerd Allas Allas my wyff
Shal she end thus that is my best lyff
And shall she drown Allas my Alisoune
For sorow of this he fill al most a down
And is ther no remedy in this case
Ȝis for God quod ende Nicholase
Yff thow wolt work aftir lore and rede
Thow maist nat work aftir thyn own hede
For this seith Salamon þat was ful trewe
Work al by counsell and þow shalt nevir rewe
And yff thow wolt work be my counsell
I vndirtake with out mast or seyll
That I shal save hir the and me
Hast þow nat herd how savid was Noe
When that our lord had warnyd hym to forne
That al the world with watir shuld be lorne
Ȝis quod this Carpenter ful yore ago
Hast þow nat herd quod Nicholas tho
The sorow of Noe with his feleshipp
He had levir I vndir take
At that tyme that al his wetheris blake
That she had had a Shipp hir selff aloon
And herkenyth now what is best to doon
This askith hast and hastly thing
Men may nat prech ne make no tarying
A noon go gete vs fast to this In
And kneding trowȝe ⁊and a kemelyn
For ech of vs but look that they be large
In the wich wee may swym as in a barge
And have ther in vitaill suffisaunte
But o day fyȝ on the remnaunte
The watir shall sclake and go a wey
Abowt pryme the next Day
But Robyn may nat weet of this þy knave
Ne gill thy mayde I may nat save
Ask nat why for þouȝ þow ask me
I woll nat tell Goddis pryvite
It suffisith the but yff thy witt be mad
To have a grete a grace as Noe had
Thy wyff shall I wele save out of Dowt
Go now thy wey and spede the her abowte
But when thow hast for hir the ⁊and me
Gete vs these kneding trowȝis thre
Then shalt thow hang hem in the roff ful hiȝe
That no man of our purpose espy
And when thow hast doon as I have seyde
And hast our vitaill in hem leyde
And an axe to smyte the with a too
That when the watir comyth that wee may goo
And breke an hole an hiȝe oppon the gabill
In to the gardenward ovir the stabill
That wee may frely pas forth our wey
When the grete showre is passid a wey
Then shall wee swym I vndirtake
As doith the white dook aftir the Drake
Then woll I call how Alison how Iohn
Be mery for the flood woll pas a noon
And thow shalt sey heill mastir Nicholay
Good morow I see thee wele for it is day
And then shull wee be lordis al our lyff
Of all the world as Noe and his wyff
But o thing I warn the be riȝt
Be wele a visid oppon that ilk nyȝt
When wee be entrid within our / shippis borde
That noon of vs speke oon woord
Ne call ne cry but be in preyere
For it is goddis own will dere
Thy wyff ⁊and thow must hong fer be twyn
That be twix ȝew shall be no synne
Nomore in looking then in dede
This is soth so God me spede
To morow at nyȝt when folk be a sclepe
Then woll wee in our kneding tubbis crepe
And sit there a biding Godd is grace
Go þow thy wey I have no lengir spase
To make as nowȝ no lenger sermonyng
Men sey send the wise ⁊and sey no thing
Thow art so wise it nedith the nat to teche
Go save our lyvis I the be seche
This sely carpenter goith forth his wey
Ful offt he seith Allas and welawey
Vn to his wyff he told his pryvite
And she was ware and knew it bet then he
What al this ment þat was so schyȝe
But nethirles she farith as she wold dy
And seyd Allas forth with a noon
Help vs to scape that wee be nat dede echon
I am thy trew weddit wyff
Go dere husbond and help to save our lyff
Lo wich grete thing is in effeccioun
Men may for ymagenacioune
So depe in pression be take
This Cely Carpentere began to quake
Hym thinkith verely þat he may se
Noyis flood comyng as the see
To drownyn alison his hony dere
He wepith and waylith ⁊and makith sory chere
He siȝith ⁊and makith many a sory suowȝ
He goith forth ⁊and getith hym a kneding trowȝ
And aftir that a tub ⁊and a kemelyn
And pryvely he sent hem to his In
And hangith hem in the roff pryvely
And aftir he made laddris thre
To clymb by the rongis ⁊and by the stalkis
Vn to the coplis that hangith in þe balkis
And vitaylith both trowȝ ⁊and tubbis
With brede ⁊and chese ⁊and good ale in Iubbis
Suffising as for oon day
But when he made al this aray
He sent his wenche ⁊and his knave also
Oppon his nedis to london to go
And on the morow when it was nyȝt
He shit his dorris by candilliȝte
And dressith all thing as it shal be
And shortly vp they clymbyn al thre
They sit still a furlong wey
Pater noster clom seyd Nicholay
And clom quod Iohn ⁊and clom qd Alisoun
This Carpenter seyd his devocioune
And still he sittith and seith his preyer
Wayting on the reyne yf he it here
The dede sclepe for wery ⁊and besynes
Fill on this Carpentere riȝt as I ges
Abowt curfu tyme or litill more
For traveling in his goost ⁊and in his sclepe sore
And aftir he rowtid for his hede mys lay
Down on the laddir stalkith Nicholay
And Alisoun ful fast down she sped
With out woordis mo they go to bedd
Ther as the Carpenter is wont to ly
Ther was the Ioy ⁊and the melody
And thus hath Alisoun ⁊and Nicholas
In besynes myrth and solas
Tyll that the bell of lawdis gan ryng
And Freris in the chaunsell gon syng
This Parissh clerk this Absolon
That for love so wo is be goon
Oppon the monday was at Oseney
With company for to disport hym ⁊and pley
And axid oppon a caas a cloysterere
Ful pryvely aftir Iohıı̄un the Carpentere
And he drowȝ a parte out of the chirch

And they are com to know hir entent
How he wold lete his old sacrifice
And riȝt a noon for hir counsell she sent
And they are com to know hir entent
When these folk assemblit were in feer
She set hir down̄ and seyd in this manere
¶ Lordis quod she yee know everichon
How that my sone in poynt is to lete
The holy lawis of Alkeron
And both our Goddis and eke makamete
But oon a vow to the grete God I hete
The lyff shal rathir out of my body stert
Or makamytis law shal out of myne hert
¶ What shuld vs tyde of this new law
But thraldom to our body ⁊and penaunce
And afftirward in hel to be draw
For wee renyed Mahounde our creaunce
But lordis wol yee make assuraunce
And I shall sey assenting to my lore
And I shall make vs saff for evir more
¶ They swore ⁊and assentid every man
To lyve with hir͗ ⁊and dy ⁊and by hir stonde
And eủery man in the best wise that he can
To strengith hir shuld hir Frendis fonde
And she this Emprise hath take in honde
Wich yee shall heer as I shal devise
And to hem al spak in this wise
¶ Wee shal first on vs Cristendom take
Cold watre shal nat greve vs but lite
And I shal such a Feest and revell make
That as I trow I shal the Sowdon quyte
For thowȝ his wyff be nevir so white
She shall have nede to wassh a wey þe rede
Thouȝe she as much of watir wᵗith hir lede
¶ O Sowdennes rote of Iniquite
Virago thow Samaritan the seconde
O serpent vndir feminete
Like to the Serpent depe in hell I bounde
Vertu and Innocence thurh thy malice
I bred in the annexid to every vice
¶ O Sathan envious sith that day
That thow were clothid from our heritage
Wele knowist þow to vommen þe old wey
Thow madist oon to bryng vs in ʆservage
Thow wolt fordo this cristen mariage
Thyn Instrument so welawey the while
Makist when thow wilt hir begile
¶ Thow Sowdennes whom I thus blame ⁊and werry
Lete pryvely hir counsell goon a wey
What shuld I in this tale long tary
She ridith on to the Sowdon oppon a day
And seid hym she wold renay hir lay
And Cristendom of prestis hond fonge
Repentyng she hethin hath be so longe
¶ Beseching hym to do hir that honour͗e
That she myȝte have the cristen folk to Feest
To plese hem I wol do my laboure
The Sowdon seyd he wold do hir heest
And knelyng thanking hir of þat request
So glad he was he wist nat what to sey
She kissid hir sone and home she went hir wey
¶ Aryvid are the Cristen folk to londe
In Surrey with a grete solempne route
And hastly this Sowdon sent his sonde
First to his modir ⁊and to al the Reem abowte
And seyd his wyff was come wᵗith out Dowte
The honour of his Reem to susteen
¶ Grete was the prees ⁊and rich was the aray
Of Surrens ⁊and Romeyns met in feer
The modir of the Sowdon rich ⁊and gay
Resseyvid hir with glad chere
As eny modir myȝte hir douȝt̉er dere
And to the next cete ther͗e beside
div.note: Iohn pasmore
These notes are signatures written upside-down.
div.l: A sofft pase solempnly they ride
¶ Nat thurh the tryhumphe of Iulius
Of wich that lucan made heest
Were rialler ne more coriouse
Then was the assemblyng of this feest
But this scorpioun this wrecchid beest
The Sowdennes for al hir flateryng
Cast these folk mortally to styng
¶ The Sowdon comyth hym selff sone aftir this
So riall that wondir it was to tell
And welcomed hir with Ioy ⁊and blis
div.note: Iohn̄ Huāngn̄
div.l: And thus with myrth ⁊and Ioy I lete hem dwell
The fruyte of this mater is that I tell
When tyme com men þouȝte it for the best
That Revell stynt and men to go to rest
¶ The tyme com the old Sowdennes
Ordeyned hath the wu Feest þe wich I told
And to the Feest Cristen folk they dres
In generall both yong ⁊and olde
Ther͗e may men see Feest ⁊and rialtees hold
And deyntees mo then I can devise
But al to dere they bouȝt it or they rise
¶ O Sowdon woo that evir þow art successour
Thy wordly bles steynyd is with bittirnes
The end of our Ioy ⁊and wordly laboure
Woo occupiith the feir of our͗e gladnes
Herken this counsell for thy sikirnes
Oppon thy glad day have þow mynde
The vnware woo that comyth behynde
¶ For shortly to tell it at oon worde
The Sowdon and the Cristen everichone
Were al to hewyn ⁊and stikkid atte bord
But yff it were Dame Custaunce Aloon
This old Sowdenes this cursid croon
Hath with hir Frendis doon this cursid dede
For she hir selff wold al the contre lede
¶ There was Surren man that was conủertyd
That of the counsell of the Sowdon woot
That he was al to hewe or he a stertid
And Coustance have they take foot hote
And in a Shipp̄ stereles God woot
They have hir set and bid hir lern to saill
Out of Surrey a geyn in to Itaill
¶ And certen tresour that she thidir ledd
And soth to sey vitaill grete plente
They have hir gyven ⁊and clothis grete plente
And forth saylid in the salt see
O my Custaunce ful of benignite
O Emꝑperours yong douȝtir Dere
He that is lord of Fortune be thy stere
¶ She blissid hir And wᵗith ful petouse voise
Vn to the Crosse of Criste seyd she
O Clere o wilfull Autir holy crosse
Reed of thy lambis blood ful of pete
That wisshist the world ful of Iniquite
Fro the Fende ⁊and from his clowis kepe
That day that I shall drown in the Depe
¶ Victorius proteccioune of so of so trewe
That oonly worthy were to bere
The kyng of hevyn with his woordis new
The white lambe that hurt was wᵗith a speer
Flemer of Fendis out of hym ⁊and her͗e
In to the wich thy lymys feithfully extende
Me kepe ⁊and gyff me myȝt to amende
¶ Ȝeris ⁊and dayis thus fletith this creature
Of many a sory mele she may bite
Afftir hir Deth full offt she may wayte
Or that the wild wawis woll hir dryve
On to the plase there she shall aryve
Men myȝte axe why she was nat sleyn
And I answere to that Demaunde a geyn
¶ Who savid Danyell in the horribill Cave
Ther͗e every white both mastir and knave
Was with the lyon fret or he a stert
No white but God that he bare in his hert
God list to shewe his wondirful myrakill
In hir͗e for wee shuld see his myȝty merwill
¶ Criste that is of euery man treacle
By certen menys as knowen clerkis
Doith thingis end ful certen þat ful derk is
To mannys witt þurh our ignoraunce
Ne can nat know his perfite purveaunce
¶ Now sith she was atte Feest no w t now not sclaw
Who kepith hy mrr hym hyrr from drownyng oppon the see
Who kept Ionas in the fisshis mawe
Tyl he was spit out at Nyneve
Wele may men know it was no white but he
What kept the pepill Ebrak from drownyng
¶ Who hidith the four spiritis of tempest
That power hath ovir londe ⁊and see
Both north ⁊and south Est and west
Anoyith no wher͗e londe see ne tree
Sothly the comaundir ther͗e of was he
That from the tempest ay this vōmman kept
As wele when she wakid as when she slept
¶ Wher͗e myȝte this vomman mete or drynk have
Thre yeer ⁊and more how lastid hir vitaill
Who fed the Egipcian mary in the cave
Or in desert noon but Criste saunce faill
V Mƚthousand folk it was a grete mervaill
With lovis too and Fisshis fyve to Fede
God sent his fusioune fusioune fusoune at that grete nede
¶ She dryvith forth in to the occeane
Thurh the wild see tyll atte last
Vndir an holt the name I ne can
In Northumbirlonde the wawis hir͗e cast

div.l: (base) And in the sond hir ship stiked so faste
(base) That thennes wolde it noght of al a tyde
(base) The wyl of crist was that she sholde abyde
(base) The Constable of the Castel down is fare
(base) To seen this wrak and al the Ship he soghte
(base) And foond this wery womman ful of care
(base) He foond also the tresor that she broghte
(base) In hir langage mercy she bisoghte
(base) The lyf out of hir body for to twynne
(base) Hir to deliuere of wo that she was Inne
(base) A manere latyn corrupt was hir speche
(base) But algates ther by was she vnderstonde
(base) The Constable whan hym liste no lenger seche
(base) This woful womman broghte he to the londe
(base) She kneleth doun and thanketh goddes sonde
(base) But what she was she wolde no man seye
(base) For foul ne fair thogh that she sholde deye
(base) She seyde she was so mazed in the See
(base) That she forgat hir mynde by hir trouthe
(base) The Constable hath of hire so greet pitee
(base) And eek his wyf that they wepten for routhe
(base) She was so diligent withouten slouthe
(base) To serue and plese euerich in that place
(base) That alle hir louen that looken on hir face
(base) This Constable and dame Hermengyld his wyf
(base) Were payens and that contree euery where
(base) To telle ȝou playne in peynes boþe were
(base) But hermengyld loued hire right as hir lyf
(base) And Custaunce hath so longe soiourned there
(base) In orisons with many a bitter teere
(base) Til Ihu hath conuerted thurgh his grace
(base) Dame Hermengyld Constablesse of thilke place
(base) In al that land no cristen dorste route
(base) Alle cristen folk been fled fro that contree
(base) Thurgh Payens that conquereden al aboute
(base) The plages of the North by land and see
(base) To Walys fledde the cristianytee
(base) Of olde Britons dwellyng in this Ile
(base) Ther was hir refut for the mene while
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) But yet nere cristen Britons so exiled
(base) That ther nere somme that in hir pryuetee
(base) Honoured crist and hethen folk bigiled
(base) And neigh the Castel swiche ther dwelten thre
(base) That oon of hem was blynd and myghte nat se
(base) But it were with thilke eyen of his mynde
(base) With whiche men seen after that they been blynde
(base) Bright was the Sonne as in that Someres day
(base) For which the Constable and his wyf also
(base) And Custaunce han ytake the righte way
(base) Toward the See a furlong wey or two
(base) To pleyen and to romen to and fro
(base) And in hir walk this blynde man they mette
(base) Croked and old with eyen faste yshette
(base) In name of Crist cryde this blynde Britoun
(base) Dame hermengyld yif me my sighte agayn
(base) This lady weex affrayed of the sown
(base) Lest that hir housbonde shortly for to sayn
(base) Wolde hire for Ihu cristes loue han slayn
(base) Til Custaunce made hir boold and bad hir wirche
(base) The wyl of Crist as doghter of his chirche
(base) The Constable weex abasshed of that sight
(base) And seide what amounteth al this fare
(base) Custaunce answerde sire it is Cristes myght
(base) That helpeth folk out of the feendes snare
(base) And so ferforth she gan oure lay declare
(base) That she the Constable er that it was eue
(base) Conuerteth and on Crist made hym bileue
(base) This Constable was no thyng lord of this place
(base) Of which I speek ther he Custaunce fond
(base) But kepte it strongly many wynter space
(base) Vnder Alla kyng of al Northumberlond
(base) That was ful wys and worthy of his hond
(base) Agayn the Scottes as men may wel heere
(base) But turne I wole agayn to my matere
(base) Sathan that euere vs waiteth to bigile
(base) Saugh of Custaunce al hir perfeccioun
And kist a noon how he myȝt have his will
And made a yong knyȝt that dwellid in þe town̄e
Loff hir so hoot with foule affeccioune
That verely hym þouȝt þat he shuld spill
But yff he of hir myȝte have his will
¶ He wowith hir but it a vaylith nauȝte
She woll do no synne by no wey
For dispite he compassid in his þouȝt
To make hir a shamefull deth to dey
He waytith when the Constabill was a wey
And pryvely on a nyȝt he gan crepe
In to Armegellis Chambir when she sclepe
¶ Wery forwakid in hir orisouns
Slepith Custaunce And Armoger also
This knyȝte þurh Sathanas temptaciouns
Al sutilly is to the bedd Igo
And cut the throte of Armoger also
And leyde the blody kyn knyff by dame Custance
And went his wey God gyff hym myschᵃunce
¶ Soon aftir comyth the Constabill home ageyn
And also Alla that was kyng of þat londe
And saw his wyffe dispetously scleyn̄
For whom he wept ⁊and wrong his hond
And in the bedd the blody knyff he fonde
Be syde Dame Custaunce Allas what myȝt she say
For verry woo his wit was nere a wey
¶ The kyng Alla was told al this chaunce
And eke the tyme And eke the wise
That in a Shipp Dame Custaunce
As here to fore yee have herd devise
The kyngis hert of pete be gan to rise
When he saw so benigne a creature
Thus much care to endure
¶ For as the lambe toward hir Deth is brouȝt
So stont this Innocent to fore the kyng
This fals knyȝt that had this treson wrouȝt
Berith hir on hond that she hath doon þis þing
But nethirles ther͗e was grete mornyng
Among the pepill and seyd I can nat ges
That she hath doon so grete wiccidnes
¶ For they have seen hir evir so vertuouse
And lovid Armegell riȝt as hir lyff
Of this bare witnes al that were in þe house
Save he that sclouȝ Armegell wᵗith hir knyff
This gentill kyng hath cauȝt a grete motyff
Of þis witnes and þouȝt he wold enquer͗e
Depper in this caas the trowith to here
¶ Allas Custaunce þow hast no champioune
Ne fiȝte can þow nat so welawey
But he that for our redempcioune
Bond Sathan and lijth ther͗e he lay
He be thy strong Champioun this day
But Criste som mirakill on the kithe
With out gylt thowe shalt dy as swith
¶ She set hir down on kneis And þus she seyde
Inmortal God þat savedist Susanne
From fals blame And þow merciful mayd
Mary I meen the douȝt͗e of Seynt Anne
To fore whose child Aungellis syng Osanne
If I be giltles of this foly
My socour be or I shall dey
¶ Have yee nat offt tymes see a pale fase
Among prese of hem þat hath be ledd
Toward his he deth ther͗e as he getith no grace
And such a colour in hir fase had
Men myȝt know hir͗e fase that was bestad
Among al the fasis in the rowte
So stood Custaunce and lokid hir͗e A bowte
¶ Quenys ⁊and dukis and ladies everichone
Have som mercy on this aduersite
An Emperours douȝtir stood a loon
She hath no wite to whom to make hir mone
O blood riall that stondist in this Drede
Ferr are thy Frendis at thy grete nede
¶ This kyng Alla hath grete compassioune
As gentill hert fulfillid with pete
That from his eyen ran the watir down̄e
Now hastly go fet the knyȝt quod he
And yff that he wol swere that she
This vomman sclouȝe ȝit wol wee vs avise
Whom wee wolel þat shal be our Iustice
¶ A breten booke writen wᵗith Euᵃaungelisis
Was fet And on this book he swore anoon
She gilty was and the meen whilis
An hond hym smote oppon the nekk boon
That Down he fill as Dede as a stoon
And both his eyen brast out of his fase
In siȝt of every body that was in the plase
¶ A voise was herd in generall audience
And seyd thow hast disclaundrit giltlese
The Douȝtir of holy chirch in hiȝe presence
Thus hast þow doon and ȝit I hold my pese
Of this mervaill agast was al the prese
And as masid folk they stood echoon
For Drede of wreke save Custaunce Aloon
¶ Grete was the Drede and eke the repentᵃunce
Of hem that had wrong suspecioune
Oppon this sely Innocent Custaunce
And for these myraclis in conclusioune
And by Custaunce meditacioune
The kyng ⁊and many othir in that plase
Conuertid was thankid be Goddis grace
¶ This fals knyȝte was scleyn for his vntrowith
By Iugement of kyng Alla hastely
And ȝit Custaunce hath of his deth rowith
And aftir this IħcIhesu for his mercy
Made Alla wedd ful solempnly
This holy mayde briȝte and sheen
And thus Criste made Custaunce a quene
¶ But who was woful yff I shal nat ly
Of this wedding but Donegell ⁊and no mo
The kyngis modir ful of Tyranny
Thouȝt hir cursid hert brak on too
She wold nat hir sone had doon so
Hir͗e þouȝt dispite that she shuld take
A straunge creature on to his make
¶ Me list nat of the chaff ne of the stree
Make so long a tale as of the corn̄
What shuld I tell of the rialte
Of the mariage or wich cours went to fore
Who blowith in Trompis or wich cours went to fore
The fruyte of every tale this is to sey
They eten ⁊and dronkyn songyn and pley
¶ They go to bed as it was skill and riȝte
For they that be ful holy thyng
Take must in pacient a nyȝte
Such maner neessarijs as been plesing
To folk that hath weddit hem with Rynge
And liȝtly ley hir holynes a syde
As for the tyme it may noon othir betyde
¶ On hir he gate a knav child a noon
And to his bisshopp and to his Constabill eke
He took his wyff to kepe whils he is goon
To Scotlonde his Foo men to seke
Now feir Custaunce þat is so humbil ⁊and meke
So long is goon with Childe þat still
She holdith hir Chambir abyding Cristis will
¶ The tyme is com a knave child she bere
Mawricius atte Font Stoon they hym calla
This Constabill bryngith forth a messengere
And wrote to his kyng that callid was Alla
How that this blesfull tyding was be faƚƚlla
And othir thingis spedefull to sey
He takith the lettir and forth he goith his way
¶ This Messengere goith for his auᵃauntage
Vnto the kyngis modir ridith swith
And saluyth hir feir in his langage
Madame quod he yee may be glad ⁊and blith
And thank God an hundrit þowsand sith
My lady the Quene hath child wᵗithout dowte
To Ioy ⁊and blis to al the Reem a bowte
¶ Lo here is the lettir sent of this thinge
That I must bere with al the hast I may
Ȝyff yee woll eny thing to yeur son þe kyng
I am yeur ʆservaunte both nyȝte ⁊and day
Donegild answerd at this tyme nay
But her͗e all nyȝte I woll thow take thy rest
To morow I wol sey the what me lest
¶ This Messengere Drank sadly ale ⁊and wyne
And stolen were his lettris pryvely
Out of his boxe whils he sclept like a swyne
And countirfetid was ful suttilly
An othir lettir wrouȝt synfully
Vn to the kyng directid of this matere
From his Constabill as yee shull here
¶ The lettir spak the Quene Delyverid was
Of so horribill a Fendly creature
That in the Castell Durst they nat endure
The modir was an elff by Aventure
Comyn by Charmys or by sorcery
And that every man hatid hir company
¶ Woo was the kyng when he the lettir had seen
Butto no white he told his sorys sore
And of his own honde he wrote ageyn̄
Wel com the sonde of Criste for evir more
To me that am lernyd in this lore
Lord welcom thy will and thy plesaunce
My lust I put al in thy chaunce
¶ Kepe this childe al be it foule or feir
And eke my wyff to my home comyng
Criste when hym list may send me an heir
More agreabill then this to my likeyng
This lettir he selid ful pryuely wepeing
Wich to the Messenger͗e was take sone
And forth he goith ther͗e is no more to doon
¶ O Messenger fulfillid of dronkenes
Strong is thy breth thy lymys flaterith ay
And thow be wreyist al sikirnes
Thy mynde is lorn þow Iangelist as a Iay
Thy fase is turnyd in to a newe array
There Dronkenes reynyth in eny rowte
Ther͗e is no counsell hid with out Dowte
¶ O Donegell I have noon Englissh digne
On to the malice of thy Tyranny
Therfor to the Fend I þe resigne
Let hym endite of thy tyranny
Fy manas fy o nay be God I ly
Fy on thy spirite I dare wele tell
Thouȝe þow here walk thy spirite is in hell
¶ This Messenger com fro þe kyng ageyn
And atte kyngis modirs court he liȝte
And she was of his message feyn̄
And plesid hym in al þat she myȝte
He Drank ⁊and wele his girdill vp piȝte
He sclept ⁊and he snowrith in his gise
All the ny⁊andte til the son rise
¶ And then were his lettrys stolen everychone
And countirfetid lettris in this wise
The kyng comaundith his Constabill a noon
Of peyn of honging ⁊and of hiȝe Iuyse
That he ne shuld suffir in no wise
Custaunce in this Reem to a bide
Thre dayis ⁊and a quartir of a tyde
¶ But in the same Shipp as he hir fonde
Hir ⁊and hir yong sone ⁊and al hir h h gere
He shuld hem throug from the londe
And charge hir͗e that she nevir more com þ̉ere
O my Custaunce wele may thy goost have feer
And in thy Shipp dryve with penaunce
When Donegell kist al this ordenaunce
¶ This messengere when he a wook
On to the Castell holdith the next wey
And to the Constabill the lettrys toke
And when he this spetouse lettir had sey
Ful offt he seyd allas ⁊and welawey
Lord Criste quod he how may this world endure
So ful of synne is many a creature
¶ O almyȝty God yff it be thy will
Sith þow art riȝtful Iugge how may it be
That þow wolt suffir an Innocent to spill
And wyld folk to regn in prosperite
A good Custaunce Allas woo is me
That me must be thy turmentoᵘure I Dy
On shameful Deth ther͗e is no more to sey
¶ There wepith yong ⁊and old in that plase
When the kyng this cursid lettir sent
And Custaunce with a pale fase
The same day toward hir Shipp went
But ȝit she thankid God with good entent
The will of Criste ⁊and kneling on the sonde
She seyd ay welcome Goddis sonde
¶ He that me kept fro the fals blame
While I was on þe londe a monge ȝew
He can me kepe from harm ⁊and fro shame
In the salt see þouȝ þat I se nat how
As strong as evir he was he is riȝt now
In hym trust I ⁊and in his modir Dere
That is to me my sayll ⁊and eke my stere
¶ Hir litill child lay wepeing in hir Arm
And kneling petously to hym she seyd
Pees litill child I wol do the no harm
With that hir kercher on his hede she leyd
And ovir his eyen she it sprede
And in hir Arm she lullid it ful fast
Into the hevyn vp hir eyen she cast
¶ Modir quod she ⁊and mayde briȝt Mary
Sith that it is þurh wommans egment
Mankynde was lost ⁊and dampnyd to dy
For wich thy Child was on cros rent
This blesful eyen saw al this turment
Then is ther͗e noon comparisoune be twene
Thy woo ⁊and myne þat I may it susteen
¶ Thow saw thy child scleyn to fore thyn eyen
And ȝit lyvith my litill child ꝑparfay
Now lady briȝt to whom we al crien
Thow glory of vommanhede þow feir may
Thow haven of refute briȝt Sterr of the Day
Rew on my child that of thy gentilnes
That rewist on every synner in distres
¶ O litill child allas what is thy gilt
That nevir ȝit wrouȝtist syn parde
Why woll thy herd Fadir have the spilt
O mercy o Dere Constabill quod she
As let my litill child here Dwell with the

Wich nedith nat reherce at þis tyme
And his office I shaƚƚ hym teƚƚ I wis
Our hoost answerd pees no more of this
And aftirward he seid on to the Frere
Tel forth yeur tale leve mastir dere
Here endith th Frere his prologg
And here begynnyth the Frere his tale
Whilom was dwellyng in my contre
An Archedeken a man of hiȝe degre
That boldly did execucioune
In punysshing of Fornicacioune
Of wich crafft and eke of bawdry
Of diffamacioune and of avowtry
Of Chirchrevis and of testamentis
Of contractis and lak of sacrementis
Of Vsury and of Symony also
But certis lechours did he grettest woo
They shuld syng yf they were hent
And smale tithers were foule I shent
Yff eny persone wold oppon hem pleyn
Ther͗ myȝt astert hym no pecunial peyn
For smale tithis and smale offeryng
He made the pepiƚƚ spetously to syng
For or the bisshopp cauȝt hym with his hook
They were in the Erchebisshoppis book
Then had he þurh his Iurisdiccioune
Power to do on hem correccioune
He hae a Sompnour redy to his honde
A sclyer boy was noon in Englonde
For sutilly he had his especiaƚƚlle
That tauȝt hym wher͗ he myȝt availe
He cowde spare lechours oon or to
To teche hym to four ⁊and twenty mo
For þouȝe the Sompnour were wood as an hare
To teƚƚ his harlotry I wol nat spare
For wee be out of his correccioune
They have of vs noon Iurisdiccioune
Ne nevir shuƚƚ term of al hir lyvis
Petir so been the vommen of the stewis
Qod þe Sompnour put out of our cure
Pees with myschaunce ⁊and mysaventure
Thus seid our hoost and let hym tel his tale
Now tel forth and let þe Sompnoᵘure gale
Ne sparith nat myne own̄ mastir dere
This fals Sompnour quod the Frere
Had alwey bawdis redy to his honde
As eny hawke to lure in Englonde
To teƚƚ hym aƚƚ the secre þat þee knewe
For hir aqueyntaunce is al fal of newe
They were his aprowers pryvely
He toke hym selff a grete profite þ̉ere by
His mastir knew nat al that he wan
With out maundement of a lewd man
He cowd somyn on peyn of Cristis curs
And they were evir glad to fil his purs
And made hym grete festis atte nale
And riȝte as Iudas had pursis smale
And was a thefe such a theff was he
His mastir had but half his duyte
He was yff I shaƚƚ gyve hym a lawde
A theff a sompnour and eke a bawde
And he had eke wenchis of his retenew
That were it ʆsir Robert or sir huh
Or Iohn̄an or Raff or who that it were
That lay by herre they told it in his ere
Thus was the wench and he of oon assent
And he wold shew a feynyd maundement
And somyn hem to the chaptir both to
And pil the man and let the wench go
Then wold he sey Frend I shaƚƚ for þy sake
Do streke the out of our lettris blake
The nedith no more in this case to traveƚƚ
I am thy Frende I woƚƚ the avaiƚƚ
Certen he knew of bribeiris mo
Then possibiƚƚ is to teƚƚ ȝew to
For in this world is dogg for þe bow
That knowith an hurt dere wᵗith a bow
Than this sompnour knew a lechoure
Or a vowtrere or els a paramoure
And for that was the fruyte of al his rent
Therfor on hit he set al his entent
And so be fiƚƚ that onys on a day
This Sompnour was weyting on his pray
Redy for to somon an old wyff rebekk
Feynyng a cause for he wold breke
And it happid that he saw to fore hym ryde
A gay yeman vndir a Forest syde
A bow he bare and arowis bryȝte ⁊and kene
He had oppon a courtepy of grene
An hat oppon his hede with fetheris blake
Sir quod this sompnour heiƚƚ ⁊and wele Itake
Welcom quod he and eủery good felaw
Whethir ridist thow vndir this wood shaw
Seyd this yeman whethir wolt þow fare to day
This Sompnour answerd and seyd nay
Here fast be syde quod he is myne entent
To ryde to resseyve vp my rent
It longith onto my lordis dewte
Art thow then a bayly ȝee quod he
He durst nat for verry vylany ⁊and shame
Sey that he was a Sompnour for the name
Deux per deu quod this yeman dere brothir
Thow art a bayly and I am anothir
I am vnknow as in this contre
Of thy aqueyntaunce I wol prey the
And eke of brethered yff that yee list
I have gold ⁊and sylvir in my chest
If þat þee happ to com in to our shire
Al shaƚƚ be thyne ryȝt as þow wolt desire
Graunt mercy quod the Sompnoᵘure be my feith
Eủerych of othir hond in othir leyith
For to be sworn̄ brotheryn tyl they dey
And with that woord they ride forth hir wey
This Sompnour þat was ful of Iangillis
As ful of venym been these wiranglis
And evir enqueryng oppon every þing
Brothir quod he where is yeur dwelling
Anothir day yf I shuld ȝew sech
Thys ȝeman hym answerith in short spech
Brothir quod he in the North contre
Where as I hope som tyme the to see
Or we depart we shal the so wele wis
That of my house shalt þow nevir mys
Now brothir quod this Sompnoᵘure I ȝew prey
Teche me whils wee riden by the wey
Sith that yee be a baylyff as am I
Som sotilte tel me now feithfully
In myne office how that I may most wyn
And sparith nat for conscience ne syn
But as my brothir tel me how do yee
Now be my trowith brothir dere seyd he
That I shaƚƚ tel the a feithful tale
My wagis been ful streyte and smale
My lord is hard to me and daungeroꝰus
And myne office is ful laborouse
And therfor by extorciouns I lyff
For I take al that men woƚƚ me gyff
Algate by scleyte or ellis by violence
Fro yeer to yeer I wyn my dispence
I can no bet ne tellyn feithfully
Now certis quod the Sompnour so fare I
I spare nat to take God it woot
But yf it be to hevy or to hote
What I may gete in counseƚƚ pryuely
Nomaner conscience ther͗ of have I
Ner myne extorcioune I myȝt nat lyve
Of such Iapes I wol me nat shryve
Stomak ne conscience know I noon
I shrew these shryvfadris everichon
Wele be wee met by God ⁊and by seynt Iame
But leve brothir teƚƚ me thy name
Quod this Sompnoᵘure in this mene while
This yeman gan a litiƚƚ to smyle
Brothir quod he wolt þow þat I the teƚƚ
I am a Fende my dwellyng is in heƚƚ
And here I ryde aboute my purchasing
To wete wher men wol gyve me eny thing
My purchas is to set of al my rent
Loke how þow ridist for þe same entent
To wyn good þow rekkist nere how
Riȝte so fare I for ryde wol I now
Vnto the worldis end for a pray
A benedicite quod this Sompnour what yee say
I ween yee were a yeman trewly
Yee have a mannys shapp as wele as I
Have yee a figure then determinate
In heƚƚ ther͗ yee be in yeur estate
Nay certenly quod he ther͗ have wee noon
But when wee likith wee can vs oon
Or els make ȝewe seme wee be shape
Som tyme like a man ⁊and som tyme like an ape
Or like an Aungeƚƚ can I ryde or go
¶ It is no wondir thing þouȝe it be so
A lowsy iogolour can disseyv the
And parde ȝit can I more crafft þan he
Why quod this Sompnour ryde ye then or goon
In sundry shapp and nat al wey in oon
For wee quod he wol vs in such foᵘurme make
As most abiƚƚ is our prayis to take
What makith ȝew to have aƚƚ this labour
Ful many a cause leve sire Sompnour
Seyd this Fend but al thing hath tyme
The day is short it is passid pryme
And ȝit ne wan I no thing in this day
I woƚƚ entend to wynnyng yf I may
And nat entend our wittis to declare
For brothir myne thy wit is al to bare
To vndirstond þouȝe I told hem the
But for þow axiste why labour wee
For som tyme we be Goddis Instrumentis
And menys to do his comaundementis
When that hym list oppon his creaturis
In diuers artis and in diuers figuris
With out hym wee have no myȝte certeyn
Yff that hym list to stond ther͗ ageyn
And som tyme at our preyer have we leve
Oonly the body and nat the soule to greve
Witnes of Iob that wee did woo
And som tyme have wee myȝt of both to
This is to sey of soule and body eke
And som tyme wee be suffrid for to seke
Oppon a man and do his soule vnrest
And nat his body and al is for the best
When he with stondith our temptacioun
It is a cause of his saluacioune
Al be it that it was nat our entent
He shuld be saff but that wee wold hym hent
And som tyme wee be seruᵃauntis onto man
As the Erchebisshop seynt Dunstan
And to the Apostelis servant was I
Ȝit teƚƚ me quod the Sompnoᵘure feithfully
Make yee thus yeur bodies al way
Of Elementis the Fend answerd nay
Som tyme wee feyn ⁊and som tyme we arise
With dede bodiis in ful sondry wise
And speke as renabiƚƚ feir and wele
As to the Phenysca did Samuele
And ȝit woƚƚ som men sey it was nat he
I do no force of yeur diuinite
But o thing I warn the I wol nat Iape
Thow wolt algatis wete how wee be shape
Thow shalt lere here aftir my broþir dere
Com ther͗ it nedith nat of me to lere
For thow shalt by thyn own̄ experience
Cone in the cheyer rede this centence
Bettir then virgiƚƚ whils he was on lyve
Or Daunte also now let vs ride belyve
For I woƚƚ hold company with the
Til it be so that thow forsake me
¶ Nay quod this Somnour that shal nat bityde
I am a yeman knowen is ful wyde
My trouthe wol I holde as in this cas
For theigh thow were the deuel Sathanas
My trouthe wol I holde to thee my brother
As I am sworn and ech of vs til oother
For to be trewe brother in this cas
And bothe we goon abouten oure purchas
Taak thow thy part what that men wol thee yeue
And I shal myn thus may we bothe lyue
And if that any of vs haue moore than oother
Lat hym be trewe and parte it with his brother
¶ I graunte quod the deuel by my fey
And with that word they ryden forth hir wey
And right at the entryng of the townes ende
To which this Somnour shoop hym for to wende
They saye a Cart that charged was with hey
Which that a Cartere droof forth in his wey
Deep was the wey for which the Carte stood
This Cartere smoot and cryde as he were wood
Hayt Brok hayt Scot what spare ye for the stones
Hayt skot hayt harad hat brok atonys
The feend quod he yow fecche body and bones
As ferforthly as euere were ye foled
So muchel wo as I haue with yow tholed
The deuel haue al bothe hors and Cart and hey
¶ This Somnour seyde heer shul we han a pley
And neer the feend he drogh as noght ne were
Ful pryuely and rowned in his ere
Herkne my brother herkne by thy feith
Herestow nat how that the Cartere seith
Hent it anon for he hath yeue it thee
Bothe hey and Cart and eek his caples thre
¶ Nay quod the deuel god woot neuer a del
It is nat his entente trust thow me wel
Axe hym thy self if thow nat trowest me

div.l: (base) Or ellys stynt a while / and thow shalt se
(base) ¶ This Cartere / taketh his hors vpon the croupe
(base) And they bigonne / drawen and to stoupe
(base) Heyt now quod he / ther Ihu crist yow blesse
(base) And al his handes werk bothe moore and lesse
(base) That was wel twight myn owene lyard boy
(base) I pray god saue thee / and Seint loy
(base) Now is my Cart out of the slow pardee
(base) ¶ Lo brother quod the feend / what tolde I thee
(base) Heere may ye se / myn owene deere brother
(base) The Carl spak o thyng but he thoghte another
(base) Lat vs go forth / abouten oure viage
(base) Heere wynne I no thyng vpon cariage
(base) ¶ Whan that they coomen / som what out of towne
(base) This Somnour / to his brother gan to rowne
(base) Brother quod he / here woneth an old rebekke
(base) That hadde almoost as leef to lese hir nekke
(base) As for to yeue a peny / of hir good
(base) I wol han twelue pens / thogh that she be wood
(base) Or I wol somne hire / vnto oure office
(base) And yet god woot of hire knowe I no vice
(base) But for thow canst nat as in this contree
(base) Wynne thy cost taak heer ensample of me
(base) This Somnour / clappeth at the wydwes gate
(base) Com out quod he / thow olde viritrate
(base) I trowe thow hast som frere / or preest with thee
(base) ¶ Who clappeth seyde this wyf / benedicitee
(base) God saue yow sire / what is youre swete wille
(base) ¶ I haue quod he / of somonce a bille
(base) Vp peyne of cursyng looke that thow be
(base) To morn / bifore the Erchedeknes knee
(base) Tanswere to the court of certeyn thynges
(base) ¶ Now lord quod she / crist Ihu kyng of kynges
(base) So wisly helpe me / as I ne may
(base) I haue been syk and that ful many a day
(base) I may nat go so fer quod she / ne ryde
(base) But I be deed / so priketh it in my syde

div.l: (base) May I nat axe a libel / sire Somnour
(base) And answere there / by my procutour
(base) To swich thyng as men wole opposen me
(base) ¶ Yis quod this Somnour / pay anon lat see
(base) Twelf pens to me / and I wol thee acquyte
(base) I shal no profit han ther by / but lyte
(base) ¶ My Maister hath the profit / and nat I
(base) Com of / and lat me ryden hastily
(base) Yif me .twelue. pens / I may no lenger tarye
(base) ¶ Twelf pens quod she / now lady Seinte Marie
(base) So wisly help me god / out of care and synne
(base) This wyde world / thogh that I sholde wynne
(base) Ne haue I nat twelue pens / with Inne myn hoold
(base) Ye knowen wel / that I am poure and oold
(base) Kythe youre almesse / on me poure wrecche
(base) ¶ Nay thanne quod he / the foule feend me fecche
(base) If I thexcuse / theigh thow shul be spilt
(base) ¶ Allas quod she / god woot I haue no gilt
(base) ¶ Pay me quod he / or by the swete Seinte Anne
(base) As I wol bere awey / thy newe panne
(base) For dette / which thow owest me of oold
(base) Whan that thow madest / thyn housbonde cokewold
(base) I payde at hom / for thy correccioun
(base) ¶ Thow lyxt quod she / by my sauacioun
(base) Ne was I neuere er now / wydwe ne wyf
(base) Somoned vnto youre court in al my lyf /
(base) Ne neuere I nas / but of my body trewe
(base) Vnto the deuel / blak and row of hewe
(base) Yeue I thy body / and my panne also
(base) ¶ And whan the deuel / herde hire cursen so
(base) Vpon hir knees / he seyde in this manere
(base) Now Mabely / myn owene moder deere
(base) Is this youre wyl in ernest / that ye seye
(base) ¶ The deuel quod she / so fecche hym er he deye
(base) And panne and al / but he wol hym repente

div.l: (base) ¶ Nay olde stot that is nat myn entente
(base) Quod this Somnour / for to repente me
(base) For any thyng that I haue had of thee
(base) I wolde I hadde thy smok / and euery clooth
(base) ¶ Now brother quod the deuel / be noght wrooth
(base) Thy body and this panne / been myne by right
(base) Thow shalt with me to helle / yet to nyght
(base) Wher thow shalt knowen / of oure pryuetee
(base) Moore / than a maister of dyuynytee
(base) And with that word / this foule feend hym hente
(base) Body and soule / he with the deuel wente
(base) Wher as that Somnours / han hir heritage
(base) And god / that made after his ymage
(base) Mankynde / saue / and gyde vs alle and some
(base) And leue thise Somnours / goode men to bicome
(base) ¶ Lordynges / I koude han told yow / quod this frere
(base) Hadde I had leyser / for this Somnour heere
(base) After the text / of crist Poul and Iohn
(base) And of oure othere doctours / many oon
(base) Swiche peynes / that youre hertes myghte agryse
(base) Al be it so / no tonge may it deuyse
(base) Thogh that I myghte / a thousand wynter telle
(base) The peynes / of thilke cursed hous of helle
(base) But for to kepe vs / fro that cursed place
(base) That he here vs from that cursed place
(base) Waketh / and preyeth Ihu for his grace
(base) So kepe vs / fro the temptour Sathanas
(base) And also from the temptour Sathanas
(base) Herketh this word / beth war as in this cas
(base) The leoun sit in his awayt alway
(base) To sle the Innocent if that he may
(base) Disposeth ay youre hertes / to withstonde
(base) The feend / that yow wolde maken thral and bonde
(base) He may nat tempte yow / ouer youre myght /
(base) For crist wol be youre champion and knyght
(base) And prayeth / that this Somnours hem repente
(base) Of hir mysdedes / er that the feend hem hente
(base) ¶ Here endeth / the freres tale

div.l: (base) ¶ The Prologe / of the Somnours tale

(base) ¶ Hic desinit fabula f̉reris /
Et incipit ꝓprologus Sıı̄unmonitoris
(base) This Somnour in his Stiropes / hye he stood
(base) Vpon this frere / his herte was so wood
(base) That lyk an Aspen lief / he quook for Ire
(base) ¶ Lordynges quod he / but o thyng I desire
(base) I yow biseke / that of youre curteisye
(base) Syn ye han herd / this false frere lye
(base) As suffreth me / I may my tale telle
(base) This frere bosteth / that he knoweth helle
(base) And god it woot that it is litel wonder
(base) Freres and feendes / been but lyte asonder
(base) For pardee / ye han ofte tyme herd telle
(base) How that a frere / rauysshed was to helle
(base) In Spirit ones / by avisioun
(base) And as an Aungel / ladde hym vp and down
(base) To shewen hym / the peynes that ther were
(base) In al the place / say he nat a frere
(base) Of oother folk / he say ynowe in wo
(base) Vnto this Aungel / spak the frere tho
(base) ¶ Now sire quod he / han freres swich a grace
(base) That noon of hem / shal come to this place
(base) ¶ Yis quod this Aungel / many a Milioun
(base) And vnto Sathanas / he ladde hym doun
(base) And now hath Sathanas / seith he a tayl
(base) Brodder / than of a Carryk is the sayl
(base) Hold vp thy tayl / thow Sathanas quod he
(base) Shewe forth thyn ers / and lat the frere se
(base) Where is the nest of freres / in this place
(base) And er that / half a furlong wey of space
(base) Right so as bees / out swarmen from an hyue
(base) Out of the deueles ers / ther gonne dryue
(base) Twenty thousand freres / on a route
(base) And thurgh out helle / swarmeden aboute
(base) And comen again / as faste as they may gon
(base) And in his ers / they crepten euerychon
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) He clapte his tayl agayn / and lay ful stille
(base) This frere / whan he looked hadde his fille
(base) Vpon the tormentz / of this sory place
(base) His spirit god restored of his grace
(base) Vnto his body agayn / and he awook
(base) But nathelees / for fere yet he quook
(base) So was the deueles ers / ay in his mynde
(base) That is his heritage / of verray kynde
(base) God saue yow alle / saue this cursed frere
(base) My prologe / wol I ende / in this manere
(base) ¶ Here endeth the prologe of the Somnours tale
(base) ¶ Hic desinit ꝓprologus / Et incipit fabula
(base) Here bygynneth the Somnours tale
(base) Et incipit fabula
(base) LOrdynges ther is in Yorkshire as I gesse
(base) A Merssh contree called holdernesse
(base) In which ther wente a lymytour aboute
(base) To preche and eek to begge it is no doute
(base) And so bifel that on a day this frere
(base) Hadde preched at a chirche in his manere
(base) And specially abouen euery thyng
(base) Excyted he the peple in his prechyng
(base) To trentals and to yeue for goddes sake
(base) Wher with men myghte holy houses make
(base) Ther as dyuyne seruice is honoured
(base) Nat ther as it is wasted and deuoured
(base) Ne ther it nedeth nat to be yeue
(base) As to possessioners that mowen lyue
(base) Thanked be god in wele and habundaunce
(base) Trentals seyde he deliuereth from penaunce
(base) Hir freendes soules as wel olde as yonge
(base) Ye whan that they been hastily ysonge
(base) Nat for to holde a preest Ioly and gay
(base) He syngeth nat but o masse in a day
(base) Deliuereth out quod he anon the soules
(base) Ful hard it is with flessh hook or with oules
(base) To been yclawed or to brenne or bake
(base) to kepe ȝou fro peynes of feendes blake
(base) Now spede yow hastily for cristes sake
(base) And whan this frere hadde seyd al his entente
(base) With qui cum patre forth his wey he wente

div.l: (base) Whan folk in chirche hadde yeue hym what hem leste
(base) He wente his wey no lenger wolde he reste
(base) With scryppe and typped staf ytukked hye
(base) In euery hous he gan to poure and prye
(base) And beggeth Mele and chese or ellis corn
(base) His felawe hadde a staf typped with horn
(base) A peyre of tables al of yuory
(base) And a poyntel polysshed fetisly
(base) And wroot the names alwey as he stood
(base) Of alle folk that yaf hem any good
(base) Ascaunces that he wolde for hem preye
(base) Yif vs a busshel whete Malt or Reye
(base) A goddes kechyl or a tryp of cheese
(base) Or ellis what yow lyst we may nat chese
(base) A goddes half peny or a masse peny
(base) Or yif vs of youre brawn if ye haue eny
(base) A dagon of youre Blanket leeue Dame
(base) Oure suster deere lo heere I write youre name
(base) Bacoun or boef or swich thyng as ye fynde
(base) A sturdy harlot wente ay hem bihynde
(base) That was hir hostes man and baar a sak
(base) And what men yaf hem leyde it on his bak
(base) And whan that he was out at dore anon
(base) He planed awey the names euerichon
(base) That he biforn hadde writen in his tables
(base) He serued hem with nyfles and with fables
(base) Nay ther thow lixt thow Somnour quod the frere
(base) Pees quod oure hoost for cristes moder deere
(base) Tel forth thy tale and spare it nat at al
(base) So thryue I quod this Somnour so I shal
(base) So longe he wente hous by hous til he
(base) Cam til an hous ther he was wont to be

(base) With pitous teerys tolde it anon right
(base) That he hir soules saugh to heuene glyde
(base) With Aungeles ful of cleernesse and of light
(base) And with his word conuerted many a wight
(base) For which Almachius dide hym so bete
(base) With whippe of leed til he his lyf gan lete
(base) Cecile hym took and buryed hym anon
(base) By Tiburce and Valerian softely
(base) With Inne hir buryyng place vnder the stoon
(base) And after this Almachius hastily
(base) Bad hise Ministres fecchen openly
(base) Cecilie so that she myghte in his presence
(base) Doon sacrifice and Iubiter encense
(base) But they conuerted at hir wise loore
(base) Wepten ful sore and yauen ful credence
(base) Vnto hir word and cryden moore and moore
(base) Crist goddes sone withouten difference
(base) Is verray god this is al oure sentence
(base) That hath so good a seruant hym to serue
(base) This with o voys we trowen thogh we sterue
(base) Almachius that herde of this doynge
(base) Bad fecchen Cecilie that he myghte hir se
(base) And alderfirst lo this was his axynge
(base) What maner womman artow quod he
(base) I am a gentil womman born quod she
(base) I axe thee quod he thogh it the greue
(base) Of thy religioun and of thy bileue
(base) Ye han bigonne youre question folily
(base) Quod she that wolden two answeres conclude
(base) In o demande ye axed lewedly
(base) Almachie answerde vnto that similitude
(base) Of whennes comth thyn answeryng so rude
(base) Of whennes quod she whan that she was freyned
(base) Of conscience and of good feith vnfeyned
(base) Almachius seyde ne takestow noon hede
(base) Of my power and she answerde hym this
(base) Youre myght quod she ful litel is to drede
(base) For euery mortal mannes power nys
