div.l: (base) But lyk a bladdre ful of wynd ywys
(base) For with a nedles point whan it is blowe
(base) May al the boost of it be leyd ful lowe
(base) Ful wrongfully bigonne thow quod he
(base) And yet in wrong is al thy perseueraunce
(base) Wostow nat how oure myghty princes free
(base) Han thus comanded and maad ordinaunce
(base) That euery cristen wight shal han penaunce
(base) But if that he his cristendom withseye
(base) And goon al quyt if he wol it reneye
(base) Youre Prynces erren as youre nobleye dooth
(base) Quod tho Cecile and with a wood sentence
(base) Ye make vs gilty and is nat sooth
(base) For ye that knowen wel oure Innocence
(base) For as muche as we doon a reuerence
(base) To crist and for we bere a cristen name
(base) Ye putte on vs a cryme and eek a blame
(base) But we that knowen thilke name so
(base) For vertuous we may it nat withseye
(base) Almache answerde chees oon of thise two
(base) Do sacrifice or cristendom reneye
(base) That thow mowe now escapen by that weye
(base) At which this holy blisful faire mayde
(base) Gan for to laughe and to the Iuge she sayde
(base) O Iuge confus in thy nycetee
(base) Wiltow that I reneye Innocence
(base) To maken me a wikked wight quod she
(base) Lo he dissimuleth heere in audience
(base) He stareth and woodeth in his aduertence
(base) To whom Almachius vnsely wrecche
(base) Ne wostow nat how fer my myght may strecche
(base) Han noght oure myghty princes to me yeuen
(base) Ye bothe power and auctoritee
(base) To maken folk to dyen or to lyuen
(base) Why spekestow so prowdly thanne to me
(base) I speke noght but stedefastly quod she
(base) Nat proudly for I seye as for my syde
(base) We haten dedly thilke vice of pryde
(base) And if thow drede nat a sooth to here
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Thanne wol I shewe al openly by right
(base) That thow hast maad a ful greet lesyng here
(base) Thow seist thy princes han thee yeuen myght
(base) Bothe for to sleen and for to quyken a wight
(base) Thow that ne mayst but oonly lyf byreue
(base) Boþe for to sleen and for to quyke a wight
(base) Thow hast noon oother power ne no leue
(base) But thow mayst seyn thy princes han thee maked
(base) Ministre of deeth for if thow speke of me
(base) Thow lyest for thy power is ful naked
(base) Do wey thy boldnesse seyde Almachius tho
(base) And sacrifice to oure goddes er thow go
(base) I recche nat what wrong that thow me profre
(base) For I kan suffre it as a Philosophre
(base) But thilke wronges may I nat endure
(base) That thow spekest of oure goddes here quod he
(base) Cecilie answerde o nyce creature
(base) Thow seydest no word syn thow spak to me
(base) That I ne knew therwith thy nycetee
(base) And that thow were in euery maner wise
(base) A lewed Officer a veyn Iustise
(base) Ther lakketh no thyng to thyne outter eyen
(base) That thow nart blynd for thyng that we seen alle
(base) That is a stoon that men may wel espien
(base) That ilke stoon a god thow wolt it calle
(base) I rede thee lat thyn hand vpon it falle
(base) And taste it wel and stoon thow shalt it fynde
(base) Syn that thow seest nat with thyne eyen blynde
(base) It is a shame that the peple shal
(base) So scornen thee and laughe at thy folye
(base) For comenly men woot it wel oueral
(base) That myghty god is in hise heuenes hye
(base) And thise ymages wel thow mayst espye
(base) To thee ne to hem self mowe noght profite
(base) For in effect they be nat worth a myte
(base) Thise and swiche othere seyde she
(base) And he weex wrooth and bad men sholde hir lede
(base) Hoom til hir hous and in hir hous quod he
(base) Bren hire right in a Bath of flambes rede
(base) And as he bad right so was doon the dede
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) For in a Bath they gonne hire faste shetten
(base) And nyght and day greet fyr they vnder betten
(base) The longe nyght and eek a day also
(base) For al the fyr and eek the Bathes hete
(base) She sat al coold and feeled no wo
(base) It made hir nat o drope for to swete
(base) But in that Bath hir lyf she moste lete
(base) For he Almachius with a ful wikke entente
(base) To sleen hire in the Bath his sonde sente
(base) Thre strokes in the nekke he smoot hire tho
(base) The tormentour but for no maner chaunce
(base) He myghte noght smyte al hir nekke atwo
(base) And for ther was that tyme an ordinaunce
(base) That no man sholde doon man swich penaunce
(base) The ferthe strook to smyten softe or soore
(base) This tormentour ne dorste do namoore
(base) But half deed with hir nekke ycoruen there
(base) He lefte hir lye and on his wey he went
(base) The cristen folk whiche that aboute hire were
(base) With shetes han the blood ful faire yhent
(base) Thre dayes lyued she in this torment
(base) And neuere cessed hem the feith to teche
(base) That she hadde fostred hem she gan to preche
(base) And hem she yaf hir moebles and hir thyng
(base) And to the Pope Vrban bitook hem tho
(base) And seyde I axed this of heuene kyng
(base) To han respit thre dayes and namo
(base) To recommende to yow er that I go
(base) To perfourme that I before haue do
(base) Thise soules lo and that I myghte do Werche
(base) Here of myn hous perpetuelly a cherche
(base) Seint Vrban with hise deknes pryuely
(base) The body fette and buryed it by nyghte
(base) Among hise othere Seintes honestly
(base) Hir hous the chirche of Seinte Cecilie highte
(base) Seint Vrban halwed it as he wel myghte
(base) In which in to this day in noble wyse
(base) Men doon to crist and to his Seinte seruyse
(base) Here is ended the Nonnes tale
And here begynnyth the Priores hir tale
O lord our lord thy name so mervelouse
Is in this world I sprad quod she
For nat only thy laude preciouse
ꝑparfourmyd is by men of dignite
But by the mowith of children thy bounte
ꝑparfourmyd is for in our brest sookyng
Somtyme shew theyne herying
¶ Wherfor in laude as I can best ⁊and may
Of the þat art of the lyly floure
Wich that the bare ⁊and art a mayde alway
To tel a story I wol do my laboure
Nat þat I may encrese hir honour
For sche hir selff is honour ⁊and þe rote
Of bounte next hir son ⁊and soulis bote
¶ Modir maide o maid modir fre
O bussh vnbrent brennyng in moyses siȝte
That ravissh it down fro þe dignite
Thurh þyn humbles the goost þat in þe liȝt
Of whose vertu when he in thy hert a lȝte
Conseyvid was the Fadir sapience
Help me to tell in thy reverence
¶ Lady thy bounte and thy magnificence
Thy vertu and thy grete humilite
Ther̉e may no thing expres in no centence
For som tyme lady or men prey onto the
Thow goist to fore of thy benyngnite
And getist vs the liȝte þarlithy
To leden vs on to his sone so clere
¶ My connyng is to weik o blesful Quene
For to declare thy grete worthines
That I ne may ne no white sustene
But as a child of twelv month age or les
That can vnneth eny word expres
But so fare I ⁊and therfor I ȝew prey
Guydeth my songe that I shall say
¶ There was a child in a grete cete
Among cristen folk in the Iewrye
Sustened by a lord of þat Contre
For foule vsury and lickyr of vilony
That fill to Crist and to his companye
And þurh the strete men myȝte ⁊and wende
For it was fre ⁊and open at ech end
¶ A litill scole of Cristen folk þer stode
Down in the ferther end in wich þer were
Childryn an hepe com of Cristen blood
That lernyd in þat scole yer by yeer
Such maner doctryn as men vsyn here
This is to sey to syng ⁊and to rede
As smale children doon in hir childhede
¶ Among these children was a wedowis son
A litill Clergioun vij yeer of age
That day be day to scole was his wonne
And wher that evir he saw þe Image
Of Cristis modir had he in vsage
As hym was tauȝt to knele a down ⁊and sey
His Aue mari as he goith by the wey
¶ Thus hath this wedow hir litill child tauȝt
Our blessid lady Cristis modir dere
To worshipp ay ⁊and he forgate it nauȝt
For þe cely child wold al day sone lere
But ay when I remembir me on þis matere
Seynt Nicholas stont evir in my presence
For he so yong to Crist did reverence
¶ This child his litill book lernyng
As he sat in the scole at his prymer
He Alma redemptoris mater herd syng
As Children lern hir Antiphoner
And as he durst he drouȝ hym nere ⁊and nere
And herkened ay þe wordis ⁊and þe note
Tyll he the furst vers cowd al be roote
¶ Nat what þe laton was to sey
For he so yong ⁊and tendir was of age
But on a day his felow he gan prey
To expoun hym þis song in his langage
Or tell hym what þis song was to sey
This preyd he hem to constru ⁊and declare
Full offt tyme on his kneis bare
¶ His felaw wich was elder þen hee
Answerd hym thus this song I herd sey
Was made of our blesful lady fre
Hir to salow ⁊and eke hir to prey
To be our help ⁊and socour when wee dey
I can no more expoun in þis matere
I lern song I can but litil gramere
¶ And is this song made in þe reverence
Of Cristis modir seyd this Innocent
Now certis I woll do my dilligence
To con it or Cristemas be went
Thouȝ I from prymer shuld be shent
And to be beten in every houre
I woll it kon our lady to honoure
¶ His felaw tauȝt hym homward pⁱrively
Fro day to day till he coude it be rote
And þen he song it wele ⁊and boldely
Fro word to word according to þe note
Thries on a day it passid þurh his throte
To scoleward ⁊and homward when he went
On Cristis modir set was his Entent
¶ As I have seyd þurh out the Iewry
This child as he cam to ⁊and fro
Ful merely then wold he syng ⁊and cry
O Alma redemptoris mater evir mo
The swetnes hath his hert ꝑpersid so
Of Cristis modir þat to hir to prey
He can nat stynt of syngyng by þe wey
¶ Our first foo the serpent Satanas
That hath in Iuys his waspis nest
Vp swal ⁊and seyd o Ebrak pepill Allas
Is this a thing þat is to ȝew honest
That such a boy shall walk wher hym list
In our dispite ⁊and syng of such centence
That is a ȝenst our lawis reverence
¶ Fro thens forth the Iuys hath conspirid
This Innocent out of this world to chase
An homycyde ther to have þey hirid
That in an aley had a pryuy plase
And as the child gan forby pase
This cruell Iewe hym hent ⁊and held fast
And cut his throte ⁊and in a pit hym cast
¶ I sey in a wardrope they hym threw
Ther as the Iuys purgit hir entrayll
O cursid folk of herodis al new
What may yeur evil ȝew availl
Mordir woll out it is no faill
And namely there honour shuld sprede
The blood out cryith of yeur cursid dede
¶ O Alma sowned the virginite
Now maist thow syng flouryng evir in oon
The white lambe celestiall quod he
Of wich the grete Euᵃngelist seynt Iohn
In pathenos wrote wich seyn they þat goon
Be fore the lambe ⁊and syng a song al new
That nevir flesshly vomman they knew
¶ This pore wedow a waytith al that nyȝte
Aftir hir litill child but home comyth he nouȝte
For whom as sone as it was day liȝte
With fase pale for drede ⁊and besy þouȝt
She hath at Scole and els wher hym souȝt
Tyl fynally she gan for fere espy
That he was last seyn in the Iewry
¶ With modris pete in the brest enclosid
She goith as she were halff out of hir mynde
To every plase wher as she hath supposid
By lyklyhede hir Child to fynde
And evir on Cristis modir meke ⁊and kynde
She cried and atte last þus she wrouȝt
Among the cursid Iewis she hym souȝte
¶ She freynyth ⁊and preyith petously
To every Iew that dwellith in that plase
To tel hir yf hir child went by
They seyd nay but Ihu of his grace
Gaff in hir þouȝt with in a litill spase
That in that plase aftir hir sone she cried
Ther he was cast in a pit besyde
¶ Grete God þat ꝓprofourmyd is þy lawde
By mowth of Innocence lo her thy myȝte
This Gem of chastite this Emerawde
And eke of martirdom þe ruby bryȝte
Ther as he wᵗith throte corve lay vp ryȝte
He Alma redemptoris gan to syng
So lowd that al the plase gan rynge
¶ The cristen folk þat þurh þe strete went
In comyn for to wondir on this thyng
And hastily they for the prouost sent
He com a noon with out tarying
And herijth Criste that is hevyn kyng
And eke his Modir honoure of mankynde
And aftir that the Iewis lete he bynde
¶ This child with petouse lamentacioune
Vptakyng synging his song Anoon
And with honour and grete processioun
The cary hym to the next Abbey
His modir swownyng by the beer lay
Vnneth myȝt the pepill that was ther
This new rachell bryng fro the ber
¶ With turment ⁊and shameful deth echoon
This prouost doith these Iewis to sterve
That of his mordir wist ⁊and þat a noon
He nuld so such cursidnes observe
Evill shall he have that evill wol deserve
Therfor with wild horsis he did hem drawe
And aftir he hong hem by the lawe
¶ Oppon this beer lijth this Innocent
To fore the cheff Autir whils the mas last
And aftir that the Abbot wᵗith his covent
Sped hem to bury hym ful fast
And when the holy watir on hym cast
Ȝit spak the child when spryngit was the Watir
And sang O Alma redemptoris mater
¶ This Abbot wich that was an holy man
As monkis be or els ouȝt to be
This yong child conyour he be gan
And seye dere child I hals the
By vertu of the holy Trynyte
Tell me what is thy cause forto syng
Sithins thy throte is cut to my semeyng
¶ My throte is cut onto my nek boon
Seyd this child and as be wey of kynd
I shuld have long tyme agoon
But Ihu Crist as yee in bookis fynde
Wol that his glory last ⁊and be in mynde
And for the worshipp of his Modir dere
Ȝit may I syng O Alma lowd ⁊and clere
¶ This well of mercy Cristis modir swete
I lovid alwey as aftir my connyng
And when that I my lyff shuld lete
To me she cam ⁊and bad me for to syng
This Antym verely in my Dying
As yee have herd ⁊and when þat I have song
Me þouȝt she leyd agreyn vndir my tunge
Wherfor I syng ⁊and syng must certeyn
In honour of þat blesful mayden fre
Thus of my tung taken is the greyn
And aftir thus seid she onto me
My litill child then woll I fech the
When that the greyn is fro thy tung I take
Be nat a gast I woll the nat forsake
¶ This Monk this Abbot hym meen I
His tung out cauȝt ⁊and toke a wey þe greyn
Anoon he gaff vp the goost ful sofftly
And when the Abbot this wondir had seyn
His salt teris streken down as reyn
And gruff he fill al plat to þe ground
And stil he lay as he had be I bound
¶ The covent eke lay oppon the pament
Wepeing ⁊and herying cristis modir dere
And aftir that they rise ⁊and forth be went
And toke a wey this martir fro the bere
And in a tombe of marbil stonys clere
Enclosid they this litil body swete
Ther he is now God graunt vs for to mete
¶ Yong hewe of lyncoln scleyn also
With cursid Iuys as it is notabill
For it is but alitill while ago
Prey eke for vs synful folk vnstabill
That of his mercy God so mercyabill
On vs his grete mercy multyply
For the reverence of his modir mary Amen
Here endith the Pryores hir tale
(base) ¶ Here bigynneth the Phisiciens tale
(base) THer was as telleth Titus Liuius
(base) A knyght that called was Virginius
(base) Fulfild of honour and of worthynesse
(base) And strong of freendes and of greet richesse
(base) ¶ This knyght a doghter hadde by his wif
(base) No children hadde he mo in al his lif
(base) Fair was this mayde in excellent beautee
(base) Abouen euery wight that man may see
(base) For Nature hath with souereyn diligence
(base) Yformed hire in so greet excellence
(base) As thogh she wolde seyn lo I nature
(base) Thus kan I forme and peynte a creature
(base) Whan that me list who kan me countrefete
(base) Pigmalion noght thogh he ay forge and bete
(base) Or graue or peynte for I dar wel seyn
(base) Apelles zanzis sholde werche in veyn
(base) Outher to graue or peynte or forge or bete

div.l: (base) If they presumeden me to countrefete
(base) For he that is the formere principal
(base) Hath maked me his vicaire general
(base) To forme and peynten erthely creaturis
(base) Right as me list and ech thyng in my cure is
(base) Vnder the Moone that may wane and waxe
(base) And for my werk right no thyng wol I axe
(base) My lord and I been ful of oon acord
(base) I made hire to the worship of my lord
(base) So do I alle myne othere creatures
(base) What colour that they han or what figures
(base) Thus semeth me that nature wolde seye
(base) This mayde of age twelue yeer was and tweye
(base) In which that nature hadde swich delit
(base) For right as she kan peynte a lilye whit
(base) And reed a Rose right with swich peynture
(base) She peynted hath this noble creature
(base) Er she were born vpon hir lymes free
(base) Wher as by right swiche colours sholden be
(base) And Phebus dyed hath hir tresses grete
(base) Lyk to the stremys of his burned hete
(base) And if that excellent was hir beautee
(base) A thousand fold moore vertuous was she
(base) In hire ne lakked no condicioun
(base) That is to preyse as by discrecioun
(base) As wel in goost as body chaast was she
(base) For which she floured in virginitee
(base) With all humilitee and abstinence
(base) With all atemperance and pacience
(base) With mesure eek of beryng and array
(base) Discreet she was in answeryng alway
(base) Thogh she were wise Pallas dar I seyn
(base) Hir facound eek ful wommanly and pleyn
(base) No countrefeted termes hadde she
(base) To seme wys but after hir degree
(base) She spak and alle hir wordes moore and lesse
(base) Sownynge in vertu and in gentilesse
(base) Shamefast she was in maydens shamefastnesse
(base) Constant in herte and euere in bisynesse
(base) To dryue hire out of ydel slogardye
(base) Bacus hadde of hir mouth right no maistrye
(base) For wyn and youthe dooth Venus encreesse
(base) As men in fyr wol casten oille or gresse
(base) And of hir owene vertu vnconstreyned
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) She hath ful ofte tyme syk hir feyned
(base) For that she wolde fleen the compaignye
(base) Where likly was to treten of folye
(base) As is at festes reuels and at daunces
(base) That been occasions of daliaunces
(base) Swich thyng maken children for to be
(base) To soone rype and boold as men may se
(base) Which is ful perilous and hath be yoore
(base) For al to soone may they lerne loore
(base) Which afterward may greve þeim sore
(base) Of boldnesse whan she woxen is a wyf
(base) ¶ And ye Maistresses in youre olde lyf
(base) That lordes doghtres han in gouernance
(base) Ne taketh of my wordes no displesance
(base) Thenketh that ye been set in gouernynges
(base) Of lordes doghtres oonly for two thynges
(base) ¶ Owther for ye han kept youre honestee
(base) Or ellis ye han falle in freletee
(base) And knowen wel ynow the olde daunce
(base) And han forsaken fully swich meschaunce
(base) For euere mo therfore for Cristes sake
(base) To teche hem vertu looke that ye ne slake
(base) Kepeþ wel þo þat ȝe vndertake
(base) ¶ A theef of venyson that hath forlaft
(base) His likerousnesse and al his olde craft
(base) Kan kepe a Forest best of any man
(base) Now kepeth wel for if ye wole ye kan
(base) Looke wel that ye vnto no vice assente
(base) Lest ye be dampned for youre wikke entente
(base) For who so dooth a traytour is certeyn
(base) And taketh kepe of that that I shal seyn
(base) Of alle tresoun souerayn pestilence
(base) Is whan a wight bitrayseth Innocence
(base) ¶ Ye fadres and ye modres eek also
(base) Thogh ye han children be it oon or mo
(base) Youre is the charge of al hir surueaunce
(base) Whil that they been vnder youre gouernaunce
(base) Beth war if by ensample of youre lyuynge
(base) Or by youre necligence in chastisynge
(base) That they perisse for I dar wel seye
(base) If that they doon ye shul it deere abeye
(base) Vnder a Shepherde softe and necligent
(base) The wolf hath many a sheep and lomb to rent
(base) Suffiseth oon ensample now as heere
(base) For I moot turne agayn to my matere
(base) ¶ This mayde of which I wol this tale expresse
(base) So kepte hir self hir neded no maistresse
(base) For in hir lyuyng maydens myghten rede
(base) As in a book euery good word or dede

div.l: (base) That longeth to a mayden vertuous
(base) She was so prudent and so bounteuous
(base) For which the fame out sproong on euery syde
(base) Bothe of hir beautee and hir bountee wyde
(base) That thurgh that land they preysed hire echone
(base) That loued vertu saue enuye allone
(base) That sory is of oother mennes wele
(base) And glad is of his sorwe and his vnheele
(base) The doctor maketh this discripcioun
(base) This mayde vpon a day wente in the toun
(base) Toward a temple with hir moder deere
(base) As is of yonge maydens the manere
(base) ¶ Now was ther thanne a Iustice in that toun
(base) That gouernour was of that Regioun
(base) And so bifel this Iuge hise eyen caste
(base) Vpon this mayde auysynge hym ful faste
(base) As she cam forby ther as this Iuge stood
(base) Anoon his herte chaunged and his mood
(base) So was he caught with beautee of this mayde
(base) And to hymself ful pryuely he sayde
(base) This mayde shal by myn for any man
(base) Anon the feend in to his herte ran
(base) And taughte hym sodeynly that he by slyghte
(base) This mayden to his purpos wynne myghte
(base) For certes by no force ne by no meede
(base) Hym thoughte he was nat able for to speede
(base) For she was strong of freendes and eek she
(base) Confermed was in swich souerayn bountee
(base) That wel he wiste he myghte hir neuere wynne
(base) As for to make hire with hir body synne
(base) For which by greet deliberacioun
(base) He sente after a cherl was in the town
(base) Which that he knew for subtil and for bold
(base) This Iuge vnto this cherl his tale hath told
(base) In secree wise and made hym to ensure
(base) He sholde telle it to no creature
(base) And if he dide he sholde lese his heed
(base) Whan that assented was this cursed reed
(base) Glad was this Iuge and maked hym gret cheere
(base) And yaf hym yiftes preciouse and deere
(base) ¶ Whan shapen was al hir conspiracie
(base) Fro point to point how that his lecherie

div.l: (base) Parfourned sholde been ful subtilly
(base) As ye shul heere it after openly
(base) ¶ Hom goth the cherl that highte Claudius
(base) This false Iuge that highte Apius
(base) So was his name for this is no fable
(base) But knowen for historial thyng notable
(base) The sentence of it sooth is out of doute
(base) This false Iuge gooth now faste aboute
(base) To hasten his delit al that he may
(base) And so bifel soone after on a day
(base) This false Iuge as telleth vs the storie
(base) As we fine writen in olde storie
(base) As he was wont sat in his Consistorie
(base) And yaf his domes vpon sondry cas
(base) ¶ This false cherl cam forth a ful gret pas
(base) And seyde lord if that it be youre wille
(base) As dooth me right vpon this pitous bille
(base) In which I pleyne vpon Virginius
(base) And if that he wol seyn it is nat thus
(base) I wol it preue and fynde good witnesse
(base) That sooth is that my bille wol expresse
(base) ¶ This Iuge answerde of this in his absence
(base) I may nat yeue diffynytif sentence
(base) Lat do hym calle and I wol gladly heere
(base) Thow shalt haue al right and no wrong heere
(base) ¶ Virginius cam to wite the Iuges wille
(base) And right anon was rad this cursed bille
(base) The sentence of it was as ye shul heere
(base) ¶ To yow my lord sire Apius so deere
(base) Sheweth youre poure seruant Claudius
(base) How that a knyght called Virginius
(base) Agayns the lawe agayn al equitee
(base) Holdeth expres agayn the wyl of me
(base) My seruant which that is my thral by right
(base) Which fro myn hous was stole vpon a nyght
(base) Whil that she was ful yong this wol I preue
(base) By witnesse lord so that it nat yow greue
(base) She nys his doghter nat what so he seye
(base) Wher to yow my lord the Iuge I preye
(base) Yeld me my thral if that it be youre wille
(base) Lo this was al the sentence of his bille
(base) ¶ Virginius gan vpon the cherl biholde
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) But hastily er he his tale tolde
(base) And wolde haue proued it as sholde a knyght
(base) And eek by witnessynge of many a wight
(base) That it was fals that seyde his Aduersarie
(base) This cursed Iuge wolde no thyng tarie
(base) Ne here a word moore of Virginius
(base) But yaf his Iuggement and seyde thus
(base) ¶ I deme anon this cherl his seruant haue
(base) Thou shalt no lenger in thyn hous hir saue
(base) Go bryng hir forth and put hire in oure warde
(base) The cherl shal han his thral this I awarde
(base) ¶ And whan this worthy knyght Virginius
(base) Thurgh sentence of this Iustice Apius
(base) Moste by force his deere doghter yeuen
(base) Vnto the Iuge in lecherie to lyuen
(base) He goth hym hom and sette hym in his halle
(base) And leet anoon his deere doghter calle
(base) And with a face deed as asshen colde
(base) Vpon hir humble face he gan biholde
(base) With fadres pitee stikyng thurgh his herte
(base) Al wolde he from his purpos nat conuerte
(base) ¶ Doghter quod he Virginia by thy name
(base) Ther been two weyes outher deeth or shame
(base) That thow most suffre allas that I was bore
(base) For neuere thow deseruedest wherfore
(base) To dyen with a swerd or with a knyf
(base) O deere doghter endere of my lyf
(base) Which I haue fostred vp with swich plesance
(base) That thow were neuere out of my remembrance
(base) O doghter which that art my laste wo
(base) And in my lyf my laste ioye also
(base) O gemme of chastitee in pacience
(base) Tak thow thy deeth for this is my sentence
(base) For loue and nat for hate thow most be deed
(base) My pitous hand moot smyten of thyn heed
(base) Allas that euere Apius thee say
(base) Thus hath he falsly Iugged thee to day
(base) Is there no grace is there no remedie cat
(base) And tolde hire al the cas as ye bifore
(base) Han herd nat nedeth for to telle it moore
(base) ¶ O mercy deere fader quod this mayde
(base) And with that word she bothe hir armes layde
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Aboute his nekke as she was wont to do
(base) The teeris borste out of hir eyen two
(base) And seyde goode fader shal I dye
(base) Is ther no grace is ther no remedye
(base) ¶ No certes deere doghter myn quod he
(base) ¶ Thanne yif me leyser fader myn quod she
(base) My deeth for to compleyne a litel space
(base) For pardee Iepte yaf his doghter grace
(base) For to compleyne er he hir slowe allas
(base) And god it woot no thyng was hir trespas
(base) But for she ran hir fader for to se
(base) To wel come hym with greet solempnytee
(base) And with that word she fil aswowne anon
(base) And after whan hir swownyng is agon
(base) She riseth vp and to hir fader sayde
(base) Blessed be god that I shal dye a mayde
(base) Yif me my deeth er that I haue a shame
(base) Dooth with youre child youre wyl a goddes name
(base) And with that word she preyed hym ful ofte
(base) That with his swerd he wolde smyte softe
(base) And with that word aswowne doun she fil
(base) ¶ Hir fader with ful sorweful herte and wil
(base) Hir heed of smoot and by the top it hente
(base) And to the Iuge he gan it to presente
(base) As he sat yet in doom in Consistorie
(base) ¶ And whan the Iuge it saw as seith the storie
(base) He bad to take hym and anhange hym faste
(base) But right anon a thousand peple In thraste
(base) To saue the knyght for routhe and for pitee
(base) For knowen was the false Iniquitee
(base) ¶ The peple anon hadde suspect in this thyng
(base) By manere of the cherles chalangyng
(base) That it was by the assent of Apius
(base) They wisten wel that he was lecherus
(base) For which vnto this Apius they gon
(base) And caste hym in a prison right anon
(base) Ther as he slow hymself and Claudius
(base) That seruant was vnto this Apius
(base) Was demed for to hange vpon a tree
(base) But that Virginius of his pitee
(base) So preyde for hym that he was exiled

div.l: (base) And ellis certes he hadde been bigyled
(base) The remenant were anhanged moore and lesse
(base) That were consentant of this cursednesse
(base) ¶ Heere may men seen how synne hath his merite
(base) Beth war for no man woot whom god wol smyte
(base) In no degree ne in which manere wise
(base) The worm of conscience may agrise
(base) Of wikked lyf thogh it so pryuee be
(base) That no man woot ther of but god and he
(base) For be he lewed man or ellis lered
(base) He noot how soone that he shal been afered
(base) Therfore I rede yow this conseil take
(base) Forsaketh synne er synne yow forsake
(base) ¶ Here endeth the Phisiciens tale
And here begynnyth the Shipman his tale ~
A Marchant whilom dwellid at Seynt Denys
That rich was for wich held hym wise
A wyff he had of excellent bewte
And compenabill and revelouse was she
Wich is a thing that causith more dispence
Then worth al the chere and reverence
That men hem doon at Festis ⁊and at dauncis
Such salutaciouns and contenauncis
Passen as doon a shadowe on a wall
But woo is hym that pay must for all
The sely husbonde algate he must pay
He must vs cloith he must vs aray
Al for own worshipp Richely
In wich aray wee daunce Iolely
And yf þat he may nat ꝓproaventure
Or els list no such expence endure
But thinkith it I wastid ⁊and I lost
Then must a nothir pay for our cost
Or leen vs gold and that is ꝑparlous
This nobill Marchaunt held a worthy house
For wich he had al day so grete repeyr
For his larges ⁊and for his wyff was so feir
That wondir is but herkenyth to my tale
Among all his gestis grete ⁊and smale
Ther was a monk a feir man ⁊and a bold
I trowe xxx wyntir he was old
That evir in oon was dwelling in that plase
This yong monk that was dwellyng in þat plase
Aqueynteid was so with the good man
Sith he the first knowlech be gan
That in his house as famuler was he
As it is possibil eny frend to be
And for as much as the good man
And eke this monke of wich I be gan
Were both to born in oon village
The monk hym cleymyth hym cleymyth as for cosonage
And he a geyn ne seith nat onys nay
But was as glad ther of as foule of day
For to his hert it was a grete plesaunce
Thus been they knet wᵗith etern lyaunce
And ech of hem gan othir to assure
Of britherhede whils hir lyff myȝt endure
Fre was dane Iohn ⁊and namely of dispence
And in that house as ful of diligence
To do plesaunce and also grete costage
He nat for gate to gyve the lest page
In al that house but aftir hir degre
He gaff the lord and aftir al his meyne
What that he com som maner honest thing
For wich they were as glad of his comyng
As foule is feyn when that þe son vp risith
No more of this as now for it suffisith
But so fill this marchuant on a day
Shope hym to make redy his aray
Toward the town of briggis for to fare
To by there a porcioune of ware
For wich he hath to parise sent a noon
A messengere ⁊and preyd hath dane Iohn
That he shuld com to Seynt Denys ⁊and pley
With hym ⁊and his wyff a day or twey
Or he to briggis went in al wise
This nobill monk of wich I ȝewe devise
Hath of his Abbot as hym list licence
Be cause he was a man of hiȝe prudence
And eke an officere out forto ryde
To se hir graungis ⁊and hir bernys wyde
And to Seynt Denys he comyth a noon
Who was so welcom as my lord dane Iohn
Our dere cosyn ful of curtesy
With hym he brouȝt a Iob of malmesy
And eke a nothir of fyne vernage
And vitaill as ay was his vsage
And thus I lete hem drynk ⁊and pley
This marchant ⁊and þis Monk a day or twey
The þird day this marchaunt vp risith
And on his nedis sadly hym a visith
And vp to his countir house goith he
To reken with hym selff wel may be
Of that yeer how wᵗith hym it stode
And how he dispendit had his good
And yff that he encresid were or noon
His bokis ⁊and his baggis many oon
He leyith to fore hym on his countyng bord
Ful rich was his tresour ⁊and his hord
For wich ful fast his countir dor he shitt
And eke he wold þat no man shuld hym let
Of his acountis for the meen tyme
And thus he sat still til it was pryme
Dane Iohn was rysen in the morowe
And in the garden walkith to ⁊and fro
And hath his thingis seyd ful curteysly
The good wyff cam walkyng pryuyly
Into the garden ther he walkid sofft
And hym folowith as she hath doon offt
A mayde child comyth in hir company
Wich as she list she may govern ⁊and guy
For ȝit vndir þe ȝerd was the mayd
O dere cosyn Dane Iohn she seyd
What eylith ȝewe so rath to rise
Nece quod he it ouȝt I nowȝ suffice
Fyve owris to sclepe oppon a nyȝt
But it were for a pallid old white
As been þese old weddit men þat lien ⁊and dare
As in a fourm sittith a wery hare
Wer al for strauȝt wᵗith houndis grete ⁊and smale
But dere Nece why by yee so pale
I trow certis that our good man
Hath ȝew labourid sith the nyȝt be gan
That yee had nede to rest hastely
And with that word he louȝe ful meryly
And of his own þouȝt he wex al rede
This feir wyff gan to shake hir hede
And seyd thus ȝe God woot al quod she
Nay cosyn myne it stont nat so wᵗith me
Wherfor I think out of this lond to wend
Or els of my selff to make an ende
So ful I am of drede and eke of care
This monk be gan oppon this wyff to stare
And seyd allas my nece God for bede
That yee for eny sorow or drede
For do your selff but tel me yeur greff
ꝑparaventure I may in yeur myscheff
Counsel or help ⁊and therfor tell me
Al yeur anoy for it shal be secre
For on my portose I make an othe
That nevir in my lyff for leff ne loth
Ne shal I ȝew of no counsell be wrey
The same quod she I to ȝew sey
Be God ⁊and oppon this portose I swere
Thouȝe men me wold al to pecis tere
Ne shal I nevir for to go to hell
Be wry a word of þing þat ye me tell
Ne for no cosinage ne for noon Aliaunce
But verely for love ⁊and Affiaunce
Thus been they sworn ⁊and here oppon they kist
And ech of hem told othir what hem list
Cosyn quod she yf þat I had a space
As I have noon ⁊and namely in this place
Then wold I tell a legend ⁊and a lyff
What I have suffrid sithins I was a wyff
With my cosyn al be he yeur cosyn
Nay quod þis monk be God ⁊and by seynt Austyn
He is no more cosyn on to me
Then is the leff that hangith on the tre
I clepe hym so be Seynt Denys of Frᵃunce
To have the more cause of aqueyntise
Of ȝew wich I have lovid specially
A bove al vomen sikirly
This swere I to ȝewe on my ꝓprofessioun
Tellith yeur greff lest he comyth down
And hast ȝew ⁊and go a wey a noon
My dere love quod she Dane Iohn
Ful leff were me this counsell for to hide
But out it mut It may no more be hid
My husbond is to me the worst man
That evir was sith the world be gan
But sith I am a wyff it sittith nat me
To tell no white of our pryuyte
Nethir a bedd ne in noon othir plase
God sheld I shuld do so for his grace
A wyff ne shal sey of hir husbonde
But all honour as I vndirstonde
Saff on to ȝew thus much I tell shall
As help me God he is nat worth at all
In no degre in valow if a fly
But ȝit me grevith most his nygardry
And wele yee woot þat vomen naturelly
Desire such thingis as wele as I
They wold that hir husbondis shuld be
Hardy ⁊and wise ⁊and rich ⁊and of hert fre
And buxom to his wyff ⁊and fressh a bed
But by þat lord þat for vs bled
For his honour ⁊and my selff to aray
On sonday next I must nedis pay
An hundrit Franks or I am lorn
Ȝit were me levir þat I were vnborn
Then me were doon sclaundir or vilany
And eke yf my husbond myȝt espy
I were but lost and therfor I ȝew prey
For atta certen day I wol ȝew pay
And do to ȝew what plesaunce ⁊and servise
That I may do ryȝt as yee wol devise
And but I do God take on me vengaunce
As foule as evir had Genylioun of Frᵃunce
This gentil monk answerd in this manere
Now trewly myne own nece dere
I have on ȝew quod he so grete rowith
That here I swere ⁊and pliȝt ȝew my trowith
That when yeur husbond is to Flaundris fare
I woll delyvir ȝew out of this care
For I woll bryng ȝew an hundrit Frankis
And with that woord he cauȝt hir by þe Flankis
And hir enbrasid hard ⁊and kissid hir offt
Go now yeur wey quod he al still ⁊and sofft
And let vs dyne as sone as evir wee may
For by my chalengir it is pryme of the day
Go now ⁊and be trew as I shall bee
Now els God for bede sir quod she
And forth she goith as Ioly as a py
And bad the Cokis that þey shuld hem hiȝe
So that men myȝte dyne a noon
Vp to hir husbond is the wyff goon
And knokkith at his countir dorr boldely
Who is ther quod he petir it is I
Quod she what sir how long woll yee fast
How long tyme wol yee rekyn ⁊and cast
Yeur somys ⁊and yeur bokis ⁊and yeur thing is
The devill have part of such rekenyngis
Yee have I now parde of Goddis sond
Com down to day ⁊and let yeur baggis stond
Sir be yee nat a shamyd that dane Iohn
Shal fasting al this day elyng goon
Let vs here mas ⁊and go to dyne
Wyff quod this man ye can litil devyne
The corious besines that wee have
For of vs chapmen al so God me save
And by that lord that clepid is Seynt Ive
Scarsly a mong xij . too þer thryve
Contenuelly lasting on to our age
Wee may wele make chere ⁊and good visage
And dryve forth the world as it may be
And kepe our estate in pryuyte
Tyll wee be dede and els þat wee prey
A pilgremage or goon by the wey
And ther of have I grete necessite
Oppon this queynt world to a vise me
For evirmore wee must stond in drede
Of hap of fortune and of our chapmanhede
To morow to Flaundris wol I go or day
And com ageyn as sone as evir I may
For wich dere wyff I ȝew be seke
As to eủery white be buxom ⁊and meke
And for to kepe our good be coriouse
And honestly govern wele our house
Thow hast I nowȝ in eủery maner wise
Thatto a thryffty houshold shuld suffise
The lakkith noon aray ne noon vitaill
Of silvir in yer purs shall yee nat faill
And with that word the countir dorr he shit
And down he goith he wold no lenger let
But hastly a mes was ther I seyde
And sikirly the tablis were I leyde
And to the dyner fast they hem sped
And richely this chapman þis monk fed
And aftir dyner dane Iohn sikirly
This chapman toke a part pryuely
And seyd hym thus cosyn it stondith so
That wele I see to briggis woll ye go
God ⁊and Seynt Austyn spede ȝew ⁊and guyde
I preye ȝew cosyn wisely þat yee ryde
Govern ȝew also in yeur diete
And temꝑparaly ⁊and namely in this hete
Be twix vs to nedith no straunge fare
Fare wele cosyn God sheld ȝew fro care
And yf that eny thing be day or nyȝte
That yee me woll comaund on eny wise
It shal be do ryȝt as yee woll devise
O thing or þat yee go yf it may be
I wold prey ȝew for to leen me
An C Frankis for a wook or twey
For certen bestis þat I must bey
To store wᵗith a plase þat is ours
As wold to God þat it were yeurs
I shall nat faill suerly at my day
Nat for a Mˢ Frankis a myle wey
But lete this thing be secre I ȝewe prey
For ȝit this nyȝt these bestis must I be
And now fare wele myne own cosyn dere
Gromercy of yeur cost ⁊and of yeur chere
This nobill marchaunt gentilly anoon
Answerd ⁊and seyd o cosyn myne dane Iohn
Now sikirly this is a smal request
My gold is yeurs when þat ye lest
And nat oonly my gold but my chaffare
Take what yee list God sheld þat yee spare
But o thing yee knowe wele I nowȝe
Of chapmen that mony is hir plouȝe
Wee may creaunce whils wee have a name
But goldles for to be it is a shame
Pay it ageyn when it likith ȝew at yeʳ ese
Aftir my myȝt feyn I wold ȝew plese
These hundrit Frankis he fechith forth a noon
And pryuely he toke it to dane Iohn
No white in the londe wist of his loon
Saveing this marchant ⁊and dane Iohn aloon
They drynke ⁊and speke and Room a while ⁊and pley
Tyl that Dane Iohn ridith to his abbey
The morow cam ⁊and forth this marchant ridith
To Flaundris ward his prentise wele hym guydith
Tyll he com to briggis merely
Now goith this marchant fast ⁊and besyly
Aboute his nede ⁊and bijth and creaunsith
He nethir pleyith at dise ne daunsith
But as a marchant shortly to tell
He ledith his lyff ⁊and there I lete hym dwell
The sonday next this marchant was a goon
To Seynt Denys I comyn is dane Iohn
With crown ⁊and berd as fressh ⁊and new shave
In al the house þer is noon so litill a knave
Ne no white els þat was so feyn
That my lord dane Iohn was comyn ageyn
And shortly to the poynt to goon
This feir wyff accordith wᵗith dane Iohn
That for his hundrit Frankis he shuld alnyȝt
Have hir in his armys bolt vp riȝte
And this accord ꝑparfourmyd was in dede
In myrth al nyȝte a besy lyff þey lede
Tyll yt was day ⁊and dane Iohn went his way
And bad the meyne fare wele ⁊and have good day
For noon of hem ne no white in the town
Hath of dane Iohn noon suspecioune
And forth he ridith home to his Abbey
Or wher hym list no more of hym I sey
This marchant was endit was the feyr
To Seynt Denys he gan to repeir
And wᵗith his wyff he makith feest ⁊and chere
And tellith hir that chaffare is so dere
That nedis must he make a chefesaunce
For he was bound in a reconisaunce
For to pay xxx Mˢ Sheldis a noon
For wich this Marchant on to paris is goon
To borow of certen Frendis þat he had
A som of Frankis ⁊and som wᵗith hym he lad
And when he was com in to the town
For grete chere and affeccioune
To dane Iohn he first goith to play
Nat for to axe ne for to borow money
But for to wete ⁊and se his welfare
And for to tel hym of his chaffare
As Frendis doon when they been in fere
Dane Iohn makith hym Fest ⁊and mery chere
And he hym told a geyn ful specially
How he had wele I bouȝt ⁊and graciously
Thankid be God of al his marchandise
Save þat he must in al mane wise
Maken a chefesaunce as for the best

div.ab: Here begynnyth Chawcere his tale of Mellebe ⁊and Prudence

A yong man callid Mellebeus the wich was
myȝty and riche begate oppon his wyffe þat
callid was Prudence a douȝtir that callid
Sophie .

And oppon a tyme it fill that for his
disporte he went in to the feld to pley ⁊and to solase

⁊and toke wᵗith
hym his wyffe .

And lefft his douȝtir at home ⁊and shit fast
the dorris .

Thre of his old enmyes have goten laddrys on
to the wallys of his house and by the wyndowis been
entryd

and bete his douȝtir ⁊and woundit hir wᵗith v mortal
woundis .

That is to sey in hir feet in hir hondis in hir
nose in hir mowith and in hir eeris ⁊and lefft hir for ded and
went hir wey

¶ When Melbeus retournyd was to his
house and saw al this myscheff he like a mad man gan to
rent his clothis ⁊and gan to wepe and cry

¶ Prudence his wyf
as ferforth as she durst be souȝt hym of his wepeing for
to stynt
But for al that he bansshed ⁊and cryed more ⁊and more

This nobill wyffe Prudence remembrith hir of the centēnce
of Ovide in his book that clepid is remedy of love wher ~
he seith

¶ He is a Fole that distrobelith the modir to wepe þe
deth of hir child tyll she hath wept hir fill as for a certen
term //

And then shall a man do his diligence wᵗith amyabil
woordis hir to recomfort ⁊and prey hir of hir wepeing to
stynt .

Be wich reson this nobill wyff Prudence sofferid
hir husbonde to wepe ⁊and to cry for a certen tyme

¶ And when
she saw hir tyme . She seyd to hym in this wise . Allas
my lord why make yee yeur selff like a fool .

Forsoth it
ꝑperteynyth nat to a wise man to make such sorow

¶ Yeur
douȝtir þurh the grace of God shall warissh ⁊and escape

And
all weer it so that ryȝte nowe she were dede yee ne
ouȝt yeur selff for hir deth so to trobill .

Senek seith
The wyse man shuld take no grete discomforte for the
deth of his Childryn

but certis he shuld suffir it in paci-
ence as wele as abydith the deth of his own ꝑpersone

¶ This

ab.hi: Here endith the tale of Chawcere

div.l: And here begynnyth the Monk this Prologg ~
When endit was the tale of Mellebe
And of Prudence and hir benignite
Our hoost seyd as I am feithfull man
And by the precious corpus madrian
I had levir then a barell of ale
That good leff my wyff had herd þis tale
For she nys no thyng of such pacience
As was Mellebeus wyff Prudence
Be Goddis bonys when I bete my knavis
She bryngith me the grete clobbit stavis
And crijth sclee the doggis everichon
And breke both bakk and eke boon
And yff þat eny Neyȝbour of myne
Woll nat in chirch to my wyff enclyne
Or be so hardy to hir to trespace
When she comyth home she raumpith in my fase
And crijth fals coward wreke thy wyffe
By goddis bonys I woll have thy knyff
And thow thow shalt have my distaff ⁊and go spyn
Fro day til nyȝt riȝt thus she wol be gyn
Allas she seith that evir I was shape
To wedd a mylk sopp or a coward ape
That woll be ovir ledd with eủery white
Thow darst nat stond by thy wyvis riȝte
This is my lyff but I woll fiȝte
And ouȝte atte . a noon I mut me diȝte
And els I am but lost but yff that I
Be leke a wild lyoune fole hardy
I woot wele she wol do me sclee som day
Som Neyȝbour and þen go my wey
For I am perlous with knyff in honde
Al be it that I dare nat hir withstonde
For she is bigg in armys be my feith
That shall he Fynde that hir mys seith
But lete vs pas ovir this matere
My lord ʆsir Monk he seid be mery of cher
For yee shall tell a tale trewly
Lo Rowchestir stondith here fast by
Ryde forth myne own lorde brekith nat yeʳ game
But be my trowith I know nat yeur name
Whethir shall I call ȝew dane Iohn
Or dane Thomas or dane Albone
Of what house be yee by yeur Fadir kyn
I vowe to God yee have a ful feir skyn
It is a gentill pasture ther þow goist
Thow art nat like a penaunte or a goost
Oppon my feith thow art som officere
Som worthy Sexten or som selerere
For by my Fadir soule as to my dome
Thow art a mastir when thow art at home
No pore Cloystrer ne noon pore Novice
But a governour wyly and wise
And ther wᵗith all of brawnys ⁊and of bonys
A wele feir persone for the nonys
I prey to God gyve hym confusioune
That first the brouȝte in to Relygioune
Thow woldist a been a treedfoule a riȝte
Haddist thow as grete leve as þow hast myȝte
To perfourm al thy lust in engendrure
Thow haddist be goten many a creature
Allas why werist þowe so wyde a cope
God gyff me sorow and I were Pope
Nat oonly thow but every myȝty man
Thouȝe he were shore hihe oppon the panne
Shuld have a wyff for al this world is lorn
Relygioune hath take vp al the corn
Of tredyng and wee borell men be shrympis
Off febill treis comyth febull ympis
This makith our Children to be so sclendir
And febill that they may nat engendir
This makith that our wyvis woll assay
Religious folk for they may bettir pay
Of venus paymentis þen mow wee
God woot no lusshburns pay yee
But be nat wroth my lord þouȝ I pley
Ful offt in game a soth I have herd sey
This worthy monke toke al in pacience
And seyd I woll do al my diligence
As ferr as semyth in to my honeste
To tell ȝew a tale or too or thre
And yff thow list herkyn hidirward
I woll ȝew sey the lyff of Seynt Edward
Or els tregedies first woll I tell

Me met how that I romyd vp ⁊and down
Wᵗith in our ȝerd wher as I saw a beest
Was like an hounde ⁊and wold have made a reest
Oppon my body ⁊and wold have had me dede
His coloure was be twixe ȝelow ⁊and rede
And tippid was his tayll ⁊and both his eris
Wᵗith blak vnlike the remnaunte of his heris
His snowte was smal wᵗith glowyng eyen twey
That for his look ȝit almost I dey
This cawsid me my gronyng doutlese
A wey quod she fy on ȝew hertlese
Allas quod she for by þat God a bove
Now have I lost my hert ⁊and al my love
I can nat love a coward be my feith
For certis what so evir eny man seith
Wee all desiryn yff it myȝt be
To have an husbonde hardy wise ⁊and fre
And secrete ⁊and no nygard ne no scold
Ne he that is a gast of every thing told
Of noon aventur by þat God a bove
How durst yee for shame sey to yeur love
That eny thing myȝt make ȝew a ferd
Have nat yee a mannys hert ⁊and have a berd
Allas can yee be a ferd of swevyns
Swevyns been engendrit of replexions
And of fleem and of complexions
When humours been to habundaunt in a white
Certis this dreme wich I have met to nyȝte
Comyth of grete superfluyte
Of yeur rede coleryk parde
Wich causith folk to drede in hir dremys
Of Arowis ⁊and of feir with rede lemys
Of rede bestis that they woll hem bite
Of Contek ⁊and of waspis grete ⁊and lyte
Riȝte as the humour of malyncoly
Cawsith many a man in his sclepe to cry
For feer of blak beris ⁊and bollis blake
Or ellis blak devillis woll hem take
Of othir humours cowd I tell also
That workyn man in his sclepe much woo
But I woll pas as liȝtly as I can
Lo Caton wich that is so wise a man
Seyd he nat thus do no force of dremys
Now sir quod she when wee flee fro þe bemys
For goddis love takith som laxatyff
Opperell of my soule ⁊and of my lyff
I counsell ȝew the best I wol nat ly
That both of Color and malyncoly
Yee purge ȝew ⁊and for yee shal nat tary
Thouȝe in this town be noon Appoticary
I shall my selff too herbis tech ȝew
That shall be for yeur ese ⁊and for yeʳ prow
And in yeur ȝerd tho herbis shall I fynde
The wich hath hir properte by kynde
To purge ȝew be neth ⁊and eke a bove
Sir for gete nat this for goddis love
Yee be ful colerik of complexioun
Ware the sone in his ascencioun
Ne fynde ȝew nat replete of humʳs hote
And yf it do I woll ley a grote
That yee shall have a fevir terciane
Or an Agew wich may be yeur bane
A day or too yee shall have degestiuis
Of wormys or yee take yeur laxatiuis
Of lawriall Centory or femetory
Or els of glebor þat growith ther
Of Catepuse or thew thorn berijs
Or eve growing in yeur gardin þᵗat mery is
Pik hem as they grow ⁊and ete hem in
Be mery husbond by yeur fadir kyn
Dredith of no dreme I can sey no more
Madame quod he gromercy for my lore
But nethirles as tellith dane Caton
That hath of wisdom such a grete nown
Thouȝe that he bad no dremys for to drede
Be God men mowe in old bookis rede
Of many a man more of Autorite
Then evir Caton was also mut I the
That al the revers seyn of this centence
And have wele founden by experience
That dremys been significaciouns
As wele of Ioy as of tribulaciouns
That folk endure in this lyff psent
Ther nedith of this to make noon Argument
The verry preff shewith it in dede
Of the grettest Auctor þat men rede
Seith thus whilom too felawis went
On pilgremage in ful good entent
And happid so they com in a town
Wher as ther was such a congregacioune
Of pepill and eke so streyte herbegage
That they ne founde as much as a cotage
In the wich they myȝt loggit be
Therfor they must of necessite
As for that nyȝte depart company
And eche of hem goith to his hostry
And toke his logging as it wold fall
The toon of hem was loggit in an oxis stall
Ferr in a ȝerd wher oxin went to plouȝe
The todir man was loggit wele I nowȝ
As was his Aventure ⁊and his fortune
That vs governyth as in Comune
And so be fill that long or it were day
This man met in his bedd ther he lay
How that his felow gan oppon hym call
And seyd Allas for in a oxis stall
This nyȝt I shall be mordrid ther I ly
Now help me dere brothir or I dy
In al hast com to me he seyd
This man out of his sclepe a breyde
But when that he was wakid of his sclepe
He turnyd hym ⁊and toke of this no kepe
Hym þouȝt his dreme was but in vanyte
Thus twyis in his sclepe dremyd he
And atte ȝirdtyme ȝit his felaw
Cam as he þouȝt ⁊and seyd I am sclaw
Be hold my blody woundis depe ⁊and wyde
Arise vp erly in the morow tyde
And atte west gate of the town quod he
A Cartfull of dung ther shalt þow see
In the wich my body is hid ful pryvely
Go to that cart ⁊and rest it boldely
My gold causid my mordir soth to seyn
And told hym every poynt how he was scleyn
With a petouse fase pale of hew
And trust wele his dreme he fond trewe
For on the morow as sone as it was day
To his felawis In he toke the way
And when he cam to the Oxis stall
Aftyrr his felaw he gan to call
The hostelere answerd hym a noon
And seyd sir ȝeur felaw is goon
As sone as day he went out of þis town
This man gan fallyn in suspecioune
Remembryng of his dremys þat he met
And forth he goith no lenger wold he let
On to the west gate of the town ⁊and fonde
A dung cart went for to dung londe
That was a raid in the same wise
As yee to forn have herd me devise
And with an hardy hert he gan to cry
Venyaunce and Iustice for this felony
My felaw mordrid is this same nyȝte
And in this cart he lijth vp riȝte
I cry out on the mynstirs quod he
That shuld kepe and rewill this Cete
Harow Allas her lijth my felaw scleyn
What shuld I more on to this tale seyn
The pepill vp stert and kist the cart to grounde
And in the myddil of the cart they founde
The dede man that mordrid was al newe
O blesful God þat art so Iust ⁊and trewe
Lo how þat þow be wreyist mordir al wey
Mordir woll out that see wee al day
Mordir is so lothsom ⁊and abominabill
To God that is so iust and resonabill
That he ne woll suffir it hidto be
Thouȝ it abyde a yeer or to or thre
Mordir woll out this is my conclusyoune
And riȝte a noon the mynystris of þe town
Hath hent the Carter and so sore hym peynyd
And eke the hostelere so sore engynyd
That they be knewe hir wiccidnes a noon
And were on hongit by the nek boon
Here mow yee see that dremys be to drede
And certis in the same book I rede
Riȝte in the next Chaptir aftir this
I gab nat so have I Ioy or blys
Too men þat wold pas ovir the see
For certen causis in to ferr contre
Ȝyff that the wynd ne had been contᵃry
That made hem in a Cete for to tary
That stode ful mery oppon an havyn syde
But on a day a geyn the even tyde
The wynde gan chaunge ⁊and blew riȝt as hym list
Ioly and glad they went to rest
And Casten hem ful erly for to seyll
But to the too man fill a grete mervaill
The toon of hem in sclepeing as he lay
He met a wondir dreme a geyn the day
Hym þouȝt a man stode by his beddis syde
And hym comaundit that he shuld a bide
And seyd hym thus yf thow to morow wende
how shalt be dreynt my tale is atta ende
e wook ⁊and told his felaw what he met
nd preyd hym his viage for to lett
s for that day he preyd hym for to byde
is felaw that lay by his beddis syde
Gan for to lawȝ ⁊and scornyd hym ful fast
No dreme quod he may my hert a gast
That I woll let for to do my thingis
I set nat a straw be eny dremeyngis
For dremys been but vanytees ⁊and Iapis
Men dreme al day of owlis ⁊and of Apis
And eke of many a mase ther with all
Men dreme of thingis þat nevir was ne shall
But sith I see þow wold her abyde
And thus for sclouȝthyn wilfully þy tyde
God woot þat rewith me ⁊and have good day
And thus he toke his leve ⁊and went his way
But or he had halff his cours I seylid
Note I what myschaunce hym eylid
But casuelly the Shippis botom rent
nd Shipp ⁊and man vndir þe water went
n siȝte of othir Shippis it besyde
That with hem saylid atte same tyde
And therfor dame Pertelot so dere
By such ensaumplis old may yee lere
That no man shuld be to rechelese
Of dremys for I sey the doutlese
That many a dreme ful sore is for to drede
Lo in the lyff of kenelme I rede
That was kenulphus sone þe nobill kyng
Of mertrik how kenelm met a thing
A litil to fore he was mordrid on a day
His murdir in his visioune he say
His Noryse hym expownyd every dele
Of his swevyn and bad kepe hym wele
Fro treson but he was but vij yeer old
And therfor litill tale ther of he told
Of eny dreme so holy was his hert
Be god I had levir þen my shert
That yee had red his legend as have I
Madame Pertelot I sey ȝew trewly
Macrobeus that wrote the Avisioune
In Affrikk of the worthy cyprione
Affermyth dremys and seith þᵗat þey been
Warnyng of thingis þat men aftir seen
And ferthirmore I prey ȝew look wele
In the old testament of danyele
Ȝyff he held dremys eny vanyte
Rede eke of Ioseph and ther shul yee see
What dremys been som tyme I sey nat all
Warnyng of thingis þat shal aftir fall
Loke of Egipt the kynge Pharao
His baker ⁊and his boteler also
Wher þey ne felt noon effect in dremys
Who so woll seke actis ⁊and sendry Remys
May rede of dremys many a wondir thing
Lo how Creseus þat was a worthy kyng
Met nat he nat how he sat oppon a tre
Wich signifijd þat he shuld hongit be
¶ Lo here Andremacha Ectoris wyff
That day that Ector shuld lese his lyff
She dremyd on the same nyȝt to forn
How that the lyff of Ector shuld be lorn
Ȝyff that day he went in to batell
She warnyd hym but it myȝt nat a Vaill
He went forth to fiȝt nethirlese
But he was scleyn a noon of Achilles
But þat tale is al to long to tell
And eke it is nere day I may nat dwell
Shortly I sey and for conclusioune
That I shall have of this avisioune
Of this advercite ⁊and I sey ferthirmore
That I ne gyff of laxatiuis no store
For they been venemo9 it woot it wele
I hem diffy I love hem nevir a dele
Now lete vs speke of myrth ⁊and stynt al this
Madame Pertelot so have I Ioy or blis
Of o thing God hath sent me a large grace
For when I se the bewte of yeur fase
Yee be so scarlet rede a bowt yeur eyen
That it makith al my drede to dyen
And when I fele a nyȝt yeur sofft side
Al be it I may nat on ȝew ryde
For that our perche is made so narow Allas
I am so ful of Ioy ⁊and of solas
That I diffy both Swevyn ⁊and dreme
And wᵗith þat word he fly fro the beme
For it was day ⁊and eke his hennys all
And wᵗith a chuk he gan hem for to call
For he had found a corn that lay in þe ȝerd
Ryall he was ⁊and no more a ferd
He fetherid Pertelot more þen xx tyme
And trad hir as offt or it were pryme
He lokid as it were a grym lyoun
And on his tois he romyth vp ⁊and down
Hym deynyth nat to set his fote to ground
And chukkith when he hath a corn I found
And on to hym then ron his wyvis all
As riall as a prynce in his hall
Now leve I this Chaunteclere in his pasture
And aftir woll I tell his aventure
When that the tyme in wich the world be gan
That hit march when God first made man
I complete was and passid also
Syn it be gan twenty dayis and to
Be fill that Chaunteclere in al his pride
With his vij . wyvis walking hym be syde
Cast vp his eyen into the hiȝe sone
That in the signe of Taurus had I ron
Twenty degreis ⁊and oon ⁊and som what more
He knew be kynde ⁊and by noon othir lore
That it was pryme ⁊and crew wᵗith a blesful steven
The sone he seyd is clombe onto hevyn
Fourty degrees ⁊and oon ⁊and more I wis
Madam Pertelot my worldis blis
Herken these blesful briddis how þey synge
And se the Fressh flowris how þey spryng
Ful is my hert of myrth and of solase
But sodenly hym fill in a sorowful case
For evir the latt̉er ende of Ioy is woo
God woot þat worldy Ioy is sone ago
And yf a rothir cowd feir endite
He in Cronicul saffly myȝt write
Ȝe for a soveren notabilite
Now eủery man lete hym herk to me
This story is also trew I vndirtake
As is the book of launcelou delake
That vommen hold in ful grete reverence
Now woll I turn a geyn to my centence
A colfox ful of Iniquyte
That in the grove had wonyd yeeris thre
By ymagynacioun a fore cast
The same nyȝt þurh out the hegg he brast
In to the ȝerd ther as chaunteclere the feir
Was wont and eke his wyvis to repeyr
And in a bedd of wortis still he lay
Tyll it was past ondryn of the day
Wayting his tyme on Chaunteclere to fall
As gladly doon these homycidis all
That in a wayte liggen to mordir men
O fals murdrer liggyng in thy den
O new Scariot new gAneloure
O fals dissimulour o greke savour
That brouȝtist troy al vttirly to sorow
O Chaunteclere a cursid be the morow
That thow in to the ȝerd fle fro the bemys
Thow were ful wele warnyd of thy dremys
That ilk day was perlous on to the
But what God woll nedis must be
Aftir the oppynyoun of certen clerkis
Witnes of hym that ꝑparfite clerkis
That in the Scole is grete Altircacioun
In this mater and grete disputacioun
And hath been of an C Ml men
But I ne can bult out fro the bren
As can the holy doctour Augustyne
Or boyis or bisshopp Bradwardyn
Whethir that goddis forȝeting
Streynyd me nedely to do this thynge
Nedely clepe I necessite
Or els yf fre choyse be grauntid me
To do the same thing or do it nouȝt
Thouȝe God for woot or it were wrouȝt
Or yff his wetyng strengith nevir a dele
But by necessite condicionele
I wol nat have to do of such matere
My tale ys of a Cok as yee may here
That toke his counsell of his wyff wᵗith sorow
To walken in the ȝerd on the morow
That for the dreme he met as I to fore told
Vommenys counsell brouȝt vs first to woo
And made Adam from paradise to go
There as he was ful mery at wele at ese
But for I woot nat whom I myȝt displese
Ȝyff I counsell of vommen wold blame
Pas ovir I seyd it in my game
Rede Autours wher they trete of such matere
And what they sey of vommen yee mow here
These been the kokkis wordis ⁊and nat myne
I can no harm of vommen devyne
Feir in the sone to bath hir merely
Lijth Pertelot and hir sustirs her by
A geyn the sone and Chaunteclere so fre
Sang merier then the Meremayde in the see
For pheselogus seith sikirly
How that they syngyn wele ⁊and merely
And so be fill as he kist his eye
Amon the wortis on a botirfly
He was ware of the Fox þat lay ful low
No thing thou list hym for to crow
But cried a noon Cokk Cok ⁊and vp he stert
As a man that was for frayid in his hert
For naturelly a beest desirith to flee
From his contrary yf he may hym se
Thouȝe he nevir erst had seyn it wᵗith his eye
This Chaunteclere when he gan hym espy
He wold have fled but that the Fox Anoon
Seyd gentil sir allas whethir woll ye goon
Be yee a fraid of me that am yeur frende
Now certis I were wors then a fende
Ȝyff I to ȝew wold harm or vylony
I am nat com yeur counsell to espy
But trewly the cause of my comyng
Was oonly to herkyn how yee song
For sikirly yee have a mery Stevyn
As an Aungell hath that is in hevyn
And ther with yee have a musik more felyng
Then had boyes or eny othir that can syng
My lorde yeur Fadir God his soule bles
And eke yeur modir of hir gentilnes
Have in my house be to my grete ese
And certis sir ful feyn I wold ȝew plese
But for men speke of syngyng I woll sey
So wele mut I broken wele myn eyen twey
That I ne herd nevir man so synge
As did yeur Fadir in the mornyng
Certis it was of hert al that he songe
And for to make his voise the more stronge
He wold so peyn hym that with both his eyen
He must wynk so lowd he must crien
And stond on his tipto ther̉e with all
And strech forth his nek long ⁊and small
And eke he was of such discresioune
That ther was no man in no Regioune
That hym in songe or wisdom myȝt pas
I have wele red of dame Burnell the Asse
Among his vers how that ther was a Cok
That for a prestis sone gaff hym a knok
Oppon his legge while he was yong ⁊and nyce
He made hym for to lese his benyfice
But certis ther is noon comparisoune
Be twix the wisdom and discrecioune
Of yeur Fadir and his subtilite
Now syngith sir for seynt charite
Lete see can yeur Fadir countirfete
This Chaunteclere his wyngis gan bete
As man that cowd nat his treson espy
So was he ravisshid with his flatery
Be ware yee lordis of their trechery
This Chauntclere stode hiȝe oppon his tois
Strecchyng his hede And held his nek close
And gan to crow lowd for the nonys
And the Colfox dan Russell stert vp attonys
And by the gorget hent Chaunteclere
And on his bak to the wood hym bere
For ȝit was no man þat hym suyd
O desteny that may nat be eschuyd
Allas that Chauntclere fle fro the bemys
Allas his wyff rouȝt nat of dremys
On a fryday fill al this myschaunce
O venus that art Goddes of plesaunce
Sithen that thy servaunt was this Chauntcler
And in thy service did al his powere
More for delite then the world to multiply
Why woldist thow suffir hym on thy day to dy
O gaynford dere mastir sovereyn
That when kyng Richard was I scleyn
With shott compleyndist his deth so sore
Why had I now thy centence ⁊and thy lore
The fryday for to chyde as did yee
For on a fryday shortly scleyn was he
Then woll I shew ȝew how I cowd compleyn
For Chauntecleris drede ⁊and for his peyn
Certis such a cry and lamentacioune
Was nevir of ladies made when Ilyoun
Was wonne ⁊and pirrous wᵗith his streit swerd
When he had hent kyng Pryamus by þe hede
And scleyn hym as seith vs Enedose
As maden al the hennys in the close
When they did see of Chaunteclere þe siȝte
And namely Dame Pertelot so verely shrite
Ful louder then did Hasdrubaldis wyff
When hir husbond had lost his lyff
And that the Romeyns had brent Cartage
She was so ful of Cakill and of rage
That wilfully in to the Feir she stert
And brent hir selff with a stedfast hert
O wofull hennys riȝt so cried yee
As when that Nero brent the Cete
Of Room so cried the Cenatours wyvis
For that hir husbondis had lost hir lyvis
With out gilt This Nero hath hem scleyn
Now woll I turn to my tale ageyn
This sely wedow ⁊and eke hir douȝtryn to
Herden these hennys criden ⁊and made woo
And out atte dor stert they a noon
And saw the Fox toward the wood goon
And bare on his bak the Cok a way
And they cried out ⁊and welawey
Ha ha the Fox and aftir hem they ron
And eke with stavis many a nothir man
Ran Coll hir dogg Talbot ⁊and eke Garlonde
And Malkyn with a distaff in hir honde
Ran Cow ran Calff ran eke the very hoggis
For feer of berkyng of the doggis
And also the shewting of men ⁊and vommen eke
The ron al til hir þouȝt hir hertis breke
They yolden as Fendis doon in hell
The doggis criden as men wold hem quell
The gees for feer fleyn ovir the treis
Out of the hyve comyth the swarm of beis
So hydously was the noyse a benedicite
Certis Iak Straw ⁊and al his meyne
Ne made showtis half so shrill
When that they wold eny flemyng kill
As on that day was made oppon þat Fox
Of bras they brouȝten bemys ⁊and of boxe
Of horn of boon in wich they blew ⁊and popid
And ther with al they shrityd ⁊and hopid
It semyd as heven shuld have fall
Now good men I prey ȝew herk all
Lo how Fortune turnyth sodenly
The hope of pride ⁊and eke of hir envy
This Cok þat lay oppon this Foxis bakk
In al his drede on to the Fox spak
And seyd sir yff I weer as yee
Ȝit wold I sey so wisly God help me
Turnyth a geyn yee prowd Chorlis all
A verry pestelence oppon ȝew fall
Now I am com to þe wodis syde
Magre yeur hede þe Cokk shal her a bide
I wol hym ete in feith ⁊and þat a noon
The Fox answerd in feith it shal be doon
And as he spak that word al sodenly
The Cok brake from his mowith dylyủerly
And hiȝe oppon a tree he flyȝ a noon
And when the Fox saw the kok was goon
Allas quod he o Chaunteclere Allas
I have to ȝew doon grete trespas
In as much as I made ȝew a ferd
When I ȝew hent ⁊and brouȝt out of yeʳ ȝerd
But sith I did it in no wiccid entent
Com down ⁊and I shal tel ȝew myne entent
I shal sey soth to ȝew god help me so
Nay þen quod he I shrew vs both to
And first I shrew my selff both blood ⁊and bonys
Ȝyff yee begile me eny more þen onys
Thow shalt no more þurh thy flatery
Do me to synge ⁊and wynk with myne eye
For he that wynkith when he shuld se
Al wilfully God let hym nevir the
Nay quod the Fox God gyff hym myschaunce
That is so vndiscrete of governaunce
That Iangelith when he shuld hold his pese
Lo what it is for to be Recheles
And feir wordis ⁊and trust on flatery
But yee that hold this tale of foly
As of a Fox or of a Cok or of an henne
Takith hede to the Moralite good men
For seynt poule seith all þat writen is
To our doctryne it is writen I wis
Takith the fruyte ⁊and let the chaff be still
Now good God yff it be ye in will
As thow art lord so make vs al good men
And bryng vs to thy blis amen

l.hi:
Here endith the tale of þe Nonnys preest of Chᵃuntclere
And of Pertelot And here þe mancipil his tale ;

div.l: (base) Here bigynneth the Manciples tale of the Crowe
(base) Narrat
(base) Whan Phebus dwelled here in this erthe adoun
(base) As olde bokes maken mencioun
(base) He was the mooste lusty bachiler
(base) In al this world and eek the beste Archer
(base) He slow Phitoun the serpent as he lay
(base) Slepynge agayn the sonne vpon a day
(base) And many another noble worthy dede
(base) He with his bowe wroghte as men may rede
(base) Pleyen he koude on euery Mynstralcye
(base) And syngen that it was a melodye
(base) To heren of his clere voys the soun
(base) Certes the kyng of Thebes Amphioun

div.l: (base) Kepe wel thy tonge and thynk vpon the Crowe

(base) Explicit fabula mancipij

Here endith the mancipil his tale
And here begynnyth the person his Prologg
By that the mancipill had his tale endit
The son fro the south side is discendit
So low that he nas to my siȝte
Degreis of xxv of his hiȝte
Ten atte Clokk it was as I ges
For enlevyn foot a litill more or les
My shadew was at þat tyme as there
Of such feet as my feetlengithfeetlengith partid were
In six foot equally of proporcioun
Ther wᵗith the monys exaltacioune
I meen libra alwey gan assende
As wee were entryng atte a towyis ende
For wich our hoost as he was wont to guy
As in this caas this Ioly company
Seyd in this wise lordingis everychon
Now lakkith vs no tale mo then oon
Fulfillid is my centence and my degre
Who woll now tell a tale let se
Almost fulfillid is myne ordenaunce
I prey to God so gyve hym riȝt good chᵃunce
That tellith this tale to vs lustely
Sir Preest quod he art þow a Vikery
Art þow a person sey soth by thy fey
Be what þow be breke nat our pley
For every man save þow hath told his tale
Vnbokill ⁊and shew what is in thy male
For trewly me thinkith by thy chere
Thow shuldist wele knet vp a grete matere
Tell vs a fabill anoon for kokkis bonys
This persone answerd al attonys
Thow getist fabill noon told for me
For paule þat writith to Thimothe
Reprevith hem that weyvith sothfastnes
Or tellyn fablis or such wrecchidnes
Why shuld I sow draff out of my Fist
When I may sow whete yf that me lest
For wich I sey yf thow list to here
Moralite and of vertuous matere
And then yff yee woll gyve me audience
I wold ful feyn at Cristis reverence
Do ȝew plesaunce leful as I can
But trustith wele I am a borel man
I can nat gest rum ram ruff be lettir
And god woot ryme hold I but litill bett̉er
And therfor yff yee list I wol nat glose
I woll ȝew tell a mery tale in prose
To knet vp al this Feest ⁊and make an ende
And Ihu for his grace wit me sende
To shew ȝew the wey in this viage
Of that ilk glorious pilgremage
That hiȝte Ierlm Celestiall
And yff yee vouch saff anoon I shall
Be gyn oppon my tale for wich I prey
Tell yeur a vise I can no bettir sey
But nethirles this meditacioune
I put ay vndir correccioune
Of Clerkis for I am nat textuell
I take but the centence trustith wele
Therfor I make protestacioune
That I woll stond to correccioune
Oppon this word wee have assentid sone
For as it semed it was for to doon
To enden in som vertuous centence
And for to gyve hym space ⁊and audience
And bad our hoost to hym sey
To tell his tale wee hym prey
Our hoost / had the wordis for vs all
Sir Preest quod he now feir mut yee be fall
Seith what yee list and wee shull gladly here
And with þat word he seid in this manere
Tellith quod he yeur meditacioune
But hastith ȝew þe sone wol a down
Be fructuouse and þat in litill spase
And to do wele God send ȝew his grase

div.ab: (base) Here bigynneth the Persons tale

(base) Iere 6ᵒ State super vias et videte et interrogate de semitis
antiquis que sit via bona et ambulate in ea et inuenietis refrigerium animabus vestris et cetera

(base) Ovre swete lord god of heuene that no man wole
perisse but wole that we comen alle to the kNoweliche
of hym and to the blisful lyf that is pardurable
(base) amonesteth vs by the prophete Ieromie that seith in this wise

(base) Stondeth vp on the weyes and seeth and axeth of olde pathes that is to seyn of olde sentences which is the goode
wey
(base) and walketh in that wey and ye shal fynde refresshynge for youre soules et cetera

(base) Manye been the weyes espirituels that leden folk to oure lord Ihesu crist and to the regne
of glorie

(base) of whiche weyes ther is a ful noble wey and
a ful couenable which may nat faile to man ne to womman that thurgh synne hath mysgoon fro the righte wey
of Ierusalem celestial

(base) and this wey is clepid Penitence
of which men sholde gladly herknen and enquere with al
his herte

(base) to wite what is penitence and whennes it is
clepid penitence and in how manye maneres been the accions
or werkynges of penitence

(base) and how manye spices ther
ben of penitences and whiche thynges apertenen and bihouen to penitence whiche thynges destourben penitence

(base) Seint Ambrose seith that penitence is the pleynynge of
man for the gilt that he hath doon and namoore to doon
any thyng for which hym oghte to pleyne

(base) And som dectour seith Penitence is the waymentynge of man that sorweth for his synne and pyneth hym self for he hath
mysdoon

(base) Penitence with certeyne circumstances is verray
repentance of a man that halt hym self in sorwe and oother
peyne for hise giltes

(base) and for he shal be verray penitent
he shal first biwailen the synnes that he hath doon and
stedefastly purposen in his herte to haue shrift of mouthe
and to doon satisfaccioun

(base) and neuere to doon thyng for which
hym oghte moore to biwaile or to compleyne and to continue in goode werkes or ellis his repentance may nat auayle

(base) For as seith Seint Isydre he is a Iapere and a gabbere and
no verray repentant that eft soone dooth thyng for which hym
oghte repente

(base) wepynge and nat for to stynte to do synne
may nat auaile

(base) But nathelees men shal hope that at euery
tyme that man falleth be it neuer so ofte that he may arise thurgh
penitence if he haue grace but certeynly it is greet

dowithe

(base) for
as seith Seint Gregorie vnnethe ariseth he out of his synne

(base) and ther fore
repentant folk that stynte for to synne and forlete synne er that

(base) The firste is that if a man be baptised after that he hath synned

Augustyn seith but he be penitent for his olde synful lyf he may

oute penitence of his olde gilt he receyueth the mark of baptesme but nat the grace ne the remissioun of hise synnes til he haue repentance verray

deedly synne after that they han receyued baptesme

thridde defaute is that men fallen in venyal synnes after

(base) ther of seith Seint Augustyn
That penitence of goode and of humble folk is the penitence

(base) The speces of penaunce been iij that oon of

(base) Contricioun of herte

(base) for which seith Seint Iohn Grisostomus

(base) and this is
fruytful penitence agayn iij thynges in whiche we wrathe oure

(base) this is to seyn by delit in thynkynge by recchelesnesse in spekynge by wikked synful wirkynge

(base) and agayns
thise wikkede giltes is penitence that may be likned vn to a tree

(base) The roote of this tree is contricioun that hideth hym in the herte of

(base) Of the roote of Contricioun spryngeth a stalke
that bereth branches and leues of confessioun and fruyt of satisfaccioun

(base) for which crist seith in his gospel dooth digne fruyt
of penitence for by this fruyt may men kNowe this tree and
nat by the roote that is hyd in the herte of man ne by the branches ne the leues of Confessioun

(base) And therfore oure Lord Ihesu crist
seith thus by the fruyt of hem shul ye kNowe hem

roote eek spryngeth a Seed of grace the which Seed is moder

(base) the grace of thys

(base) Of this matere seith Salomon that
in the drede of god man forleteth his synne

seed is the loue of god and the desirynge of the Ioye pardurable

(base) for soothly ther is no thyng that sauoureth so wel

oother mete

(base) but fro that
tyme that he loueth sadly oure lord Ihesu crist and desireth the lyf
pardurable ther nys to hym no thyng moore abhomynable

(base) for soothly the lawe of god is the loue of god for which
Dauid the prophete seith I haue loued thy lawe and hated wikkednesse and hate he that loueth god kepeth his lawe and his word

(base) this tree saugh the prophete Daniel in Spirit vp on the auysion of
Nabugodonosor whanne he conseiled hym

to do penitence
